fields.headline: James MacMillan triumphs in Manchester
fields.standfirst:
The Kingsbury Manx
Water Rats, London ***
fields.trailText:
The Kingsbury Manx
Water Rats, London ***
fields.body:
In their riot of visual understatement, The Kingsbury Manx suggest a new derivation of math-rock that has little to do with rigorously precise musicianship and everything with their dweebish collegiate demeanour.

It suddenly becomes quite apparent why their eponymous debut album was delivered to prospective patrons without any visual representation of the creators - it would have been hard to credit this arresting specimen of pastoral groove with a group the coolest member of which is a Frasier Crane lookalike.

Bill Taylor and his three fellow renegades from the common room are presumably grateful that with rock at this advanced post-everything stage you don't have to be a showman to put on a show.

Taylor and Stephenson have a way with peeling every layer of nuance from each guitar chord, revealing small but absolute truths at their core, while Scott Myers' organ lends matters a vital security blanket of warm synthetics. It's as well their instrumental proficiency is so real, for vocally it seems the Manx are driving without a licence. Taylor apologises for the lack of high harmonies, an absence due not to some AWOL member but rather sheer larynx fatigue, unaccustomed as they are to such a torrid workload.

fields.headline: Multi-culturalism meets multi-media
fields.standfirst:
Tan Dun festival
Barbican, London **
fields.trailText:
Tan Dun festival
Barbican, London **
fields.body:
Ever since he moved to Manhattan from China in 1986, Tan Dun's compositional career has continued to cross geographical and musical continents. The Barbican's weekend-long festival, Fire Crossing Water, was an appropriately diverse showcase of some of his most recent collaborations, featuring artists such as cellist Yo-Yo Ma and film director Ang Lee.

All of Tan Dun's compositions programmed in the festival - played by the London Sinfonietta and BBC Symphony Orchestra, sung by London Voices, and conducted by Tan Dun himself - are grounded in the aesthetic principles of multi-culturalism and multi-media.

His radically universalist vision seeks to demonstrate that all cultures are equivalent in their essential humanity and common compassion - an ideal as artistically watertight as it is politically unassailable. But in practice, the terms of Tan Dun's fusion of different cultures and media are creatively problematic.

There was a telling contrast between Tan Dun's realisation of multi-media in the world premiere of his Crouching Tiger Concerto - written for Yo-Yo Ma and bawu soloist Jun Qiao Tang, and accompanied by images derived from Ang Lee's forthcoming film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - and Bill Viola's video for Edgard Varèse's Déserts, performed live by the BBCSO and Pierre André Valade.

Introducing the Crouching Tiger Concerto, Tan Dun and Ang Lee spoke of their attempt to invert the usual priorities of the interaction between film and music.

Instead of music enhancing a cinematic narrative, here the music's drama - driven by Yo-Yo Ma's contributions - was the catalyst for Lee's images. Tan Dun's music was a series of immediately attractive and descriptive episodes - exactly like a suite from the most conventional film score.

In the end, Ang Lee's and James Schamus's discontinuous, improvisational film had very little room to produce any creative friction with this transparent, directly affecting music.

At the other end of the spectrum, Bill Viola's video-track for Varèse's Déserts articulated the real possibilities of multi-media collaborations. Imitating - but never slavishly mimicking - the music's elemental changes of texture and mood, Viola's editing created an interpretative space between image and music.

In comparison, Tan Dun's Crouching Tiger Concerto allowed only the narrowest gap for difference or imagination.

A directness of musical communication is also an essential part of Tan Dun's multi-culturalism. In The Gate: Orchestral Theatre IV, Tan Dun dramatises the deaths of three legendary women from Japanese, Chinese and English-speaking cultures, all of whom commit suicide: Yu Ji, from the story Farewell my Concubine, Shakespeare's Juliet, and Koharu, a central figure of the Japanese drama The Love Suicides at Amijima.

Three soloists represented these respective cultures, with Beijing Opera Actress Shi Min, classical soprano Nancy Allen Lundy, and Japanese puppeteer Hua Hua Zhang.

Tan Dun's music dramatises each of the women's stories with a mix of expressionist outbursts and generic, folk-music modality. The piece tells the three stories against the backdrop of this suggestively cinematic music.

For Tan Dun, the fact that he features three different cultures is enough to make the piece meaningfully multi-dimensional. But the combination of all this music and theatre is mystifyingly bland.

Water Passion after St Matthew, composed in response to Bach's St Matthew Passion, encapsulates the problem.

When each piece comprises so many different elements - like Water Passion's performance-art percussion-playing with 17 bowls of water, an oratorio-style chorus, and instrumental and vocal soloists - the compositional interest is in how Tan Dun weaves them together.

But Tan Dun simply appropriates the surface power of individual gestures and styles. There is no real engagement with each kind of musical material. For all the grandiose theorising behind much of Tan Dun's music, the actual results in performance are frustratingly predictable.

Tan Dun's mix of media may be innovative, in some sense, for the concert hall. But the way Tan Dun synthesises his panoply of cultural sources is skilfully manipulative rather than radically contemporary.

fields.headline: Armatrading on tour
fields.standfirst:
Joan Armatrading
Barbican Centre, York **
fields.trailText:
Joan Armatrading
Barbican Centre, York **
fields.body:
After 27 years in the business, Joan Armatrading is touring without an album to promote, any new material to air or even a T-shirt stand in the lobby.

Now into her fiftieth year, she seems to be touring simply in order to confirm that she still exists.

So what has tempted this country-dwelling, childrens-comic-reading, chart-untroubling enigma back onthe road again? It can only be the love and affection of a hard-core of adoring fans- in which case the singer must have surveyed this somnambulant opening-night audience and wondered why she bothered.

The last time Armatrading played here there was dancing in the aisles; but then the last time she brought a drummer and a bass player with her. This tour sees Armatrading strip everything back to a trio; herself, her guitar and her huge, miraculous voice flanked by two gangling figures - the staggeringly versatile multi-instrumentalists Gary Spacey-Foot and Spencer Cousins - whose job is to drape a variety of sparse, jazzy textures around Armatrading's robust, melodic soul-pop.

This is tasteful in the extreme, but having noodled her way into the set with a laid-back lounge-piano arrangement of Drop the Pilot, you get the impression that Armatrading intends to spend the evening doing cover versions of her own material.

Isn't this what tribute bands are for? On second thoughts, isn't this what Tracy Chapman is for?

fields.headline: Sinaisky
fields.standfirst:
BBC Philharmonic Orchestra / Sinaisky
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****
fields.trailText:
BBC Philharmonic Orchestra / Sinaisky
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****
fields.body:
You could tell that few of the enormous crowd in the Bridgwater Hall were there for Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony, even though Vassily Sinaisky was conducting. (It was a magnificent performance, from its gentlest to its harshest moments, and Sinaisky's control of the design is unassailable.)

The tangible excitement was for the arrival of James MacMillan at the BBC Philharmonic for a three-year stint with the ugly title of Composer/Conductor. That a composer in his early forties can drum up such support is no accident. The ground has been prepared with a care that must gladden the heart of anybody who is at all worried about the future of serious music.

Given his apparently inexhaustible energy, he has begun with a week-long MacMillan in Manchester festival, and there will be another next February. With his aggressive commitment to music in education he has already been working intensively with children at the Manchester Grammar School and Withington Girls' School.

In the opening concert they sang his recent Magnificat, a work that helps to explain why MacMillan has been so successful. The choral writing is remarkably simple: the schoolchildren can have had very little difficulty learning it, and they sang it with an ease and commitment that contributed powerfully to its religious message.

At the same time, though, MacMillan knows how to write for a professional orchestra in a way that challenges them and keeps them on their toes. The two contrasting styles blended bizarrely and with considerable success.

His shorter Exsultet that opened the concert showed an entirely different kind of music: a slow, almost minimalist, accumulation of brass textures that grew to a mighty climax - relatively simple but highly effective.

And then yet another kind of music followed these, his Veni, Veni, Emmanuel. In the eight years since it was composed this has become a classic and seems likely to stay firmly in the repertory as the finest existing percussion concerto: repeated hearing brings to light more and more fascinating internal details in the endlessly resourceful scoring.

As a conductor, MacMillan controlled the varying speeds with considerable skill. But much of its success was due to the solo playing of Colin Currie, whose athletic percussionism blended his almost compulsive showmanship with an increasingly deep musicality.

Even so, the overwhelming impression of the three MacMillan works together was the range of his invention and that there was not a moment that lacked a burning intensity.

We can safely predict that MacMillan's tenure with the BBC Philharmonic will be a continued triumph.

fields.headline: FSA verdict on mortgages 'incomplete'
fields.standfirst:
Jessica McCallin on the lukewarm response to the FSA's report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jessica McCallin on the lukewarm response to the FSA's report.
fields.body:
Consumers groups have slammed the financial services watchdog for failing to identify firms which mis-sold endowments mortgages, whilst claiming that policyholders are no worse off than repayment customers.

In its progress report on mortgage endowment complaints, the Financial Services Authority said 60% of the 11m endowments still in force are not on track to repay the mortgage, but that a full-scale review of all past sales is not necessary. Instead, it points consumers to its factsheet, which explains what to do if they think they have been mis-sold a policy. The FSA added that most customers will have paid out less money in premiums than others will have paid in mortgage repayments.

In response, the Consumers' Association said the report was incomplete and that the job of a regulator should be to protect consumers and identify companies and products that are offering a poor deal. The factsheet, while helpful, places the burden on consumers to get hold of the information and then contact firms and work out compensation, it added.

Comments from FSA chairman Howard Davies that endowment customers have fared better than repayment ones were dismissed as ridiculous. A spokesperson for the Consumers Association said: "People took out endowments because they thought they would pay of their mortgages. To say someone paying endowment premiums over the past 10 years will have paid out less and, therefore, be better off than someone paying by repayment is irrelevant and ridiculous. Less money may have left the endowment policyholder's bank account, but they still don't have enough money to repay their mortgage and will need to increase the monthly payment. On the other hand, someone using a repayment policy will have paid off significant amounts of their mortgage and, in our opinion, have fared significantly better than endowment holders."

The endowments selling fiasco centres on the projections customers were given for the growth of their policy when they bought it. Many were quoted annual growth rates of between 8% and 11% and had premiums set accordingly. But policies have only been growing at around 6% or 7% a year, leaving customers with endowments that will not pay off their mortgage at maturity.

Research by the Guardian in April revealed that up to 3m UK households could be affected by a shortfall, some by as much as 40%. These policyholders have several options, including increasing their monthly premiums, cashing the policy or taking out an additional mortgage product to pay of the shortfall.

webTitle: Business: House prices make a comeback

fields.headline: House prices make a comeback
fields.trailText: The downturn in house prices may prove to be short-lived Nationwide Building Society said yesterday after revealing that average prices rose last month for the first time since June.
fields.body:
The downturn in house prices may prove to be short-lived Nationwide Building Society said yesterday after revealing that average prices rose last month for the first time since June.

The average house price, seasonally adjusted, rose 0.4% to £80,672 in September according to the Nationwide index. In July and August the index saw falls of 0.2% and 0.6% respectively.

Nationwide also made one of the most bullish forecasts on the property market for months. It said that, although prices were likely to remain flat for the rest of this year, they were likely to recover in spring, with 2001 enjoying house price growth of between 5% to 7%.

Chief economist Alex Bannister says that recent falls indicate a market pausing for breath rather than facing a meltdown. "It's good that the market slowed down after a clearly unsustainable run ear lier in the year, but we are not standing at the edge of a cliff. An upward trend in annual house price inflation is likely to recur, although it may not be until next spring," he said.

He predicts a resurgence in the market, driven by rising real take home pay and improved confidence among first time buyers. But Nationwide admitted that its forecasts for 2000 had proved wrong. At the beginning of the year it predicted that prices would rise nationally by 11%, but it now believes the out-turn will be closer to 7%. It adds that London, which saw the biggest rises earlier in the year, may continue to see declines for a few more months.

"Although monthly mortgage payments are low historically, absolute values are stretching first-time buyers' ability to raise large enough mortgages and deposits. In London, an average first-time buyer would typically need to earn £34,000 compared to £27,000 a year ago," it said.

fields.headline: Pascal Rog&eacute
fields.standfirst:
Ysaÿe Quartet / Pascal Rogé ****
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Ysaÿe Quartet / Pascal Rogé ****
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
fields.body:
This was France's night at the South Bank's International Chamber Music Season: one of Paris's finest ensembles, the Ysaÿe Quartet, were joined by a Parisian pianist of similar calibre, Pascal Rogé, for a programme concentrating on the music of their home city.

The first item in the concert was, however, from the Germanic classical era - the starting point for all the chamber music traditions that followed, including that of France. The Ysaÿes caught the sense of indecision in the opening unison bars of Beethoven's Quartet Op 18 No 1, before playing the rest of the first movement with a light, sweet touch. Their heightened sense of sonority, contrast and colour was to the fore in the slow second movement, with first violinist Guillaume Sutre letting the melody creep in high on the D-string. A scherzo of energy dissolved the tension and, even though a couple of slips let down the carefree flourish of the finale, this was a performance with a lot of flair.

The broad, portentous opening melody of Fauré's first Piano Quartet set a different atmosphere. With the piano now on hand to provide much of the textural detail, the violin, viola and cello were given more soloistic roles. Their melodies were always sensitively shaped, but at times a little reticent; indeed, throughout the recital it seemed the string players perhaps expected their quieter solos to carry slightly more easily in the hall's dry acoustics than was actually the case.

Where Sutre had been the driving force in the Beethoven, now the pianist Rogé became the bedrock of the ensemble. The string players gave him barely a glance, but his communication with them was apparent in every rubato and shaping of a phrase.

All four members of the quartet joined Rogé for César Franck's Quintet in F Minor. Franck's writing explored all the textural possibilities of the ensemble, and second violinist Luc-Marie Aguera and violist Miguel da Silva were called upon to play more intensely than before.

Nothing in the last two movements could equal the way the ensemble wound the tension up at the end of the first movement, but their playing throughout was impassioned and utterly convincing. Dvorak's Scherzo from his Op 81 Quintet, performed as an encore, lightened the mood - but still didn't see the players miss a beat.

webTitle: Knives out for Lippi as Inter lose again

fields.headline: Knives out for Lippi as Inter lose again
fields.trailText: The pressure on Internazionale's coach Marcello Lippi increased yesterday after the Milanese club slipped to a shock 2-1 defeat at Reggina on the opening weekend of an Italian league season delayed by Olympic commitments.
fields.body:
The pressure on Internazionale's coach Marcello Lippi increased yesterday after the Milanese club slipped to a shock 2-1 defeat at Reggina on the opening weekend of an Italian league season delayed by Olympic commitments.

Inter seemed to be heading in the right direction when their Uruguayan striker Alvaro Recoba scored after 10 minutes. But Davide Possanzini equalised on the stroke of half-time and Massimo Marazzina hit the winner five minutes after the interval.

Lippi, under fire since Inter were knocked out of the Champions League by Helsingborg, said: "I am ashamed to have presented a squad that has played in that manner and without heart."

Roma were 2-0 winners at home to Bologna in a game which marked Gabriel Batistuta's debut. Francesco Totti put Roma ahead in the 27th minute and a 67th-minute own-goal by Marcello Castellini secured the points for Fabio Capello's side.

Milan beat newly promoted Vicenza 2-0, with the in-form Oliver Bierhoff heading home a cross by Gennaro Gattuso and Andrei Shevchenko doing likewise from Federico Giunti.

Parma and Fiorentina drew 2-2, which may make life easier for Fiorentina's Turkish coach Fatih Terim, under pressure since going out of the Uefa Cup to Tirol Innsbruck.

On Saturday, Alessandro del Piero responded to being dropped for Juventus's last Champions League outing by hitting a fine winner 15 minutes from time in the 2-1 win at Napoli.

fields.headline: Will the real Chelsea stand up
fields.trailText:
Chelsea 3 - 0 Liverpool
Chelsea find more success against the mighty.
fields.body:
Chelsea should begin campaigning now for a self-perpetuating European League. Then they would never have to play the likes of Bradford and St Gallen, whom they find so difficult to beat. Yesterday they showed once more their preference for playing mightier opposition as they comfortably dismissed Liverpool.

Claudio Ranieri has been coach for only three games and he is as perplexed as anyone why the team switches between Jekyll and Hyde more easily than Spencer Tracy. Asked which was the real Chelsea, the one that rolled over against the Swiss or the one that came back thrillingly to draw 3-3 at Manchester United and won yesterday, the Italian coach replied: "I wish I knew."

The team's spirit and concentration made the difference from Thursday, he said, though when asked why those qualities had made a reappearance he again shrugged his shoulders.

Solving the riddle will almost certainly prove the key to Ranieiri's success in the post. He now has two weeks without a game to try to get his head round a few answers.

In the meantime three points in his first home game in charge - Chelsea's first league win since the opening day of the season - will have taken some of the pressure off. Not that Ranieri should get too worked up about this victory. Apart from the goals Chelsea hardly worried Sander Westerveld in the Liverpool goal.

To pop the champagne because of a win against a side who were arguably worse than St Gallen would be overdoing it a bit. Liverpool, who have never won at Stamford Bridge in the Premiership, gifted Chelsea two goals, struggled to conjure up any creativity going forward and played with a half-heartedness that does not bode well for their championship pretensions.

The most animated member of their staff was the coach Phil Thompson, whose remonstrations with players and officials alike included a stand-up row between the dug-outs with Ranieri and the Chelsea coach Ray Wilkins.

The former England defender does his side no favours with his rantings and it could be argued that he even incites the fans. The Liverpool travelling support was right behind the visiting dug-out and took its lead from him.

Liverpool and Chelsea have a lot in common: expensively assembled sides managed by foreign coaches employed to win the title but struggling to live up to expectations. Unlike Chelsea, Liverpool are through to the second round of the Uefa Cup, so it might have been expected that Chelsea would come into this game lacking some confidence.

But that was remedied on nine minutes when Westerveld gifted them a goal, punching Gianfranco Zola's corner into his own net.

Still in a state of shock, Liverpool conceded a second within a minute. A move down the right ended with Zola's clever ball between two defenders which found Eidur Gudjohnsen, making his first start, on the edge of the area.

The Icelander passed to another summer signing, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, who swept the ball over Westerveld with a striker's instinct.

In his search for an answer to Chelsea's problems, Ranieri rang the changes yesterday. The young midfielder Sam Dalla Bona was also given his first start and responded with a heartening performance, demonstrating accurate passing and neat feet.

However, after the opening burst the game went a bit scrappy, with Liverpool going closest before the break through the otherwise disappointing Michael Owen and Dietmar Hamann.

In the second half Liverpool continued to press forward and Nick Barmby shot wide from close range. But then Liverpool gave Chelsea another goal. The young England hopeful Steven Gerrard played the ball back to Stéphane Henchoz but left it short. Gudjohnsen nipped in, rounded the keeper and slotted home his first goal for the club.

Robbie Fowler, on as a substitute, almost pulled a goal back with a close-range shot fired just wide, but the game was beyond Liverpool by then.

"We are not at the level of some of the teams at the top," admitted Gérard Houllier. Ranieri is not the only one with riddles to solve.

 The Liverpool striker Patrik Berger is set to solve the club's work-permit problem by applying for a British passport. The Czech midfielder hopes to qualify for dual nationality next summer after playing for five seasons in England.

fields.headline: Viduka's bite better than Tara's bark
fields.trailText:
Leeds 4 - 3 Tottenham
Leeds take the honours after doubles from Sergei Rebrov and Mark Viduka.
fields.body:
Crazy game, crazy guys. "Who would have thought a match between David O'Leary and George Graham would have produced seven goals?" the Tottenham Hotspur manager noted.

Who indeed, except perhaps Mark Viduka, the singular Australian who takes advice from his dog and seems to have only a passing acquaintance with the guidelines to Premiership etiquette - "Do not turn a George Graham defence porous" being one of them?

The Australian striker had been made to train with the under-15s after arriving back late from the Olympics but he responded with a vitally timed double on Saturday to haul Leeds back into a match they were in danger of losing and to justify his selection ahead of Michael Bridges.

Had Spurs but known he was taking advice from his pet Rottweiler Tara they could have made out a case for ruff justice. "I tell her everything that no one else hears," the towering antipodean unwisely confided to the press last week. "She is the only one who knows all my thoughts and ambitions."

Whatever advice she is giving him seems to be working. After an unbelievably turgid first half Leeds were trailing to an opportunist Sergei Rebrov strike when Viduka turned the game around inside a matter of minutes. For such a huge man he has uncannily nimble feet and they got him into po sition to pounce on the rebound after Neil Sullivan had puzzlingly palmed a cross against his own post.

In the 55th minute he was there again when Gary Kelly's fierce drive needed only the subtlest diversion to leave the Scotland goalkeeper wrong-footed. "I saw the shot and I thought in that split second I'll get a little touch to it and maybe it will go in," he said.

Strange things continued to happen after Viduka's second strike. The players kept on doing incompetent things around the halfway line but the ball was meanwhile hitting the net with enough frequency to keep three matches happy. Alan Smith scored with a free header, Chris Perry did the same for Spurs, then another Smith header put Leeds 4-2 up. Smith then hit the bar for good measure before Rebrov scored a second with the help of a linesman who decided that his hooked shot had crossed the line. Phew.

Afterwards Graham confirmed his interest in Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu as he attempts to halt his side's slide down the table. It is two years since he jumped ship at Leeds after a 3-3 draw with Spurs at White Hart Lane, since when he has lost all four games in the league against his old side.

O'Leary and he managed only the merest of handshakes on the final whistle, though they were generous in their praise of each other afterwards. "He's a great learner, David, and he'll go on to be one of the top managers in the game," said Graham.

"Everything I have I owe to George Graham," O'Leary said. "But I'm delighted with three points."

fields.headline: Smith on-line for abuse after Ipswich demolition job
fields.trailText:
Everton 0 - 3 Ipswich
The pressure's on Walter Smith after Ipswich's demolition job.
fields.body:
Back in the days of supporter innocence, when managers in sheepskin coats were revered as saintly figures, the barometer that indicated their popularity was the letters page in the local 'pink un.

It still happens, of course. The Liverpool Echo's Saturday night sports edition remains essential reading for those absorbed by others' afflictions.

But in these days of electronic communication, the Internet possibly carries the greater threat to a down-on-his-luck manager. On Wednesday night, within minutes of Everton's Keatonesque exit from the Worthington Cup, a wide variety of forums and sites devoted to matters of a royal-blue hue - notably the admirable Toffeeweb - were flooded with the outpourings of the angry and the downright confused. The unthinkable had happened and the calls for the dismissal of Walter Smith were only to be expected.

Like his Manchester City counterpart, the average Everton punter is a remarkable animal. Masochistic, sustained by blind faith and imbued with the belief that something better will turn up, those who regularly fill Goodison Park are to be admired; the real heroes, at a club marooned in a period of transition for most of a decade, wear scarves not shorts.

Irrespective of whether he ultimately succeeds in pushing Everton around the corner, Smith has already won a place in the hearts of most of his club's followers simply because he is perceived as the man who pointed the former chairman Peter Johnson towards Goodison's door and then applied a size-10 boot.

In truth, removing the amiable and largely misunderstood Johnson from office was not that difficult. He had had enough of the abuse and he was capable of recognising a fast-fading dream.

But on Saturday evening, as the jeers rolled down from cheap and expensive seats alike, Smith must have reflected on the old theory that popularity is a transient thing in sport. He must have felt embarrassed, too, for his team had just delivered a performance which was clueless, guileless and above all else careless.

Simply by playing simple, orderly football bereft of pretension, Ipswich Town shredded first Everton's midfield, then their defence and finally their confidence.

"If you give away goals as we did, you deserve to lose," observed Smith. And lose they did - by some distance and with some ease.

With players absent injured and far too many of those present asked to undertake alien roles, Everton were beaten from the moment John McGreal's header from a Jim Magilton free-kick found its way home on 19 minutes.

Thereafter it was simply a question of how many more times Ipswich would pierce a defence which, ludicrously, featured the midfielder Alex Nyarko as its main plank.

In the end George Burley's side settled for just a couple, Marcus Stewart showing true predatory instinct to convert smartly after first Steve Watson and then David Unsworth committed wretched, unforced blunders.

"The bookies keep telling me we'll be relegated but I think we have a decent little side," said Burley. Spot on.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Saints see signs of redemption
fields.trailText:
Southampton 1 - 3 Middlesbrough
Saints signs of redemption amid the gloom.
fields.body:
The pain of defeat was numbed for Southampton's fans and beneath Glenn Hoddle's furrowed brow there was hint of a contented smile. For while there was gloom aplenty here on Saturday there was little doom as any frustration at Middlesbrough's rather fortuitous victory was tempered by the sense that this was something of a new beginning.

"We needed to know where the short-term future of the club is going because it was just ticking along and it's right for myself, the club and the players that we do know what's going on," said Hoddle after committing himself to the club until July 2002.

By then Southampton will have played a season in their new 30,000-all-seater ground, which, it was announced on Saturday, will be named the Friends Provident Stadium after a five-year sponsorship extension was signed with the financial services group.

An encouraging start to the season, Saturday notwithstanding, suggests that Hoddle's aim - "To take the club into the next bracket in the Premiership" - is realistic.

"I've seen signs that we're getting there," Hoddle said, "and I've seen signs that we're a long way off it still. It won't happen overnight. There's a lot of potential here but we'll have to wait and see if that potential can be hit. Eighteen months is a good time span for us to find these things out."

Certainly the Saints could do with an Alen Boksic. He was a class apart on Saturday, drifting past three Southampton defenders before guiding a precise shot into the corner of the net for his first goal and punishing Jones's weak punch with a sharp header for his second and Middlesbrough's third. In between times Southampton were in charge, Tahar el Khalej and Trond Soltvedt both hitting a post.

However, Gianluca Festa had given the visitors a two-goal cushion by half-time and despite dominating possession Southampton had only Marian Pahars's header to show for their efforts.

Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson still has little to show for spending more than £60m but the £2.5m of that invested in Boksic could prove money well spent.

fields.headline: Redknapp alone hits purple patch
fields.trailText:
West Ham 1 - 1 Bradford
Joe Cole is on song, but Harry Redknapp is left fuming over West Ham's errors.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio takes no prisoners, even when they are fighting on the same side. In his forthcoming lid-blowing autobiography the maestro now dubbed: "Di Slamio" blasts Rio Ferdinand, one of West Ham's very own, Nigel Winterburn, now a team-mate, and even Big Ron, now retired. Has this man no respect?

If the publishers and Paolo had been a bit more patient, not one of his most obvious qualities, he could have penned even more revealing stuff about managers. "His eyes seem to bulge out of their sockets ... by now his face had gone from red to purple. He was shaking, hyperventilating."

No, this is not Big Ron in his Sheffield Wednesday guise but Unhappy Harry of the Hammers on Saturday evening. Redknapp was fully expecting to praise West Ham but instead absolutely buried them first in the dressing room and then in the press room. Harry, too, was taking no prisoners with the neutrals, biting the head off one who asked the manager the standard question of what he had said to his players at half-time.

With all expletives deleted Redknapp basically ranted about three points "thrown away" by conceding "a crappy goal" from a "silly free-kick" conceded by Igor Stimac compounded by "a wrong decision" by Trevor Sinclair in failing to mark Dan Petrescu.

Thus Benito Carbone's curving free-kick was headed in by Petrescu seconds from the end of normal time to leave a disbelieving Upton Park still awaiting a first home win. Redknapp was speaking for all of the claret-and-blue persuasion when he declared: "It'll be a bad weekend for me."

Redknapp's almost weekly brave words predicting a top-half finish - repeated here despite his diatribe - are beginning to drift away on the wind. And expectations will drop as inevitably as the autumn leaves if West Ham do not soon get a grip on early season. Even Joe Cole, the youngest of the crew, senses it.

"There's an inconsistency in our game that we've got to do something about," said the 18-year-old prospective England midfielder. "The players are not worried about it at this stage of the season. But I don't want to stand here and have egg on my face at the end of it."

Cole is less troubled about England than his club. "I want to start against Germany; it wouldn't faze me at all. I've played against German internationals like Christian Zeige and Dietmar Hamann. But I don't know at this stage whether I'm in the [final] squad or the team."

The midfielder strengthened his international cause by cleverly heading in Frédéric Kanouté's fine cross for a second goal in successive league matches but then weakened it by fading, like West Ham, after the interval. It is a trait only partially explained by man marking, first by Jamie Lawrence and then by the substitute Gunnar Halle, or by some crude earlier challenges from Bradford players.

Bradford's manager Chris Hutchings took justified pride in his side's persistence in gaining a first goal and first point away, and by eventually subduing two "world-class players", but Cole is clearly not ready for a competitive international and Di Canio, on his utterly unproductive second- half performance, will not, at 32, be receiving any belated call-up from the Azzurri.

Di Canio effectively signed off here by being booked after 83 minutes for kicking the ball away at a free-kick. The Italian would have been better advised following the example of the 19-year-old Michael Carrick, who had by now taken over the baton from Cole as West Ham midfielder to watch. This teenager provided composure, thoughtful distribution and one cunning shot that was somehow turned on to a post by Matt Clarke.

No one was more robustly defiant for Bradford than Dean Windass - booked for a hack on Cole - and afterwards the çity player added to Redknapp's weekend woes. "In the second half we had them on the back foot and they didn't know what to do," he said. "West Ham had a go at each other, just like they did when we were 4-2 up here last season. They've got weaknesses in defence."

No, this is not Big Ron in his Sheffield Wednesday guise but Unhappy Harry of the Hammers on Saturday evening. Redknapp was fully expecting to praise West Ham but instead absolutely buried them first in the dressing room and then in the press room. Harry, too, was taking no prisoners with the neutrals, biting the head off one who asked the manager the standard question of what he had said to his players at half-time. With all expletives deleted Redknapp basically ranted about three points "thrown away" by conceding "a crappy goal" from a "silly free-kick" conceded by Igor Stimac compounded by "a wrong decision" by Trevor Sinclair in failing to mark Dan Petrescu. Thus Benito Carbone's curving free-kick was headed in by Petrescu seconds from the end of normal time to leave a disbelieving Upton Park still awaiting a first home win. Redknapp was speaking for all of the claret-and-blue persuasion when he declared: "It'll be a bad weekend for me." Redknapp's almost weekly brave words predicting a top-half finish - repeated here despite his diatribe - are beginning to drift away on the wind. And expectations will drop as inevitably as the autumn leaves if West Ham do not soon get a grip on early season. Even Joe Cole, the youngest of the crew, senses it. "There's an inconsistency in our game that we've got to do something about," said the 18-year-old prospective England midfielder. "The players are not worried about it at this stage of the season. But I don't want to stand here and have egg on my face at the end of it." Cole is less troubled about England than his club. "I want to start against Germany; it wouldn't faze me at all. I've played against German internationals like Christian Zeige and Dietmar Hamann. But I don't know at this stage whether I'm in the [final] squad or the team." The midfielder strengthened his international cause by cleverly heading in Frédéric Kanouté's fine cross for a second goal in successive league matches but then weakened it by fading, like West Ham, after the interval. It is a trait only partially explained by man marking, first by Jamie Lawrence and then by the substitute Gunnar Halle, or by some crude earlier challenges from Bradford players. Bradford's manager Chris Hutchings took justified pride in his side's persistence in gaining a first goal and first point away, and by eventually subduing two "world-class players", but Cole is clearly not ready for a competitive international and Di Canio, on his utterly unproductive second- half performance, will not, at 32, be receiving any belated call-up from the Azzurri. Di Canio effectively signed off here by being booked after 83 minutes for kicking the ball away at a free-kick. The Italian would have been better advised following the example of the 19-year-old Michael Carrick, who had by now taken over the baton from Cole as West Ham midfielder to watch. This teenager provided composure, thoughtful distribution and one cunning shot that was somehow turned on to a post by Matt Clarke. No one was more robustly defiant for Bradford than Dean Windass - booked for a hack on Cole - and afterwards the çity player added to Redknapp's weekend woes. "In the second half we had them on the back foot and they didn't know what to do," he said. "West Ham had a go at each other, just like they did when we were 4-2 up here last season. They've got weaknesses in defence."  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Finn goal papers over the cracks
fields.trailText:
Charlton 2 - 2 Coventry
Jonatan Johansson papers over the cracks for Charlton.
fields.body:
If Charlton are an authentic Premiership team, this was not the authentic Charlton. On the evidence of this, their fifth league game without defeat, something horrible has happened to the confident, quick-thinking unit that won the First Division last season. It seems to have been taken over by a clueless bunch of strangers relying on flashes of inspiration from a foreign star to get them out of trouble, just like half of the other teams in the top flight.

Charlton began at a depressed tempo and never discovered much dynamism. They can pass as sweetly and move as effectively as virtually any side in the league but on Saturday they shuffled the ball sideways or punted it long, without confidence, rhythm or accuracy. They should have lost and would have done but for Jonatan Johansson, a mobile, two-footed Finnish international striker who warmed up for the England game on Wednesday week by laying on one goal and scoring the other.

Coventry made it difficult - "We've won away three times but that's the best we've played," said their manager Gordon Strachan - and, when the home side did eventually find some coherence late in the first half, they were immediately hit on the counter, with a goal from John Aloisi.

Charlton equalised with a counter-attack of their own, fell behind to a penalty after Richard Rufus, who has evidently been watching the Olympic volleyball, spiked the ball over Carlton Palmer, then rescued a point when Johansson scored his seventh goal in eight games with what some insisted on calling a bicycle kick. Imagine the bicycle tilted parallel to the ground and four feet off it.

Charlton's first equaliser was even better and was a reminder of their neglected virtues. Dean Kiely started the move, throwing the ball out to Claus Jensen in space around the half-way line. The Dane pushed the ball forward into another gap in Coventry's cover, Magnus Hedman obligingly marooned himself in no-man's-land and, when Johansson shot against the bar, Andy Hunt headed in.

The ball had been moved the length of the field along the ground in two passes. This was Charlton as they used to be, as they must be, trusting in their speed of movement and swiftness of execution.

fields.headline: Familiar fears as City stock falls
fields.trailText:
Man City 0 - 1 Newcastle
City stutter as Shearer gets his first of the season.
fields.body:
Having been invited to the top table, Manchester City's players are beginning to lurch around as though they have indulged in a glass too many of the Beaujolais.

Things are already getting claustrophobic towards the bottom of the Premiership and, though this defeat hardly leaves Joe Royle's team struggling for oxygen, their vapid display does not augur well for their chances of preservation.

It would be easier to argue a case for the demotion of Derby or Bradford - even Middlesbrough - but the air of vulnerability lingering over Moss Side on Saturday evening should generate misgivings among supporters who, after all, know a thing or two about events conspiring against them.

As they traipsed away through the red-brick terrace streets surrounding Maine Road, crunching through the broken glass and tiptoeing around the ragamuffin gangs lurking on every corner, there was certainly plenty to occupy their minds.

"It was our second most inept performance of the season," said Royle. "We didn't mean to be so direct but when things aren't going well one or two of the players start treating the ball like a hot potato. It's a confidence thing."

It has not reached the point where City need to reinvent themselves, but the fact that Alan Shearer's winning goal ought to have been disallowed for offside should not disguise that Newcastle, only a fair-to-middling side themselves, were the better team by a considerable distance. Only the durability of City's stand-in goalkeeper Tommy Wright - 37 going on 21 - prevented further punishment.

The one cloud on an otherwise bright day for Newcastle was the injury to Kieron Dyer, who twisted a knee and may be doubtful for the England game against Germany next weekend.

Shearer may be more of a Shetland pony than a thoroughbred these days but that does not mean the former England captain is being primed for the knacker's yard just yet. Had he not retired from international football over the summer, a betting man would not have found himself in the poorhouse for assuming Kevin Keegan would start with him for England against Germany on Saturday.

So it was somewhat ironic that his first goal from open play this season, a stooping far-post header after Lomano Lua-Lua and Nolberto Solano had concocted a route beyond the left of City's defence, was so similar to his winner against Germany in the Stade du Pays in June.

Shearer later insisted the regurgitated rumours of his demise had not affected him - "there will always be people who jump on my back" - although his version of events differed with that of Bobby Robson.

"Alan was concerned he was not scoring goals so he came to see me this week to ask what he was doing wrong, what in his game he was no longer doing right," disclosed the Newcastle manager.

They concluded that he was too static, he was not getting behind defenders and was becoming too easy to mark. "We've done some extra work in training on his movement," added Robson.

"He will always motivate himself without help from anyone. He still wants to be the best centre-forward in England and he wants to finish the season with the most goals. Mark my words, he will be extremely disappointed if he doesn't score as many as Kevin Phillips or Emile Heskey."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Doin' me bit to prove we're still on top

fields.headline: Doin' me bit to prove we're still on top
fields.trailText: Darren Tackle There is not enough hours in the day what can afford to be wasted watching one long parade of posh sports, what with the three vital elements of the professional athlete's training regime: rest, rest and more rest.
fields.body:
Personally I has not seen much of them Olympics. What with all the meticulous preparation required by your modern professional, for Darren Tackle there is not enough hours in the day what can afford to be wasted watching one long parade of posh sports.

But old Demo, our coach, has gone Olympic batty, bringing in rowing machines to the gym, running videos of some geezer in a dinghy to show us how to do a man-marking job on free-flowing Brazilians, telling Wattsy to go all patriotic and get hisself an Audley Harrison barnet job. Plus the old nonce has been playing bleedin' M People's What Have You Done Today To Make You Feel Proud non-stop in the changing room. I've told him, only geezers what hang their jackets up on the little hook in the back of their family saloons listen to M bleedin' People. What he wants to do to get us up before a match is spin some hot wax, summat by D'Angelo, say. Or I've told him he could borrow me latest well heavy CD, The Life & Times of Sean Carter Vol 3 by Jay Z. But no, because of the Olympics me ears is being battered by M People.

"Listen to the words, Dazz," he says to me when I's complained to him that the noise is putting me in danger of a Ronaldo-style migraine. "You might just be inspired."

All right, Demo, since you insist. I'll tell you what I have done today to make me feel proud. First off there's that personal best in the afternoon nap (me head hit the sofa cushion at 2pm last Thursday and I wakes up at 2.35pm. On Friday). Another three days and I'll be right up there pushing Stan Collymore's British all-comers' record in that particular field. Plus there's Saturday night's lifetime achievement down at Dell's: nine vodka and Red Bulls, three shots of Dave the Barman's new cocktail called the Thorpedo (it makes your head swim) concluding with a grope over the bonnet of the Jeep with a fellow cocktail enthusiast what tells me she has a big future in the adult entertainment industry behind her. And while I has yet to touch the world record of the master Wattsy for drink-driving convictions, the return journey from the aforesaid evening proves I is actively working towards it. Hey, it's not just down under that your British sportsmen is proving that only world class is good enough.

As I has said many times, Darren Tackle is second to no man in his complete adherence to the three vital elements of the professional athlete's training regime: rest, rest and more rest. But even he has, sometimes, to ignore the benefits of a rigorous afternoon's work-out of his snoring muscles in front of his favourite video (Jerry Springer out-takes including the now-legendary I'm In A Threesome With My Sister And Her Dog featuring a geezer what looks uncannily like Francis Jeffers). And instead he is forced to address more pressing concerns. Like what exactly is happening with DarrenTackledotcom? Considerable investment has been made in the website about the footballer everyone wants to hit. No, let me rephrase that: the website everyone wants to hit about the footballer. Rodders tells us there's millions in it.

"Just register the name, boy, put a few intimate details of your private life on there, slag off your current management for lacking ambition, then sit back and watch the sponds roll," he says.

Yet despite an outlay now approaching four figures (£28.50) as yet it is a distinctly long 'un-free zone. Which, as far as I understand it, is not the point of the internet at all. So I has decided that in an attempt to liven up said site and get some more much-needed folding stuff heading in a Tackle bank account-wardly direction, drastic action has to be applied. There is, for instance, the short video involving a Kylie Minogue lookalike and a well lively donkey what Wattsy was showing everyone on his new WAP mobe at training last week. But when I bells Rodders to see as how he might get his people to download the whole interface on to DarrenTackledotcom, just to brighten things up a bit, he comes over all stressed.

"No, no, no, boy," he says. "It's your image we're selling here, boy. Think role model, think striving for achievement, think setting goals."

"What's Stan Collymore got to do with it?" I says.

"I got it, boy, I got it," he screams, ignoring me. "Patriotism, pride, it's got to be the Olympics. I see it now, you in slo-mo, sliding in on Alan Shearer, set to that M People track. You know the one, how's it go? Who have you done today to make you feel proud?"

Who have you done today? Now for once, Rodders, you might be on to something.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: First Division  round-up
fields.trailText: As sleeping giants go, Preston North End seemed to be slipping into a coma, but the good times are fast returning at Deepdale.
fields.body:
As sleeping giants go, Preston North End seemed to be slipping into a coma, but the good times are fast returning at Deepdale.

Preston moved up to fourth place in the table after a comfortable 2-0 win at home to Crystal Palace. A first-half goal from Jon Macken was followed by a hypnotic 30-yard volley from Paul McKenna.

But it could have been many more against a poor Palace side, whose manager Alan Smith was far from happy with his side's efforts.

"Even if Tom Finney had played at his age he would have had a good game against us," he said.

"There were too many people - the whole 11 in fact - who for whatever reason were doing their own thing. At least I am paid to watch it, unlike the fans who came here. I am sure they will go home absolutely disgusted."

Sheffield United conceded their first home league goal of the season when Queens Park Rangers' striker Sammy Koejoe scored a 52nd-minute equaliser at Bramall Lane.

Shaun Murphy had headed the Blades into a 36th-minute lead but United wasted a chance to secure a fourth straight home win when Rangers' keeper Lee Harper saved a penalty from Paul Devlin for a second time after the original save was ruled out for encroachment.

Burnley's substitute Paul Weller grabbed a late equaliser to earn a point at home to Portsmouth. The Pompey manager Tony Pullis had thought his side were on the way to a much-needed win when Steve Claridge fired them in front after 74 minutes.

"We controlled the game and should have won it; in fact we had enough chances to have won two," he said.

Barnsley moved into the top half of the table and continued their 100% home record with a straight-forward 2-0 win over lowly Grimsby Town .

Steve Chettle opened the scoring after 32 minutes and Neil Shipperley made sure soon after the interval.

Grimsby boss Lennie Lawrence moaned about his side's impotent attack. "I might be able to get one half-decent striker into the club but even he would have to come on loan first. That will be it and I will have to look at the foreign market," he said.

Nottingham Forest failed to close in on the leading teams with a goalless draw at home to Wolverhampton Wanderers.

A Neil Ardley penalty and a Damien Francis volley secured three points for Wimbledon at home to Stockport County .

Rob Hulse netted a goal in each half to help Crewe to their first away win of the season at Tranmere. Colin Little scored in between before Andy Parkinson gained late consolation. "It is normally all one-way here and it was nice to see us running the ball into their box," said Crewe's manager Dario Gradi.

Gaetano Giallanza scored the equaliser as Norwich City drew 1-1 at home to Huddersfield. Kevin Gallen had scored for the visitors after 58 minutes.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Second Division  round-up
fields.trailText: The league leaders Walsall continued their remarkable start to the season when they emphatically beat Notts County 5-1. The result means that Ray Graydon's side remain unbeaten at home and are three points clear at the top of the Second Division.
fields.body:
The league leaders Walsall continued their remarkable start to the season when they emphatically beat Notts County 5-1. The result means that Ray Graydon's side remain unbeaten at home and are three points clear at the top of the Second Division.

County had won three of their last four away games but found Walsall an altogether more difficult proposition. Pedro Matias, Brett Angell, Tom Bennett, Jorge Leitao and Darren Byfield scored for the home side and Mark Stallard netted his eighth of the season for County.

Bury jumped into second place with a 2-0 win at Swansea through goals from Adrian Littlejohn and Jason Jarrett, while Reading made it five wins from six games and propelled themselves into third place with a 3-1 success at Rotherham; Martin Butler, Jamie Cureton, with his ninth of the season, and Jim McIntyre scored for Reading and Rotherham's only goal was a 28th-minute penalty converted by Mark Robins.

A change of managers can galvanise a side, and Millwall provided an example. Mark McGhee, in his first game in charge since the surprising dismissals of Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary, saw his side put four past an out-of-sorts Peterborough through Joe Dolan, Lucas Neil, Tim Cahill and Sam Parkin - the latter scoring his third in four games since joining on loan from Chelsea.

Another side enjoying a good start to the season are Lawrie Sanchez's Wycombe Wanderers. They stayed in contention at the top of the table after an Andy Rammell goal gave them a 1-0 win at Port Vale, who are now without a victory in their last six matches.

Whereas that run of poor form continued, another one was ending as Scott Murray scored for Bristol City at Oxford United's Manor Ground to break their sequence of eight games without a win. The hapless home side have now lost eight of their opening 10 matches and are precariously placed at the bottom of the division.

fields.headline: Third Division  round-up
fields.trailText: Chesterfield moved five points clear at the top of the table with a 4-1 mauling of Macclesfield at Saltergate, but only after an early surprise.
fields.body:
Chesterfield moved five points clear at the top of the table with a 4-1 mauling of Macclesfield at Saltergate, but only after an early surprise.

Ritchie Barker put the Silkmen in front after 23 minutes, but the home side drew level thanks to an own-goal from Darren Tinson. Then a Sean Parrish hat-trick - the third a penalty - made the points safe.

Southend had sacked their manager Alan Little in midweek but they gained their third win on the trot when they shocked second-placed Rochdale at Spotland, courtesy of a 31st-minute goal by Martin Carruthers. The shot was so vicious that it tore the net and caused a five-minute delay for repairs.

Cheltenham are level on points with Rochdale after two goals from Martin Devaney - six for the season - gave them a 2-0 win at Exeter.

Brighton secured a fourth win in succession, 2-0 over Leyton Orient, which keeps them among the front runners, Paul Rogers and Kerry Mayo the scorers, while Cardiff lost ground with a 2-0 defeat at Hull, where they scored both goals for the Tigers. Daniel Gabbidon, a £500,000 signing from West Brom, was the first to put through his own net followed by David Greene, who was also sent off for violent conduct.

Barnet and Scunthorpe ended five-match runs without a win, the Irons whacking Torquay - still without a point away from home - 3-0 with Guy Ipoua (two) and Andy Davidson the scorers.

Barnet won 3-2 at Plymouth with two goals from Tony Richards and the other from Mark Arber scoring, with Sean McCarthy and Steve Guinan netting for the Pilgrims.

Carlisle lost for the fifth time in succession, going down 1-0 at Darlington through Paul Beavers' first goal for the Quakers.

fields.headline: Wednesday hit rock bottom
fields.trailText:
Gillingham 2 - 0 Sheff Wed
Wednesday hit rock bottom.
fields.body:
In January it was a major FA cup shock, but now a Gillingham victory over Sheffield Wednesday has sent Paul Jewell's team to the bottom of division one.

Wednesday, who lost 3-1 here in the fourth round of the cup last season, were killed off this time by goals in each half from Guy Butters and Andy Thomson.

Jewell's concern with his team - who have just one win in nine and the worst goal difference in the division - was evident after the match.

"We don't look as if we have got a goal in us," he said. "I know we scored five in the week against Oldham but that flattered us a bit really."

"It's a big ask but I will do all I can to try and turn things around. We have got to improve because we are bottom of the league and that's not good enough. There is a lot wrong but the first thing we need is more quality in the side.

"Confidence is low at the moment and I can understand that. Players are only human beings and might try and shy away from the ball, but you cannot excuse people who are not prepared to run for 90 minutes. That's the least the supporters deserve."

Jewell can add the disappointing form of Gilles de Bilde to his long list of worries. He revealed that the Belgian international did not even make the trip to Gillingham.

"There is nothing sinister in it," explained Jewell. "I just did not think his performances of late had warranted a place in the squad and that is why I left him out and he did not come with us."

Gillingham dominated the first half and took a deserved lead in its dying seconds when Butters volleyed in a free-kick from Andy Hessenthaler at the far post.

Though Wednesday looked more positive after the break, they went two down with seven minutes remaining after Hessenthaler's good work down the left. His cross was touched on by the substitute Paul Shaw into the path of Thomson, who turned and shot past Wednesday's 17-year-old goalkeeper, Chris Stringer.

To heap insult onto the visitors' injuries, Hessenthaler, Gillingham's player-manager, implied that Wednesday had not even felt the full force of his side.

He said: "I'm pleased with the win and a clean sheet. We weren't at the races at times but we kept going. I think we were still a bit tired after the midweek game against Manchester City which went to extra time."

fields.headline: Taylor's quiet revolution gains spin
fields.trailText:
Watford 2 - 0 Birmingham
Graham Taylor's quiet revolution gains speed.
fields.body:
September has only just slipped by but the bookies have effectively closed the betting on the First Division title race. Fulham, nine wins on the bounce, have it sewn up and the others are competing for the minor placings.

That theory, which became more compelling after Jean Tigana's remarkably consistent team eased their way to victory at Bolton, is a trifle harsh on Watford, who have themselves started as though the season is a sprint and not a marathon.

This was their eighth win in nine games, they have yet to lose and, in addition to rewriting their own record books, they are assembling a strong case for an instant return to the Premiership. True, Graham Taylor's side lacked something in the way of style yesterday but the defeat of a close rival gains a currency over and above the value of another three points.

Two second-half goals which thankfully drew a veil over what had gone before enabled Watford to bring Fulham back into view. The gap is now two points with Watford's advantage over Bolton extended to five. "For those of us below Fulham and Watford it's obviously a concern that they have both made such an unbelievable start," said Trevor Francis, the Birmingham manager. "That was in our minds today. While they lead by a considerable amount of points, there are 37 games to go and I don't think it's impossible to haul them back; I'm talking about Watford here, not Fulham."

So, by inference, Francis believes Fulham are uncatchable. Certainly those who have seen all three sides will confirm that, on ability, Tigana's troupe are out on their own.

That much was obvious throughout this game. For, until Allan Nielsen scored just before the hour, passes had gone astray with monotonous regularity, half-chances had not been taken and defences in the main were on top.

That goal punished a lack of concentration in the Birmingham defence because the corner should not have been conceded by Martin Grainger. Neil Cox floated the ball over and, when Heidar Helguson drove it back, Nielsen redirected it over the line.

Birmingham responded with vigour. Jerry Gill sent Stan Lazaridis clear but, as he was about to shoot, with Cox challenging, he went down. Much to Francis's consternation no penalty was given.

"It was the decisive moment," said Francis, whose hopes of an 11th game unbeaten, which would have been the best under his management, were dashed. "Our players were demoralised that nothing was given while Watford seemed to take a lift from it."

That lift helped Cox get airborne in the 76th minute after trickery from Nordin Wooter down the right and on this day at least Watford were beyond recall.

"Our start has created an expectancy where we only have to turn up, play well and score goals and the opposition will let you do it, but of course it's never as easy as that," said Taylor. "It was a disjointed game but once we got ahead it did not look as if we would lose it."

He must have been impressed with the way his central defenders kept Geoff Horsfield and Mark Burchill on a tight rein. When Lazaridis escaped Cox's attention before half-time a combination of Darren Ward's leg and Robert Page's body somehow ushered his dangerous cross to safety.

It was an effort which said a great deal about Watford's determination.

fields.headline: Leicester lead from the back
fields.trailText:
Sunderland 0 - 0 Leicester
Leicester lead from the back and secure top spot.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Amidst the chorus of boos that rang out on the final whistle, it was just about possible to hear the away supporters basking in unlikely glory. Unlikely as it seemed after this dire goalless draw, this was a Premiership contest and Leicester will spend the next fortnight as the best team in the league.

"I am surprised but delighted," said the City manager Peter Taylor, who only arrived at Filbert Street in June. "As a new manager you pray for a good start, particularly when you follow someone like Martin O'Neill. I cannot thank the players enough, but they deserve it."

This match proved that much, illustrating perfectly how such heights have been scaled for the first time since 1963. City's rearguard were robust, relentless and fearsome in the tackle; their midfield snapped at opponents' heels with boundless energy, justifying a defensive record of just two concessions in eight league matches this season.

Sunderland lacked the imagination to prise open their visitors. Surrounded by the twin peaks of Gerry Taggart and Matthew Elliott, their own gentle giant Niall Quinn was cut off from his usual supply line. With no service forthcoming, the home side simply bounced off the defensive blockade leaving the England striker Kevin Phillips so withdrawn from the action as to be near anonymous.

"They defended terrifically well," conceded the Sunderland manager Peter Reid.

"You can't play the ball through them so we had to go wide, but we didn't have that bit of magic needed to break them down. There were not enough quality crosses, and those that we did get in seemed to stick to Mr Elliott's head."

While Leicester's defensive record is that of championship challengers, their own lack of attacking invention will surely drag them down to mid-table before too long. After Ade Akinbiyi had missed an early chance, bursting on to a poor Kilbane back pass before shooting wide, they had to wait until Richard Cresswell's diving header on the hour to trouble Thomas Sorensen in the home goal.

"It's not that we're over defensive," said Taylor. "Everything I'm doing is exactly the same as last season at Gillingham when we scored over 100 goals in all competitions. It's just that it's harder to score in the Premiership.

"My lads call themselves the grinders and I'm not worried. The Leicester people tell me that Sunderland battered them up here last year, so to come and claim a point is superb."

Regardless, the Premiership leaders may find it harder to graft a result from their next two fixtures - against Manchester United at Filbert Street and Liverpool at Anfield. "It's an easy old game isn't it," said Taylor, adding, "but we'll enjoy it while it lasts."

fields.headline: Determination downs Rovers
fields.trailText:
WBA 1 - 0 Blackburn
Blackburn lack the muscle to withstand Albion's aggression.
fields.body:
Graeme Souness has never appeared interested in winning popularity contests, which is why the failure of money to buy love probably does not bother him.

What does concern him is the inability of the late Jack Walker's millions to purchase a key ingredient he believes is essential if Blackburn Rovers are to regain Premiership status: muscle.

Though an expertly executed volley by Lee Hughes determined the scoreline, the Rovers manager was adamant it was the more aggressive approach of Albion which was decisive.

"Not for the first time this season we were outmuscled, and that is something we must address," he said after his side's continued failure to win on their travels.

"They were more determined than we were and my players must learn that they have to battle whether it's in the First Division, the Premiership or international."

If Souness is looking for an example to show his players, he could do worse than fast-forward the match video to the 63rd minute to replay his spot of touchline argy-bargy when Albion's reserve-team coach Gary Shelton taunted Jason McAteer after the Irish international's substitution.

"I will not accept someone from another bench having a go at one of my players. It's as simple as that," Souness said.

"Who was the guy anyway? All I know is that he has the same initials as mine on his tracksuit."

Unfortunately for Souness, his side's lack of muscle coupled with such a paucity of invention that his expensively assembled strike force of Matt Jansen and Noel Blake were not presented with a chance between them, meant that Shelton and Co had the last word.

Not that West Bromwich Albion, expertly marshalled at the back by Tony Butler, created much more. Jason Roberts made life easy for John Filan by opting for power rather than precision with a header, and Hughes took the second of his two chances when he volleyed home Richard Sneekes's diagonal cross in the 57th minute.

Many managers would be happy with a conversion rate of one in three. Not so West Bromwich Albion's Gary Megson, despite his side extending their unbeaten run to seven games.

"We've scored eight goals in 10 games and that means we've got one of the worst scoring records in the First Division," he said.

"We've got to sharpen up if we are to remain among the challengers for promotion. We've picked up a lot of results by the odd goal and it's a dangerous game."

Maybe, but against seven-stone Blackburn Rovers it wasn't.

fields.headline: Celtic shorn of perfect record
fields.trailText:
Aberdeen 1 - 1 Celtic
Henrik Larsson saves a point as Celtic lose their perfect record.
fields.body:
Henrik Larsson's dreadlocks have abruptly gone - shorn off by a Glaswegian barber presumably wielding a machete - but his head retains all its old instincts for goal.

This Scottish Premier match had been nicely trimmed and shaped in Aberdeen's favour by their boisterous opening half yesterday before Larsson popped up with a crisp header in the 82nd minute to grab Celtic's point and preserve their unbeaten status in the league.

Pittodrie has witnessed a few rabid encounters between Aberdeen and the Old Firm and this was always threatening to become another of them. In the second half especially there were some scything tackles, a business that made the referee Mike McCurry issue five yellow cards and finally send Bobby Petta off.

Aberdeen have everything to live for. Under Ebbe Skovdahl they are scaling the giddy heights of mid-table mediocrity and yesterday they skipped around Celtic's players with a spriteliness not witnessed in a long time at Pittodrie.

Not only that but Skovdahl has resisted the old managerial instinct of cramming his side with old lags to bail him out. Six of this Aberdeen team were eligible for the under-21s.

There might also be a faint evangelical fervour around Scotland's oil capital over the rebirth of Robbie Winters, a young striker who has always had off-field problems stalking him but who this season has come to resemble the prospect everyone savoured three years ago.

Early in the first half, haring towards Jonathan Gould with all his old zip, he was blatantly tripped inside the box by Tom Boyd. McCurry chose to ignore that incident but the striker was to claim his justice before the interval.

Aberdeen, on the basis of their simmering opening half, thoroughly merited the lead Winters snatched for them seconds before half-time. Sent on his way by an exchange of passes between Eoin Jess and Derek Young, the striker once more sprinted through on Gould before applying a golfer's feathery wedge shot to send the ball over the advancing goalkeeper.

Celtic in this match were not the side that had swaggered through 12 matches unbeaten under Martin O'Neill. Largely outplayed in the first half, they had to resort to some robust scuffling later to break Aberdeen and encroach upon their goal.

Fluency, Celtic's traditional currency, was in drastically short supply. Larsson's goal, though, was a typical leap of opportunism by the Swede.

fields.headline: Boa Morte repays Tigana's faith
fields.trailText:
Bolton 0 - 2 Fulham
Luis Boa Morte repays manager Jean Tigana's faith
fields.byline: Ian Whittell  at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
He is proving as enigmatic as Eric Cantona, the fellow Frenchman who first brought him to the attention of Fulham's owner Mohamed al Fayed, and in his own understated way Jean Tigana may one day have as big an impact on the Premiership as his friend.

His stamp is evident on a Fulham team who strolled to an effortless ninth successive First Division victory against a Bolton side fully capable of finishing the season in second place.

And though Tigana employs the tried and trusted linguistic defence mechanism mastered in his early Manchester United days by Cantona, his message is clearly getting through to his team, in whatever language.

Take Luis Boa Morte, the Portuguese striker brought to England by Arsène Wenger, passed on to Southampton, and loaned to Craven Cottage for the season by Glenn Hoddle.

Only starting because of an injury to the leading scorer Louis Saha, Boa Morte took all of 10 seconds to open the scoring, direct from a Bolton kick-off, thereafter helped keep Wanderers' Finnish keeper Jussi Jaaskelainen fully employed, then wrapped up another Fulham win in the 85th minute.

In a week in which David Beckham has again brought Hoddle's man-management skills into question in a new biography, perhaps events will prove the Southampton manager was hasty in dispensing with Boa Morte's services, especially if the two clubs swap divisions at the end of the season.

"Hoddle arrived in February and it only got worse after that," said Boa Morte. "I realised the best way for me to play was to move. I just didn't feel comfortable there.

"I was playing under David Jones but Hoddle just put me on the bench, then left me out completely. He never spoke to me, he just left me out of the squad."

He added sarcastically: "Maybe Mr Wenger, who first brought me to this country to play for Arsenal, is the one who has it all wrong. Or maybe Southampton just had better players than Arsenal, because I won two Charity Shields in my time at Arsenal.

"Whether this move is permanent is to be seen in the future but I don't think I will ever play under Glenn Hoddle again. He wouldn't want me to and at the moment if they asked me back I would say no because I want to be here until the end of the season."

By which time Tigana will surely have completed his first season in English football by winning the First Division championship.

"There is no easy secret to his success," said the midfielder John Collins, a former player for Tigana at Monaco and now his post-match mouthpiece. "We've worked hard in training from day one, we're a very fit side, and his attention to detail is excellent; nothing is left to chance."

However, though Collins is confident the club can achieve their stated aim of a place in the Premiership, he doesn't believe listening to the plaudits will help their cause. "We are playing well, winning every week and everyone is talking about us," said the former Scotland player. "But we cannot afford to be complacent. If we keep working hard I am sure success will come.

"Nobody is getting carried away here; they know if they do there will be changes. But, having said that, while this may not be Monaco, I don't think I've ever played as good football as this in my time in British football."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: BAe in South African arms row

fields.headline: BAe in South African arms row
fields.trailText: The South African government's special unit set up to investigate state corruption is to decide this week whether to launch a formal inquiry into allegations surrounding a new £3bn defence package, which includes Britain's BAe Systems as one of the prime contractors.
fields.body:
The South African government's special unit set up to investigate state corruption is to decide this week whether to launch a formal inquiry into allegations surrounding a new £3bn defence package, which includes Britain's BAe Systems as one of the prime contractors.

The move follows the publication last week of a report by the auditor general, Shauket Fakie, which identified flaws in the way the contracts were handled.

The deal has been plagued by allegations since it was signed at the end of last year. They centre on reports that some of the sub-contracting work has been awarded to companies associated with senior and former government figures and their families.

In his report to parliament, Mr Fakie said there were "material deviations from generally accepted procurement practices" in choosing BAe's Hawk trainer jets. He said the department of defence had not given a satisfactory answer as to why the Hawks were preferred over three competitors when they were offered at "a significantly higher cost".

Mr Fakie recommended a special investigation into the way the four European prime contractors awarded work to sub-contractors. Potential conflicts of interest, he said, had not been properly addressed.

The claims were repeated last week by the Pan Africanist Congress MP Patricia de Lille, who called for an inquiry into the role of the head of defence acquisitions, Chippy Shaik, and the former defence minister, Joe Modise.

The cost of the defence deal has attracted criticism from South African churches and pressure groups which argue that the country can ill afford such expenditure on defence.

The deal involves the purchase of 52 Hawks and Gripen fighter aircraft from BAe and the Anglo Swedish Saab-BAe consortium, four frigates and four submarines from Germany and 40 Augusta helicopters from Italy.

The companies are expected to provide "offset" investments for several years, amounting to an ambitious £11bn and the creation of 65,000 jobs. But Mr Fakie concluded that the guarantees given by the companies might be inadequate to ensure delivery of the full investment package.

In the report, the Hawk deal came in for particular criticism. Taking into account the cost, BAe came third in the technical evaluation and second in the overall evaluation. But it was awarded the contract after the armaments acquisition council insisted that cost should not be taken into consideration. A BAe spokesman denied any improprieties, saying: "We meticulously abided by the rules. It was one of the most rigorous negotiating processes we have encountered."

The allegations first surfaced in a memo to Ms De Lille last September. It was signed "concerned ANC MPs". She passed the material to the special investigations unit.

One of the critics of the deal, Terry Crawford-Browne, of the Coalition for Defence Alternatives, said: "There is no conceivable foreign military threat to South Africa, and offset agreements are internationally discredited as an invitation wide open to corruption."
