fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Danny Kelly, publishing director of 365corp.com.
fields.trailText: Danny Kelly, publishing director of 365corp.com.
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Football 365.com is my favourite football site, but that's one of our own. The other sites I go to tend to reflect my own interests. One is old pop music, so I recommend expectingrain.com, an unbelievably intense resource about Bob Dylan, that runs around 12 news stories a day about him. I also recommend woolyrockstars.com, where you can buy knitted models of Jimmy Hendrix, Dylan and the Beatles. eBay goes without saying. We love eBay.

Latest online purchase? I purchase a lot of stuff online, all to feed my sad obsessions. I last bought: a poster advertising a Duke Ellington concert, from eBay; an Evening Standard billboard announcing the death of Marc Bolan, and some football programmes. That's all true.

Most recent technological faux pas? I cannot operate my new Sony video, which I've had for a year and a half. That's true as well.

Main news sources on web? For general news I'm afraid I still use television. I risk the derision of small children in the streets by still being a fan of the BBC.

Most persistent spam emailer? I do not regard anything as spam. I think it's communication, I think it's marketing. I like junk mail and I like spam, and this is the truth. I can sort out useful pizza companies and minicab firms from useless Franklin mint material in a nanosecond.

Time spent on web? I spend 10 hours a day on the web, between my work and my recreation.

Next boo.com/clickmango? Anything that was launched to be puffed up, then sold on to some mug.

Least useful site/s on web? The official sites of big organisations like Uefa and the IOC. These tend to be hi-tech arse-covering operations by people who don't want the public to know anything about their activities. That is the opposite of what the internet is good at.

Most useful site? Those which join together people who have a shared passion but are geographically disparate.

What screensaver do you use? It's of a band called MC5, a fantastic group. It's the opening section of their song, Kick Out The Jams. That and the opening speech from Taxi Driver are how I motivate myself in the morning.

Most irritating thing about the web? That there's not enough rubbish on it.

Do you bother with old media? I love the old media. I love television, radio, newspapers, magazines and cinema. I would love video if I could get the fucking thing to work.

fields.headline: Henry genius takes United down a peg
fields.trailText:
Arsenal 1 - 0 Man Utd
Thierry Henry's genius takes United down a peg.
fields.body:
One outstanding piece of craftsmanship by Thierry Henry amid much worthy but often artless effort helped to remove Manchester United from the top of the Premiership yesterday.

Though Arsenal's victory at Highbury has ushered Leicester City into the lead Arsène Wenger will be more than satisified at having gone level on points with the champions, United holding second place only on goal difference.

Arsenal have now won six successive games at home in all competitions and if they can start to improve on their away record - a defeat and three draws so far in the league - the race for the championship with United will be on again. For the moment, however, United face the unusual task of overtaking Leicester, whom they meet at Filbert Street on Saturday week.

Wenger's side owed yesterday's victory to their tradition of being able to grab a goal against the run of play and hold that narrow lead for the larger part of the game. United had a lot of the play territorially, particularly in the second half, and enjoyed the bulk of the possession. But they were seldom able to produce the quality of pass or centre needed to disturb the command of Martin Keown and Tony Adams at the heart of Arsenal's defence.

Arsenal created the greater number of significant chances in breakaways and would have won by more but for the anticipation and agility of Fabien Barthez, back in the United goal after injury, and some indifferent finishing. The finish that won the match, however, will rarely be bettered anywhere in the Premiership this season.

Henry scored 25 times for Arsenal last season and his successful conversion from winger to striker more than compensated for the loss of Nicolas Anelka. Yet he went into yesterday's encounter having failed to find the net in nearly a month of football, and a striker without goals becomes a little lost, like a dog that has forgotten where it has buried a bone.

For half an hour yesterday Henry, despite some excellent support play and a dash past three United defenders that ended when Mickael Silvestre cut out a low centre, offered little hint of what was to come. The play had quickly slipped into a slough of predictable passes and pedestrian movement, with little width on either side and the midfield too crowded for the football to breathe.

Then David Beckham was cautioned for fouling Fredrik Ljungberg, and Nwankwo Kanu tapped the free-kick to Gilles Grimandi, who in turn found Henry near the left edge of the penalty area and with his back to goal. The Frenchman then flicked the ball on to an instep before pivoting to lob a shot past Barthez and into the top far corner of the net.

"You can't do anything about a goal like that," Sir Alex Ferguson admitted afterwards. "I couldn't believe it."

"When you haven't been scoring goals, sometimes you need to try something a little bit crazy," said Wenger, "something you don't have to think about but just do it. Thierry played with much more freedom once he had scored."

United seldom performed with the freedom that has distinguished much of their football this season. Ferguson recalled seven of the players who had missed last Tuesday's Champions League game in Eindhoven, when PSV punished his weakened defence with a 3-1 victory. But for United yesterday a change was not as good as a rest.

Although the champions increased the tempo in the second half they remained surprisingly sluggish in midfield, where normally their football is at its most tenacious. Roy Keane's response to the busy, bustling presence of Ray Parlour was placid - not a description often applied to his game - and Paul Scholes took up threatening positions without making much of them.

Individually there were some admirable qualities in United's performance; Beckham's tireless capacity for hard work, for example, and Andy Cole's undying enthusiasm for taking on Keown or Adams. But Teddy Sheringham's ineffectiveness belied the case that had been made for his England recall and Ryan Giggs, isolated on the left wing, often had to move into the middle to find the ball.

Parlour and Grimandi were influential in denying United their familiar rhythm. Although Arsenal will be glad to see the return of Patrick Vieira, who completed a five-match suspension yesterday, the way this pair consistently denied Keane, Scholes and Beckham space and time on the ball made it easier for Adams and Keown to snuff out any danger up front.

The result was that David Seaman was rarely called into urgent action. His best save, and United's best moment, came at the start of the second half when Cole's persistence on the right set up Beckham for a centre which Giggs met with a rising shot which Seaman tipped over the bar.

Once Wenger had replaced Kanu with a defender, Nelson Vivas, United found it even harder to break Arsenal down, and had Parlour not trodden on the ball after a 50-yard dash by Henry set him up for a goal, Highbury would have been spared an anxious last few minutes.

This was United's first Premiership defeat since losing 3-0 at Newcastle on February 12 and they have now beaten Arsenal only once in seven encounters. "You get these blips occasionally," said Ferguson, but Highbury bleeped merrily all the same.

 Martin Keown (ankle), David Beckham (knee) and Paul Scholes (foot) will need treatment after reporting for England duty this evening.

fields.headline: Vodafone hands global task to McCann-Erickson
fields.trailText: 11.15am: McCann-Erickson has picked up a multimillion pound global branding task for Vodafone following a three-way pitch, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
McCann-Erickson has picked up a multimillion pound global branding task for Vodafone following a three-way pitch.

The agency beat BMP DDB, the incumbent on the £41m UK account, and Ogilvy & Mather to the business.

Thomas Geitner, Vodafone Group's executive director responsible for global branding, said: "After seeing a number of agencies we selected McCann-Erickson for the strength of its network and proven track record on campaigns of this type. The agency will have an important role to play in establishing our future global brand, enabling Vodafone to achieve its aim of becoming the world's leading mobile multimedia company and ensuring the Group is in pole position when its operating companies launch their third-generation networks."

BMP and Vodafone had both indicated that a European review would not affect the UK business and it is unclear at this stage if the work created by McCann-Erickson will run in the UK market.

Vodafone purchased the German telecoms company Mannesman for £105bn last year. The company also paid £4.4bn for a UK mobile phone licence in May and is bidding for other European licences.

"We are delighted to have been chosen by Vodafone to assist them," said Don Dillon, regional director, McCann-Erickson Europe, Middle East & Africa. "It reaffirms the capability and experience in McCann WorldGroup in building and developing global brands."

webTitle: Zinc lures two creative directors from Ehsrealtime

fields.headline: Zinc lures two creative directors from Ehsrealtime
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Zinc has poached two creative directors from Ehsrealtime, doubling its creative team and enabling it to expand into new areas, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Interactive agency Zinc has poached two creative directors from Ehsrealtime, doubling its creative team and enabling it to expand into new areas.

Ehsrealtime creative directors Ray Howard and Paul Snoxel will slot into the same roles at Zinc and work with executive creative director Ken Frakes and creative head Louis Lygo.

While both Ehsrealtime and Zinc are part of the Havas Advertising group, Zinc is only 40%-owned by Havas and retains independent control.

New Media Age's Top 100 Web Agencies 2000 survey ranks Zinc eighth among UK interactive agencies, with a declared turnover of around £10m and a client list that boasts Microsoft, Virgin and Vodafone.

Mr Frakes said: "We are delighted that Ray and Paul - who are great creative directors - have decided to come to Zinc, where it will be an exciting challenge for them heading up a tighter team and working across digital executions."

fields.headline: Mexico hit by 135mph winds
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: With winds of nearly 135mph, Hurricane Keith buffeted the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico yesterday, with heavy rains stretching to Belize, Honduras and Nicaragua.
fields.body:
With winds of nearly 135mph, Hurricane Keith buffeted the Yucatan peninsula in Mexico yesterday, with heavy rains stretching to Belize, Honduras and Nicaragua.

Mexican officials were evacuating 5,000 people from low-lying areas around Chetumal, a city of 250,000 on the border with Belize. Many of the abandoned homes were shacks made of wooden slats and cardboard.

Forecasters warned of possible flash floods and mud slides, although the slow-moving hurricane was expected to weaken as it drifted further inland.

A hurricane warning was in effect along the Yucatan peninsula's eastern shore, from Cabo Catoche south to Monkey River Town, Belize, according to the national hurricane centre in Miami. A hurricane watch remained in effect for the Yucatan's northern coast from west of Cabo Catoche to Progreso.

Emergency teams from the Yucatan to Costa Rica were on alert in low-lying areas at risk for flooding and mountainous zones where there was a possibility of landslides. The Mexican army and civil protection officials set up shelters and called for evacuations in flood-prone areas.

The authorities in Honduras blamed bad weather for the disappearance of a helicopter carrying the country's chief justice and five others near the northern coast on Friday. The aircraft disappeared from the radar screens shortly after takeoff.

In Washington, the US state department said that Americans should consider leaving Belize because of flooding from Hurricane Keith.

In a travel warning, the state department said the hurricane had caused extensive flooding in Belize. It urged US citizens to stay in contact with the U.S. embassy "and consider departing the country as soon as it is safe to do so".

fields.headline: JWT lands Glamour magazine launch
fields.trailText: 10.45am: JWT has beaten M&C Saatchi to the £5m UK launch task for Condé Nast's Glamour magazine, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
J Walter Thompson has beaten M&C Saatchi to the £5m UK launch task for Condé Nast's Glamour magazine.

In July the publisher announced that it was launching a UK edition of the US lifestyle title in time for next spring.

A marketing spend of £5m has been earmarked for the launch of the title, which aims to establish a readership of more than 200,000 in its first year. Glamour will follow the successful US formula of celebrity coverage and features deconstructing the look of the rich and famous.

The National Magazine Company's Simon Kippin has been signed up as publisher and New Woman's editor, Jo Elvin, has been poached from Emap to edit the title.

JWT intends to make Glamour appeal to an audience that does not usually buy glossies. It will face stiff competition from Time Inc's In Style magazine, which has proved a phenomenal success in the US and is due to launch in the UK next year.

It has eclipsed the ad sales of well-established competitors including Vogue and Harper's Bazaar with its brand of celebrity features to take the top ad revenue spot for the first quarter of 2000.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life - week seven, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life - week seven, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Gambling expert Patrick Murray offers his analysis of the latest round of punts
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £126.11
Sean Ingle = £98.42
Football Unlimited punters collective = £78.28
Paul MacInnes = £76.00
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £126.11
Sean Ingle = £98.42
Football Unlimited punters collective = £78.28
Paul MacInnes = £76.00

Scott Murray
Southampton v Middlesbrough, four or more goals: £10 @ 15/8

When it comes to the total goals market Scott Murray is fast becoming a legend. He landed a touch a while back on, if memory serves me right, Liverpool v Manchester City and this week he turned his attention to the seemingly innocuous Southampton v Middlesbrough game. To the rest of us this was just another mediocre mid-table clash but to Mr M it was a money-making opportunity. I like that kind of thinking.

It is often the more esoteric markets that offer the best value because these are the markets the bookies spend least time pricing up. If you can find a market you like and really concentrate on it - undertake some detailed (preferably statistical) research, price events up yourself before you see the bookies' odds - there is no doubt you can stay one step ahead of the bookies. There are punters out there who make a good living by betting on bookings alone.

I'm not sure Scott is quite ready to go full-time yet - indeed I can't help thinking there is a large element of luck to his success so far - but he could have a future if he puts the hours in.

Sean Ingle
Sunderland to beat Leicester £8 @ 11/10

Regulars readers of this column will know I don't tend to have a lot of time for Mr Ingle. It's nothing personal but something about him irks me. I don't know what it is but I do know I find it irksome. This week, however, I am determined not to be such a curmudgeon.

Let's look on the bright side. Mr Ingle restricted himself to just one selection this week, a policy that meets with my hearty approval. Moreover, the inestimable Mr I announces his intention to "creep slowly above the £100 mark", veritable music to my ears. Indeed, Mr I, the aspiration to creep slowly, if something more than just a passing fancy, may be the beginning of your transformation into a winner. Patience is more than just a virtue - it is a necessity. I believe I have said it before, more than once, but I will say it again - it is a marathon not a sprint.

In this new-found spirit of magnanimity I will pass over the actual bet itself, pausing only to observe that it failed to win but applauding the restraint implied within it. I do wish you'd stop backing favourites though, Mr Ingle. Search out the value and you shall be rewarded.

Paul MacInnes
Arsenal to draw with Manchester United, and Chelsea to draw with Liverpool: £4.67 double @ 9/4 and 2/1

Ah, the dual disasters that are draw doubles, to wallow in alliteration for one excruciatingly extended moment. Draw doubles, two sins for the price of one. The double element surely needs no further condemnation but my objection to betting on the draw may not be so obvious.

It's not that these two games didn't look like draws to me, they did (and Mr MacInnes made an eloquent argument as to why they did), it is just that I know from experience that obvious draws rarely end up as expected. If just a third of what we consider to be 'obvious draws' ended up as such then there could be profit to be made, but believe me they don't. Or better still don't believe me, test it for yourself: over the next few weeks note down what you consider to be the obvious draws and see how many turn out as predicted. If you're still getting a third or more right after fifty-odd results then perhaps draws are the way forward for you.

But for me it always seems far easier, and somehow less random, to oppose bad favourites or back underrated outsiders (or preferably both at once).

So nought out of two for Mr MacInnes this week, but there's still plenty of time to turn the season around. It's the World Cup qualifiers next weekend when bookies are at their most vulnerable, so start researching now.

Roy Chan, trainee accountant
Arsenal to beat Manchester United @ 13/8, Bolton to draw with Fulham @ 9/4, Cambridge to beat Oldham @ 13/8, Bristol City to beat Oxford @ 6/4, Millwall to beat Peterborough @ 5/4, and Swansea to beat Bury @ 5/4: 1x50p accumulator, 20x20p trebles, 15x20p fourfolds, 6x20p fivefolds = 42 bets at £8.92

I see that all my efforts are doomed. Week after week I rail against perms, multiples and other such monstrosities designed to maximise payout and thus minimise the actual chance of winning. But week after week our lucky punters seem to collect despite embracing the very things I condemn. But I won't give up. I'll restate my position once again although doubtless I'm shouting into a void.

What it comes down to is this - value is a very rare commodity. When a bookmaker sets his win/draw/win prices he builds a 12% margin into his prices (ie: if you backed all three outcomes to pay out the same amount of money you would lose 12% of your stake whatever the result), so for the bookmaker to offer value he has to get the prices fairly radically wrong. And given the fact that he has probably been doing the job for years and eats, drinks and sleeps football this isn't going to happen too often. Certainly not five or six times a week.

But when you do a multiple you are implying this is exactly what has happened, the bookmaker must have got several matches radically incorrect. Because if the bets aren't value, why are you having them? Moreover, by combining non-value bets in multiples, you merely compound the error leading to even worse value.

Impatience is the curse of the modern age but "I want it all and I want it now" is not an appropriate mantra for a successful gambler. It's not about the big hit, it's about the slow accumulation. It's the bank balance at the end of the year that matters not the bank balance at the end of the week.

Mr Chan certainly seems to have a good knack at picking winners, with four out six selections coming in and all at odds against - he's made a profit of £11.78 - but are his selections value? If they aren't then sure as pigs is pigs Mr Chan will lose in the long term.

But there I go being curmudgeonly again. I can't help it, dear punters. I see you wandering like lost sheep and I try to protect you but alas harsh words are all I know. Happy punting.

webTitle: Behind TV's latest answer to OK! is a serious agenda

fields.headline: An accessory after the factual
fields.standfirst: Behind TV's latest answer to OK! is a serious agenda.  Maggie Brown  talks to the man who has always been too good for Carlton
fields.trailText: Behind TV's latest answer to OK! is a serious agenda. Maggie Brown talks to the man who has always been too good for Carlton
fields.body:
Last Monday, Andi Peters went on This Morning to plug the start of Celebrity!, the new teatime showbiz programme he's fronting. By Wednesday, Richard and Judy had got their pound of flesh as the undemanding Celebrity! "took us behind the scenes" of This Morning. It won't surprise anyone to hear that Celebrity! is made by Carlton. With its reliance on ITV stars (well, it was rustled up in six weeks), it is budget TV, wall-to-wall easy-view plugs and pop videos: a stereotypical Carlton project.

Except that that is not the whole story. As Celebrity! was bedding down, Steve Hewlett, Carlton's director of programmes, was in Washington, sealing a deal with Time magazine and the Washington Post to develop factual programming together. (This mirrors an arrangement by Granada with the New York Times.) Stacked by Hewlett's TV set in his Portman Square offices in London's West End are tapes of Britain at War, a follow-up series to the award-winning Second World War in Colour.

Celebrity!, warts and all, fits into a larger quest, to build a production business, in volume as well as value terms, after the failed collaboration with OK! magazine. Hewlett has made sure that a seasoned team is in charge, used to making live, daily television. Another department of Carlton Productions is, even now, casting actors for the remake of Crossroads; sets are under construction in the company's Nottingham studios and production starts in December. Landing a daily soap was, Hewlett observes, "the holy grail". He tenderly produces a huge box file containing Crossroads scripts and storylines.

At 42, Hewlett is a large, shrewd and resilient man, whose past career spans a successful stint as editor of Panorama, and another as head of factual programmes at Channel 4. Delegates at this year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival watched him anchor a key session on Big Brother, forcing Peter Bazalgette to disclose that he was automatically signing up contestants for his talent agency.

Lawyers for Richard Desmond, chairman of Northern and Shell, which publishes OK!, have written to Carlton warning it that they will be swelling the audience watching Celebrity! to make sure OK! isn't being ripped off. "For us it is a fantastic opportunity. ITV is prepared to trust Carlton with a live and daily programme - that's quite a new phenomenon," observes Hewlett. "Richard Desmond is his own man, used to running his own company, and everything jumps to his tune. It's his thing. Television requires a different approach, collaborative. It's harder to be finicky." Hewlett then goes off the record to describe some ripe Desmond-style exchanges.

Carlton is already locked in a legal dispute with the News of the World, over allegations of fakery on The Cook Report. The strand remains off air while the libel war dance is played out. Hewlett confirms that series editor Mike Morley left the company's employ over the summer, but is still a consultant.

Hewlett was recruited to inject gravitas and editorial controls after the disaster of The Connection, a programme that faked drug-trafficking evidence, leading to a record fine from the independent television commission, and no little discredit for the company. "Those problems are historic, not current," insists Hewlett. But what about The Cook Report? "There was never any suggestion that the audience was misled. The issues are about the way the programme was being run. We are disputing the veracity of what they [the NoW] are saying.

"At its best the programme, and Roger Cook, showed themselves capable of bringing investigative journalism to a wide audience. If we could bring it back, splendid. At the moment, until the News of the World case is resolved, it is in suspended animation. The problem for The Cook Report, although we reject the serious allegations, is that because it delves into areas of criminality, it is always dealing with people who are unreliable. As soon as questions are raised about reliability, it's an open invitation for someone to claim he's been traduced. So it's just not practicable to run it."

Surely Hewlett's collaborative TV team skills have been tested to the limit since Lord (Waheed) Alli of Planet 24 was brought into Carlton 18 months ago, seemingly to do the same job? "I'm not going to say it wasn't a bit difficult at first. It was. Partly because at that time I was only six months into what you can see the results of. I'm director of programmes, part of Carlton Television. I report to Waheed. When you look at the production division, out of a turnover of £140m, £120m of it is here with me."

So Hewlett has nothing to do with The Big Breakfast? "It's run as separate companies. Planet 24 [now a wholly owned subsidiary of Carlton] doesn't report to me. Going forward, who knows? Anyway, the point is, there were difficult moments in the beginning. The reason it was a bit tricky is that in the end we were saying the same thing, and both trying to create a vibrant in-house talent base.

"At the launch of The Railway Children, Waheed was host. But the celebrity launch of World War Two in Colour - I'll host that. These things are never easy, but in the fundamentals, there is some evidence that we are succeeding. In a curious way our skills are complementary.

"I'm used to working in big organisations. I have broader, longer and more direct production experience. And I'm plugged into genres that he has no knowledge of. Whereas in entertainment, in dealing with talent, he's pretty plugged in."

Carlton is also making the UK version of Survivor, the reality gameshow that has taken the US by storm. The format was devised by Alli and his partner Charlie Parsons, but was not part of the Planet 24 sale to Carlton (according to some accounts of the deal, Carlton chairman Michael Green was dismissive of the show). But for all Alli's showbusiness nous - it was he who fronted the bid to get ITV to commission Crossroads - he is not taking a hand in Celebrity!.

Carlton's fundamental problem, as Hewlett sees it, is that it isn't Thames. "The problem for Carlton, once Michael Green had taken the licence off Thames, was that it was seen as part of the whole Thatcher project. Everyone hated them. I don't have that much to do with Michael Green. He's fairly hands-off in terms of the way the business is run; I get a note from him every now and then saying 'I really enjoyed that, thanks very much.'"

Carlton, he adds, was set up on a fundamentally flawed concept, as a publisher/broadcaster. "It seemed like a brilliant idea at the time. Except why should independent producers bother with a TV franchise holder when they could go direct to the ITV network centre". Or anywhere else. The abiding truth seems to be that "content is king", especially in the new media. Between 1994 and 1999, Carlton, by now buttressed by the takeover of Central, saw a 45% decline in its production business. In addition what was Central Productions, with a great tradition in a wide range of programming, just withered in the hands of centralised management. Last year Carlton accounted for 13% of network programmes, while the Granada bulldozer made 50%. The danger now is that Carlton, loser in the TV merger game, will itself wither as a minor player in ITV.

"I don't accept that," argues Hewlett. "Carlton has the two biggest, most lucrative licences, and can't be messed around with. We intend to proceed in the spirit of partnership. The merger doesn't disadvantage us, though it is unsettling. In production we didn't get over-panicked - these people here are sufficiently good to have a future. ITV needs programmes and the ones we make. The production businesses really are separate from broadcasting," he says.

Behind the scenes, adds Hewlett, there has been a big reorganisation at Carlton in the past two years, to separate out production. "I inherited a commissioning structure. We've transformed it to a production centre."

In-house production is shooting up: Barbara, Big Bad World, The Vice, Peak Practice, now up to 26 episodes a year (and discussing a further increase with ITV network centre). But there is a downside: Carlton declined to go on making Monsignor Renard, a John Thaw star vehicle, because, at a cost of £2m an episode (not fully paid back by ITV), it was losing money without hefty guaranteed overseas sales. It marked the point when Alli was cracking the boss's whip.

Hewlett says his key input was to hire the right people to turn around Carlton's image. "Factual programmes, in my view, were desperate for the credibility." He pays tribute to Polly Bide, Carlton's controller of factual programmes: "She's fantastically sure-footed in matters of editorial." He points to the two episodes of Horizon made for the BBC, a new series for Channel 4 and Discovery's Learning Channel, Hell in the Pacific, marking the anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

"In terms of Carlton's image and appearance, these programmes are absolutely vital. What most people thought was wrong with Carlton related to its factual programmes."

Equally, with around 250 people now working in Carlton Productions you can see how the incentive to stick around, and work with Alli, is real enough.

fields.headline: Mviva attracts 30,000 customers
fields.trailText: 10am: Mviva, the Carphone Warehouse Group's mobile internet joint venture with AOL Europe, has attracted 30,000 customers, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mviva, the Carphone Warehouse Group's mobile internet joint venture with AOL Europe, has attracted 30,000 customers.

The portal, which launched in July, offers shopping, banking, news and email services, with coverage in five European countries so far.

Mviva has been quick to sign content deals with the likes of CNN, Sky News, the Guardian and Loot.

Charles Dunstone, chief executive of the group, said: "These figures are a good start for Mviva and clearly indicate that the mobile internet is becoming a popular and useful service, representing the future of mobile communication.

"In addition, our partnerships with the European networks give customers an even wider choice of service and content by being able to choose both Mviva and the network's own portal."

The Carphone Warehouse Group raised £185m from its July flotation, which will help maintain the pace of its European expansion. Carphone Warehouse has 45 UK stores and another 430 in Europe.

The group's shares fell 1% to 190p in early trading, against a post-flotation high of 237.5p.

The stock market remains concerned about the pressure on Carphone Warehouses' margins as it continues to invest in its European ventures and competition builds from supermarkets and other non-specialist retailers.

webTitle: IPC boss joins protest against BBC mags

fields.headline: IPC boss joins growing protest against BBC mags
fields.standfirst: Publishers press for BBC mags probe
fields.trailText: 10am: Caroline Ward, managing director of IPC TX, which handles IPC's TV listings titles, has called for stricter rules to prevent BBC magazines having an unfair market advantage over its rivals.
fields.body:
Caroline Ward, managing director of IPC TX, which handles IPC's TV listings titles, has called for stricter rules to prevent BBC magazines having an unfair market advantage over its rivals.

Ms Ward has thrown her weight behind Emap, which last week said it was looking at whether it had a case to ask the OFT to investigate BBC Worldwide's magazine launch strategy.

She told MediaGuardian that the growth in uptake of digital TV services meant it was becoming harder for commercial publishers' advertisements to reach mass audiences.

Ms Ward said: "I, and other publishers, would like to have a review of the right of BBC magazines to have on-screen promotion. As it gets harder to reach audiences, this makes the advantages for BBC magazines even greater."

She added that IPC was not actively talking to the OFT or formally with other publishing houses.

Last week Emap Elan's president, Sue Hawken, said Emap was considering whether it had a legal case to ask the OFT to examine whether BBC Worldwide's magazine launches had an unfair advantage over commercial rivals.

Ms Ward said the issue - which was raised by commercial magazine publishers when the BBC first launched magazines - had been revived by the corporation's increasingly aggressive commercial magazine launches. But she added that "for TV listings magazines it's always been a very live issue".

Commercial publishers claim that the practice of allowing magazines free promotion on licence-fee funded channels gives BBC magazines an unfair commercial advantage.

fields.headline: Mirror Group hires Hurman as national ad director
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The Mirror Group has appointed Leagas Delaney's media director Neil Hurman as ad director for national titles, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Mirror Group has appointed Leagas Delaney's former media director Neil Hurman as its new ad director for national titles.

Mr Hurman said: "The opportunity to join the national newspaper division of Trinity Mirror at such a compelling time for both the company and the media was too interesting a challenge to pass on."

He began his career at Ray Morgan and Partners which became Zenith after it was bought by Saatchi & Saatchi in 1998. He joined Leagas Delaney in 1989 and was appointed to its board in 1993, becoming media director in June 1998.

The Mirror has been looking for a candidate to fill the ad director's role since last year. The departure of managing director Roger Eastoe and the arrival of chief executive Joe Sinyor from Sony last month increased speculation about who would take the position.

Mark Pritchett, the group advertising director, national titles, is considering an alternative role within Trinity Mirror.

webTitle: Large and Roberts launch Fresh agency

fields.headline: Large and Roberts launch Fresh agency
fields.trailText: 9am: Ali Large, the former vice-chairman of Doner Cardwell Hawkins, and Lindsey Roberts, its planning director, are launching a start-up agency called Fresh, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ali Large, the former vice-chairman of Doner Cardwell Hawkins, and Lindsey Roberts, its planning director, are launching a start-up agency called Fresh.

The agency, which opens for business this week, aims to help clients apply inspiration to their brands and business.

The impetus behind Fresh was a recognition of the changes that have taken place in media and communication. "The tried and tested has become the tired and tested and while clients have access to lots of opinions few are really unbiased," said Ms Roberts.

Ms Large added: "Our style is collaborative and we don't care who has a good idea - as long as someone does. We will work with clients and their agencies and that way you get buy-in rather than competition and the real winner is the brand."

Ms Large, who has worked at several large agency networks including Young & Rubicam, Ammirati Puris Lintas and D'Arcy, said she had become frustrated with the limitations of an agency environment.

Ms Roberts is a former managing director of Yellowhammer. Before that she worked as marketing director of Still Price Lintas.

fields.headline: ONdigital's subscriber churn rate hits 20%
fields.trailText: 9.45am: ONdigital's subscriber churn rate is understood to have hit 20% and is expected to go higher, says Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Digital terrestrial television operator ONdigital's subscriber churn rate is understood to have hit 20% and is expected to go higher, jeopardising the pay-TV outfit's chances of hitting its take-up targets.

The rise in churn could also hit Carlton and Granada's plans to float or sell-off a minority stake in ONdigital. The two companies are considering whether to float up to 20% of the pay-TV operator, possibly before the end of the year. They are also reported to be talking to telecoms companies about taking an equity stake. ONdigital is expected to be valued at £1.5bn-2bn.

The sharp rise in ONdigital's churn rate - the percentage of the consumer base not renewing their subscriptions on a month-by-month basis - was highlighted earlier this week in a Merrill Lynch analyst's report on Carlton Communications. The briefing noted: "signs of a significant increase in churn from 4% to 20% as early subscribers come off 12-month contracts."

The churn rate is said has risen over the past three months as ONdigital customers who took advantage of the free set-top box offer introduced at the end of May 1999 came to the end of their 12-month contract.

It is the likely ONdigital's churn rate will rise even higher in the first quarter of 2001. The first three months of the year, when consumers cut back on spending after the Christmas and new year period, is traditionally a time when pay-TV subscriber numbers dip.

In the three months to the beginning of June, ONdigital's subscriber numbers rose by 101,000 to hit 774,000.

Stuart Prebble, chief executive of the Carlton/Granada joint venture, said in July that the pay-TV firm was on course to reach 1m subscribers by the end of the year and 2m - at which point it is expected to break even - by the end of 2002.

webTitle: Magic boxes which want to filter our viewing

fields.headline: Must-see TV, all day, every day
fields.standfirst: Stick it on top of your set and it takes out the programmes you don't like and leaves you with your favourites - but it won't mean the end of adverts.  Dawn Hayes  on the tide of magic boxes which want to filter our viewing
fields.trailText: Stick it on top of your set and it takes out the programmes you do not like and leaves you with your favourites - but it will not mean the end of ads. Dawn Hayes on the tide of magic boxes which want to filter our viewing.
fields.body:
Just as Europe was catching on to the name TiVo, another magic box which lets you skip the adverts or fast forward and rewind "live" television has arrived. So technology has moved on again and a war is developing over who wins the right to filter our viewing experience for us.

The personal video recorder technology (PVR), which is also intelligent enough to work out which pro grammes we like to watch and then record them for us, was heralded by the director-general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, as having the power to change the TV industry for ever. And as he gleefully pointed out in his keynote speech at the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival last month, PVRs jeopardise the entire economic structure of commercial TV.

Perhaps that is why the two biggest names in the PVR business, TiVo and ReplayTV, have sold fewer than 100,000 units in the US between them after nearly two years. Broadcasters have been understandably resistant to the idea of technology taking away their advertising revenues and the whole idea has gone down like a lead balloon among advertisers.

The cracks have already begun showing in the PVR wonder box even before it hits the high street in Britain. It will go on sale for £400 this month for use on BSkyB's digital network. But it will be superseded early next year by a new and cheaper set-top box from Pace Micro Technology and NDS Technologies, a division of News Corporation, which puts the remote control back in the hands of broadcasters.

The new box most definitely will not allow you to skip the adverts. Quite the opposite in fact. It collects information about the viewer for the benefit of the broadcaster - not the other way round. That means it is better able to target adverts at the right people, which means more advertising revenues for broadcasters. Impulse buying is so much easier with digital TV: all you need to do is press a button.

The Pace-NDS box contains a 40 gigabyte recordable hard drive and two tuners so that consumers can view their programmes and record a different channel simultaneously. It offers the same functionality as the TiVo box, and much more besides, but it will be cheaper. It offers enough storage for broadcasters to download everything from Yellow Pages, home shopping catalogues, online games and digital music files to the week's top 10 films. TiVo is working hard to stand still by adding the same capabilities to its platform.

"All broadcasters are looking at these embedded PVR products - we're in intense discussions with a number of them," says Malcolm Miller, chief executive at Pace. "We've been working on this for the last two years and we think we're ahead of anyone else."

It is no coincidence that the first customer for the Pace-NDS box is BSkyB, which also happened to sign an exclusive agreement to sell the TiVo box. That may explain why TiVo will cost more than the Pace-NDS box.

Certainly, £400 is an ambitious price for a nation that has grown accustomed to getting set-top boxes and mobile phones for "free". Faced with the arrival of the hard-drive product next year, TiVo and ReplayTV have begun reshaping their strategy to conform with broadcasters' and advertisers' wishes. It boils down to survival.

They have started positioning themselves as not just box suppliers, but also service providers. They are working hard at packaging advertising and programming in their boxes before they ship them out of the factories in order to offer a service to broadcasters which don't hold content rights. Operators such as BSkyB have built their own services and TiVo is working on storing original content such as programme previews, infomercials, short films and features on the PGA golf tour. Similarly, Coca-Cola will launch an ad campaign on ReplayTV's box this month in the US and a promotional campaign with Universal Pictures is planned.

TiVo is even working with Nielsen Media Research to measure audience interaction with its service. The two companies also plan to experiment with finding more effective advertising vehicles for PVR services by using a 1,500-person panel of TiVo customers.

For all the talk about technology transforming our experience of watching television, it appears to have been snatched from under our noses.

Since BSkyB signed an exclusive agreement with TiVo, it can keep any other pay-TV networks in the UK from getting their hands on it.

Still, companies have started finding ways to get round the status quo and others are expected to follow. Last week, Videonet rolled out the first commercial video-on-demand service in the UK using British Telecom's ADSL souped-up phone network. It claims to offer similar functions to the TiVo box.

Called HomeChoice, the service is heavily subsidised: customers pay a one-off set-top box charge of £40 and monthly charges start at £6 for access to a range of films and television programmes. The cost to Videonet is considerably more. It pays British Telecom £62 per ADSL line customer and £100 for each set-top box. Profit at the company is some way off, but chief executive Simon Hochhauser says that unlike other on-demand television companies, including Yes Television and Filmgroup, he has not cancelled plans for a stock market flotation.

"We are also looking at strategic relationships with other companies in order to raise money, but we might well do an IPO," he says.

HomeChoice is available now to 2.5m households in London, and the company plans to extend it to 70% of British homes by the end of next year, with Birmingham and Manchester next on the list.

Slice it or dice it whichever way you want - a range of businesses from phone companies to internet upstarts plan to start offering personalised TV and e-commerce services to British consumers over phone lines, satellite and terrestrial networks from now on. If the choice seems overwhelming, it's meant to be. There is everything to play for and projections for growth in on-demand digital services are awe-inspiring.

According to UK-based Kagan World Media, by 2006 42% of the UK, or around 11m homes, will be able to subscribe to on-demand television services compared with just 3% now. Beyond the UK, there will be 410m digital cable and satellite homes worldwide by 2010, representing 37% of the world's television households, according to research company Baskerville Communications. Together, these homes are expected to generate $21bn in pay-per-view film revenues.

So TiVo may have peaked before its time but the concept behind the box is alive and kicking. That said, for all Greg Dyke's predictions of seismic change in the industry, it looks as if advertising is very much here to stay.

fields.body:
GUARDIAN

Comedian Jim Davidson is to provide the warm up to the Tory party conference's climax on Thursday. (p6)
BT has denied that Sir Iain Vallance, its chairman, has agreed to stand down and has insisted he will remain for at least two more years. (p22)
The new economy must come of age.(p23)
MEDIAGUARDIAN
Trevor Kavanagh, the Sun's political editor, talks to Roy Greenslade. Cover story
NTL's link up with US film giant Universal could be bad news for Sky. (p4)
A look at TV's latest answer to OK! And the man behind it: Maggie Brown interviews Steve Hewlett. (p4)
The BBC's head of children's entertainment Chris Bellinger talks to Merope Mills. (p6)
Cabal's new magazine, Mondo launches today. (p7)
Why the few Asian actors on television are the same old faces. (p8)

FINANCIAL TIMES

The total earnings of top chief executives rose by an average of 18.6 per cent in the year to May says a report from Hay Management Consultants. CEOs of companies in the FTSE 100 are now being paid an average of £752,000 a year. (p2)
More than two dozen of Scotland's most promising technology start-up companies will pitch this week to raise a combined total of £100m from venture capitalists at Scotland's biggest investment showcase event. (p6)
A Russian TV show called Redykyulass! that makes fun of the political establishment has become the king of locally made television. Within two months of its first airing it scooped about three-quarters of the market share on a Sunday evening. (p11)
Vivendi, the French communications group, is to overhaul its corporate goverance practices in an effort to satisfy the demands of US investors ahead of its planned £23bn merger with Seagram. (p25)
Vallance stays on at BT.(p25)
Totalise, an internet company that gives free shares to its users, announces plans for an AIM flotation to raise funds for launching the UK's first online bank to be partly owned by its customers. (p25)
MP3.com, which is in the midst of a copyright fight with Universal Music group, hopes to settle. (p31)

INDEPENDENT

Camelot has threatened to take fresh legal action against the lottery regulator.(p2)
Nomura, the Japanese investment bank, has sacked two of its top London salesmen for unauthorised share dealing in Scoot.com, the online directory service. (p15)

DAILY TELEGRAPH

The White House has tried to block an Ulster Television programme about IRA gun running in Florida.(p2)
Five million viewers tuned in to watch the British Olympic team at the Games' opening ceremony on the BBC - high figures recorded for several key programmes. (P2)
Dan Sabbagh takes a look at Psion's new Wavefinder digital radio. (p24)
Silicon.com, the online real-time news and recruitment service, is to expand its business into Europe.(p25)
More speculation about Manchester United's sponsorship deal with Nike which is due to be announced today. (p27)

THE TIMES

The Times fights a case on the right of the media to report matters of public interest. (p10)
Publicis and Cordiant Communications are close to a deal that will create one of the world's media buying organisations. (p23)
The £1.5 billion flotation of OnDigital is likely to be postponed until the spring. (p23)

THE MIRROR

More on Olympic viewing figures. (p4)
Jerome Flynn vehicle Badger has been ditched by the BBC. (p7)
More on the Olympics coverage. (p8-9)

THE SUN

An advert for energy drink Red Devil, starring Vinnie Jones, has received 390 complaints. (p3)

DAILY EXPRESS

TV presenter Anthea Turner in yet another publicity stunt, this time for Comic Relief (p16)

fields.headline: Haider embraces SS veterans
fields.standfirst:
Weeks after the end of EU sanctions against Austria, the far-right leader is again mixing in bad company

Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: Austria's populist firebrand, Jörg Haider, taunted EU governments yesterday by appearing at an annual reunion of SS veterans and Hitler's other soldiers shortly after Brussels ended seven months of diplomatic sanctions against his country.
fields.body:
Austria's populist firebrand, Jörg Haider, taunted EU governments yesterday by appearing at an annual reunion of SS veterans and Hitler's other soldiers shortly after Brussels ended seven months of diplomatic sanctions against his country.

The de facto leader of the anti-immigration Freedom party (FPO), which shares government with the conservative People's party (OVP), hit back at Vienna's 14 EU partners for attempting to isolate Austria because of his rightwing views.

The experience of Austrians in rebuilding postwar Europe had given the country the strength to stand up and fight the "unjust" sanctions, said Mr Haider, who is governor of the southern province of Carinthia.

"The future democracy is decided by the people and not by a handful of various self-declared European leaders," he said in what was widely interpreted as an indirect dig at France, Germany and Belgium.

The sanctions were lifted last month after a report by a group of European experts, dubbed the "three wise men", concluded that the sanctions were "counter-productive" because they turned Austrians against Europe and into the arms of Mr Haider.

Mr Haider said of the gathering of veterans: "Those who come to Ulrichsberg are not the old Nazis. They are not neo-Nazis, they are not criminals."

But Peter Timm managed to make the strenuous mountain pilgrimage, paying £2.50 for entry to the annual gathering to commemorate the deaths of Hitler's soldiers. The 79-year old former Waffen SS officer travelled to Carinthia from his home in Rheinland-Pfalz, in Germany.

"This is my 40th time," he said. "It gets harder every year, but only death will keep me away." The sentiment was largely shared by more than 2,000 of his former colleagues from the SS and Wehrmacht, members of sympathy groups from Italy, France and Hungary, and the Burschenschaften - young and uniformed rightwing fraternities.

Mr Timm and his colleagues spoke with enthusiasm about their time spent fighting on the Russian front for Hitler. The SS death's head signet ring Mr Timm still wears, he explained with ease, was an award, along with an iron cross, for the part he played in the Nazis' brutal suppression of the Warsaw uprising.

"We fought for Germany, not for the SS, and I had no choice - that's why Europe's free today," he added before three skinhead youths from the German state of Saxony suddenly tried to extricate him from the media glare.

For Mr Haider, who was elected as governor of Carinthia last February with 42% of the vote, this year's event was supposed to be a chance for him to clean up his act. The speech he made five years ago to SS veterans at Ulrichsberg caused an international outcry after he praised the former members of Hitler's voluntary army as "men of character".

Speaking yesterday against the backdrop of a huge steel and concrete crucifix, he defended Austria from criticism by the outside world that it had done little to fight its Nazi past.

"It can't be so that the history of our fathers and grandparents, due to dubious commentaries, is reduced to a single catalogue of crimes, and that the part they played in history is just thrown back in their faces," he said to great applause.

Willi Stelzhammer, of the human rights pressure group SOS Mitmensch, whose members milled among the crowds along with a handful of anti-Nazi observers, said: "This was clearly a cleverly-constructed event by Haider to convince the world that Austria is more tolerant."

An attempt by opponents to disrupt the meeting by flying over the scene in a helicopter blaring Wagner music flopped after a tabloid newspaper exposed the plan, prompting the helicopter company to cancel the flight.

Drinking a schnapps with his neo-Nazi fans, Mr Timm said he was satisfied. "He's the only one we've got," he said of Mr Haider, his hands trembling as he lit a cigarette with a lighter bearing the slogan of the rightwing extremist German National party (NPD).

"I only wish he had a doppelgänger so that we could have a Haider in Germany."

fields.headline: Maximus voted big screen's sexiest
fields.trailText: The brooding Roman general Maximus in the movie Gladiator has been voted the sexiest film character of all time, in a poll published yesterday.
fields.body:
The brooding Roman general Maximus in the movie Gladiator has been voted the sexiest film character of all time, in a poll published yesterday.

The avenging hunk, played by the New Zealand actor Russell Crowe, topped the voting in the survey of readers for the film magazine Empire. More than 5,000 voted.

The top choice for a female star was Princess Leia in Return of the Jedi, in which the actor Carrie Fisher appears in a skimpy gold bikini top.

At number three is Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman in Batman Returns, which sees her cavorting in a rubber catsuit.

The Star Wars saga has another entry, at number seven, for Qui-Gon Jinn, the Jedi Knight played by Liam Neeson, and Jane Fonda's space strip as Barbarella made number six.

Characters from four decades ago are in the top 10: Holly Golightly (Audrey Hepburn) in Breakfast at Tiffany's and Sugar Kane (Marilyn Monroe) in Some Like It Hot.

The top 10 are: 1. Maximus in Gladiator (2000). 2. Princess Leia in Return of the Jedi (1983). 3. Catwoman in Batman Returns (1992). 4. Indiana Jones in the sci fi trilogy (1981/84/89), starring Harrison Ford. 5. Sugar Kane in Some Like It Hot (1959). 6. Barbarella in Barbarella (1967). 7. Qui-Gon Jinn in Star Wars: The Phantom Menace (1999). 8. Holly Golightly in Breakfast at Tiffany's (1961). 9. Trinity in The Matrix (1999), Carrie-Anne Moss. 10. Catherine Banning in The Thomas Crown Affair (1999), Rene Russo.

fields.headline: Sky shows way
fields.standfirst: It has converted most subscribers to digital and is dominant in TV's latest revolution. But Sky is still heavily reliant on football and what happens when we all go digital is anyone's guess, says  Oliver Rowe
fields.trailText: It has converted most subscribers to digital and is dominant in TV's latest revolution. But Sky is still heavily reliant on football and what happens when we all go digital is anyone's guess, says Oliver Rowe
fields.body:
It is exactly two years since Sky launched its digital TV service and in that time, around one in five UK households have bought a digital TV system. New research by media agency CIA UK, revealed here exclusively by the Guardian, shows digital is totally changing the way many of us look at our TV.

Sky has established itself as the dominant digital platform. Around four out of five digital households have gone with Sky, but it has now converted the majority of its traditional analogue users on to digital. CIA's research shows that digital penetration will slow over the next 12 months to around two-thirds of the last year's level. Switching those who have resisted multichannel TV for so long is going to be far harder.

But for those who have switched, the result is positive. Sky's programming is the dominant attraction and not just thanks to the volume of channels but also because the digibox gives consumers access to their favourite programming - sport. CIA's research found four of the top five shows that could make Sky Digital viewers change supplier are football, namely home nations World Cup qualifiers (top with 28%), Premiership football, Champions League and Match of the Day. The other top five show was EastEnders.

Football's dominance could be seen as a weakness but with its current offering, Sky is in a position of strength. The other weapon in its armoury is the development of interactive channels such as Sky Sports Extra. Subscribers listed it as the second most important reason for purchase, behind increased number of channels. Interactive services such as email, internet access and shopping through Open weren't given as major reasons for purchase but once they have them, 44% of digital subscribers enjoyed using them. UK adults as a whole put interactive channels fourth in terms of appeal behind more channels and better picture and sound.

Interestingly, the growing number of channels isn't seen by many digital subscribers as a straight trade-off with quality. A third agree that more channels will be detrimental but 44% don't think quality will suffer. Among the general public (including those with digital) CIA found just under half expecting programming to suffer while 29% said it wouldn't. Three years ago CIA found 56% expecting quality to fall as quantity rose, suggesting that the public is slowly coming round to the charms of multichannel programming.

One yardstick of quality is news. The Sensor research asked people which of the current rolling news services they would turn to first in terms of quality. BBC News 24 got the highest vote with 38% saying it would be their number one choice, while ITN's new service came second with 31%. Although the difference isn't statistically significant Sky News looks like the winner in Sky Digital households, scoring 36% versus 32% for BBC News 24, while ITN got just 18%.

Does this support the idea that Sky is better than many people give it credit for? Is the experience so much better than people expect that they suddenly feel able to trust Sky with delivering programming as important as news or are digital households (biased towards young middle-class families) less able to discern quality?

What happens when we've all gone digital is anyone's guess but the fact is that Sky is doing well at present. The selection of news channel has enormous implications for broadcasters. What time BBC or ITV shows news is just a sideshow for the digital audience. Rolling news services deliver the news almost on demand, permanently head-to-head; when we all have digital, the need to run a news programme primetime on an entertainment channel will go. Instead the consumer's decision will be between news brand and not broadcast time. In this situation, it will be a straight choice.

Indeed such issues will affect every programme as technology such as the much-vaunted TiVo demonstrates. The ability of TiVo to record shows without being programmed and to pause live broadcasts means a future of time-shift viewing. Implications for advertisers as well as broadcasters are as yet uncertain.

But when CIA asked people how much they would be willing to pay for TiVo, only 3% said they would pay the £400 plus £10 monthly fee that looks set to be the launch price. This rises to 8% among 15- to 35-year-olds. Interestingly, 57% of all adults wouldn't pay anything, confirming that the UK population is comfortable with advertising as part of their viewing experience.

What is clear from CIA's work is that the TV is going through a revolution and many of those buying into it are enjoying the experience and looking forward to further developments. At the other end is a hard core of around 25% of adults who never intend to go digital. They may become a major issue for any government intending to switch off the UK's analogue transmitters.

fields.headline: Blink and you'll miss these actors. Why? Because they're Asian
fields.standfirst: Patrick Younge, commissioning editor of  multicultural programmes at Channel 4, on TV's colour bar
fields.trailText: Patrick Younge, commissioning editor of multicultural programmes at Channel 4, on TV's colour bar
fields.body:
Imagine, if you can, that appearances by Denise Van Outen accounted for 30% of all the women you saw on a major terrestrial channel. It might be hard to believe that individual actors could dominate a channel's output in that way, but that's the reality if you're an Asian watching ITV.

According to a recent study of a week's prime-time output on British television, seven appearances by newsreader Shulie Ghosh accounted for 30% of all Asian women in speaking roles on ITV. Meanwhile four appearances by Vikram Desai in Coronation Street accounted for 40% of all Asian men on the channel.

These figures were extrapolated from an annual research study for the broadcasting standards commission (BSC). Taken at face value the study made happy reading for UK broadcasters, with ethnic minorities over-represented compared to their percentage in the UK population. But the detailed channel by channel breakdown shows a more complex picture, producing surprising outcomes in terms of relative channel performances and highlighting a major problem of Asian invisibility.

The BSC logged the race of participants with speaking roles over a "composite week" to minimise distortions (Monday from one week, Tuesday from another week). Starting in late March 2000, they watched 475 programmes in total, broadcast between 5.30pm and midnight.

In all programmes shown across the five major terrestrial channels and Sky One the BSC counted 7,610 appearances, of which 570 (7.5%) were black or Asian. In UK-produced programmes there were 359 ethnic minority participants - or 6.3% of the total. Both of these figures compare well to the ethnic minority population of the UK, which is 5.5%.

Of course these figures are a snapshot, and therefore carry a health warning, but consider them from the perspective of ethnic minority viewers, especially Asian viewers, who never sees their lives, issues or achievements reflected back to them by the major UK channels.

It all feels very gloomy, but I do get a sense things are starting to change for the better. You can see shifts in ITV drama such as The Vice, Always and Everyone, The Knock and London's Burning. The new BBC2 drama Attachments has a black character in a lead role, as did the recent BBC1 series Clocking Off. And as Patrick Robinson leads in the new detective series on Channel 5, the Untold season of black and Asian history which begins tonight on Channel 4 follows on from our Caribbean Summer. All these are developments broadcasters can be proud of.

But the main reason I'm optimistic is because this time, after many false starts, the issue isn't just being driven by the liberal ideals of fairness and equality but also by the politics of the licence fee and the big, economic issues of demographics and advertising.

Black and Asian viewers are mov ing away from terrestrial television faster than any other sub-demographic in our audience. They are the early adopters of cable and satellite, with around 12 dedicated channels now providing Asian language news, film and music programming and a great deal of activity under way to establish a black/urban channel.

This shift in viewing patterns coincides with a demographic revolution already under way in British society. Currently ethnic minorities account for 5.5% of the UK population as a whole, but they account for 10% of the under-30s and 12% of the under-fives. Conservative projections predict 40% of the under-25s in London will be black, Asian and/or mixed race within 10 years.

So, the fastest growing section of the audience is also switching away from terrestrial television in record numbers - that combination makes licence fee advocates and advertising-driven commercial companies sit up and take notice. It is what has led to the establishment of the Cultural Diversity Network (CDN); an industry body "committed to changing the face of British television".

Right now senior executives in all the major broadcasters are drafting their action plans which will be pub lished this month, and submitted to culture secretary Chris Smith. Most will be setting targets for staff, at junior and senior level, with other initiatives around portrayal and talent.

At Channel 4 we already have to comply with a licence requirement of "not less than three hours on average per week of multicultural programming". It's a requirement we welcome, and because we have to deliver, the responsibility for multiculturalism has moved out of the narrow confines of the multicultural programmes department and become a duty of the channel as a whole.

So part of Channel 4's response to the CDN is a process of consolidating a range of initiatives we're already piloting. For example, every proposal for consideration will in future have to state how it intends to be appropriately multicultural, either in terms of content and/or production personnel and/or on-screen talent. To help them achieve that we're establishing a talent database, because most recruitment is informal, unadvertised and based around the "people you know".

It all seems so simple, but if it really is to work this time the broadcasters have to be held to account. Chris Smith has already pledged to make sure chief executives keep promises they've made, but what about the ITC and the BBC governors, shouldn't they have a role?

For example, how does the BBC shift responsibility for multiculturalism away from its specialist units into the channels as a whole? Most of the movement within the BBC has been on the staffing front, which will bring rewards in the long term if they can keep people from leaving. But how do they ensure that the next time they do a drama based in Glasgow, such as Glasgow Kiss, we'll actually see the Asian population of Glasgow represented? And if they can turn Gary Lineker into a decent football presenter, what black or Asian talent are they working with in sport? Should BBC2 have an hours remit like C4? These are all questions the BBC will need to consider if it is to make progress at the same rate as the change going on around it.

ITV, on the other hand, may find itself in the situation where its major component companies, Carlton and Granada, are pushing hard to increase the ethnic mix in their offers without a similar shift in the commissioning attitudes of the Network Centre - look how long it took to get an Asian family into Coronation Street.

It does involve all of us changing the way we work, and there will be mistakes. When we asked one independent company how many black or Asian staff they employed, they replied: "We interviewed a number of ethnic minority directors, and the ones we recommended you [C4] rejected." But at least now it's all out in the open. And remember the scene at the end of Big Brother where Craig, Anna and Darren - a white working class scouser, an Irish lesbian ex-nun and a black father of three - were all hugging each other, ecstatic in their shared moment of triumph. The Big Brother house may have been artificial, but the people were real, and that effortless multiculturalism and their ease of presence in each other's company is what we need to aspire to, day in day out, on British television. Especially if Big Brother, or even Big Chris, is watching.

How do six major TV channels compare when it comes to race representation?

Sky One

Sky One was the best performer. If you look at its overall output, including imports, it had by far the highest percentage of ethnic minority appearances at 13% - 8% black, 1% Asian and 4% others. However, when you took out imports such as Star Trek, the number fell from 62 to just 12, although the percentage only fell to 10% which still leaves it in first place. This 10% breaks down as seven black appearances, three by Asians and two by others. However, as all the Asians were in the same programme, an edition of British Tribes, it means Asians were entirely absent from the remaining 40-plus hours of Sky's UK programming surveyed.

Channel 5

When it comes to UK-produced programmes, 7% of appearances on Channel 5 were by people from ethnic minorities. This put it in joint second place after Sky One. However, three male characters on its soap Family Affairs accounted for more than 70% of all the black men on Channel 5, and the five black members of the Family Affairs cast accounted for more than 50% of the channel's entire ethnic rep resentation. As for Asians, over the week there was one solitary Asian appearance - on Night Fever.

ITV

In UK-produced programmes on ITV, ethnic minorities accounted for 7% of those surveyed, compared with 5.5% in the population at large. This put ITV in joint second place with Channel 5 and Channel 4, but the combined appearances of newsreader Shulie Ghosh and Coronation Street's Vikram Desai alone accounted for 32% of all the Asians on the channel - hardly a representative portrayal of British Asians.

BBC1

In UK-produced programmes on BBC1, ethnic minorities accounted for 6% of those surveyed. However, three Asian women, Shefalia Oza, Nina Nanaar and Blue Peter's Konnie Huq, accounted for 50% of all Asian women appearing on the channel - and Oza and Nanaar can only be seen by viewers of the BBC Midlands news programme.

Channel 4

Channel 4 is the only channel with a specific remit on portraying racial and cultural diversity. In UK-produced programmes on C4, 3% were black (29 people), 3% were Asian (29 people) and 1% others. Ethnic minorities accounted for 7% of those surveyed overall. Even here the Asian issue remains, because 15 of the Asians (50% of the Asians surveyed) were in one programme, a Cutting Edge documentary on the curry houses of Manchester.

BBC2

The worst performing of all channels was BBC2, where 97% of the characters in speaking roles were white, 2% were black and 1% were Asian (five people). This is the channel that gave us Goodness Gracious Me and the iconic Millie in This Life, but once again the fragility of the Asian presence is apparent - of the five Asians surveyed, three were guests on Newsnight, one was a contestant on University Challenge and one was in a Video Nation Short.

webTitle: Mondo's launch to buck the trend?

fields.headline: Bowl them over on the stands
fields.standfirst: It's been a bad year for consumer magazine launches but, says  Mat Snow, Mondo is a different story
fields.trailText: It's been a bad year for consumer magazine launches but, says Mat Snow, Mondo is a different story
fields.body:
Requiescat in pace, Aura. Go gentle into that good night, Men's Quest. James Brown's Hotdog? Not exactly sizzling off the shelves. IPC's Nova has been newsworthy more for the activity in its staff departure lounge than for soaraway success. And the BBC's Eve might need more than a fig leaf if rumours of early sales figures are true.

Why, then, is Cabal Communications trying to buck the trend with Mondo, our new magazine to be launched on Wednesday? As the lifestyle magazine for the global hedonist (it will be racked on the stands with the men's titles), we believe we have an idea whose time has come - bear market or not. More practically, as publishers of Real Homes and Front - whose improving circulations stand in contrast to the bumpier ride endured by much of our competition despite their deeper pockets, we believe we know how to reach and keep the flesh-and-blood readers who lie behind the zeitgeist.

No idea, however inspired, succeeds purely on its own merit - or its creators' self-belief. When Cabal started in 1998, the pressure was on to launch high-circulation titles as quickly as possible, knowing that months of advertising forward bookings would have to be sacrificed to the urgent necessity of establishing to the whole industry our credibility as a publisher of reader-friendly magazines. So it proved, although today's much healthier advertising revenues - up 100% year on year - suggest what might have been achieved had Front and Real Homes spent six months present ing to the advertising industry before launch.

But, with Mondo, Cabal could afford to take its time to tune the launch of a radically different magazine proposition with a hitherto untargeted upscale potential readership. It is fully 14 months since its inventors, editor Push and deputy editor Mark Wernham, quit their successful careers on the IPC magazines Muzik and Melody Maker in order to develop the Mondo concept with fellow IPC renegade Sally O'Sullivan (our proprietress who, along with Front's editor Piers Hernu, stole every scene in BBC2's four-part documentary on Cabal broadcast earlier this year).

For Push and Wernham, Mondo realises a dream. For O'Sullivan it is a magazine that not only adds to Cabal's strength in the male lifestyle market, but is a proposition that only a publisher with its tuned-in talent pool and lack of costly corporate impedimenta could achieve efficiently and without the fatal dilution that afflicts so many launches by big magazine combines. Think Later. Think Heat. Think of numerous short-lived titles published to fill a perceived gap in the market or protect a cash-cow title.

By early spring, Push, Wernham and Cabal's advertising director, Mark Lonergan, had their pitch to the advertising industry polished to a high gleam, and Mondo's launch was scheduled for May. But two months before the due date, we switched the light from green to amber. Why? Firstly, Push collapsed and had to be hospitalised with a serious kidney complaint. Secondly, display space on the news-stands was at a premium in May due to intense promotional activity by our competitors, and Mondo could not be guaranteed the visibility on the shelves that is vital to any consumer magazine launch.

Now, in October, we have plenty of prime shelf-space and an editor who is pursuing a slightly healthier lifestyle. In the weeks to come we at Cabal will see how well Mondo can swim. Being talked about in the right places should help. With its unapologetically libertarian, pleasure-seeking agenda and appeal to all those who have ever turned on, tuned in and gone travelling, tongues will wag. Furthermore, unlike existing male lifestyle magazines, Mondo is not a bunker to protect bruised male self-esteem. It does not hang a sign saying "Girls keep out". Addressing itself to self-confident, adventurous men, it will also provide a clubhouse for women who like to walk on the wild side.

And being seen in the right places should prove the clincher. Mondo's launch strategy is geared to high visibility where it ultimately matters - at point of sale. From there, we believe that once we get the magazine into the hands of the intrigued or even mildly curious, its quality will convert the impulse buy into a habit. And then into a readership. And then into a brand. Watch this space, playmates.

 Mat Snow is editorial director of Mondo
