fields.headline: Runaway train derails stock plans
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack launches inquiry into incident involving model to be introduced next year
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The timetable for the introduction of new railway rolling stock has been thrown into chaos after a driverless train made its way out of Glasgow central station and had to be derailed to prevent it hitting another train head on.
fields.body:
The timetable for the introduction of new railway rolling stock has been thrown into chaos after a driverless train made its way out of Glasgow central station and had to be derailed to prevent it hitting another train head on.

Railtrack last night confirmed that it was conducting an inquiry the incident.

The new train, with six coaches, ran down an incline, passed through red lights and continued for almost a mile until a Railtrack signalman deliberately derailed it.

Test certificates on the train, built by Alstom, have been suspended until the runaway incident on a busy commuter network has been explained. Inquiry teams are trying to find out if the brakes failed or were not fully secured.

The model is one of 40, valued at £100m, scheduled to be introduced throughout Scotland this year. The incident, which Railtrack said posed no threat to public safety, highlights the growing problem of delays to new rolling stock.

Alstom said it could not comment further until after the investigation into the incident was completed.

Railtrack is being investigated by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, following complaints by Alstom and another train manufacturer Adtranz over its refusals to approve new rolling stock costing millions of pounds. The company said yesterday: "Tests have to be strict because it must be proved that a train is safe."

It made no apologies "for making sure that a new train's electric circuits don't change red signals to green or that a new train won't clip another as they pass each other.

"Often a new train is not in service due to a failure to meet the reliability test, not because of the safety demands we require."

The rail manufacturers have told Mr Winsor that Railtrack has not provided them with adequate information about the state of the network, including such simple information as track gauges.

Mr Winsor is expected to issue an order in the next few weeks compelling Railtrack to set up a computer base in which all its assets can be stored and easily accessed by the manufacturers.

One manufacturer said: "In some cases we have had to rely on maps which are out of date or on guesswork."

webTitle: Hague bats away Heseltine googly on euro

fields.headline: Hague bats away Heseltine googly on euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague last night moved to fend off a renewed bid by moderate One Nation Tories to recapture the soul of their party when he signalled a dramatic plan to create publicly funded, private "partnership schools" as a catalyst for reviving neglected inner cities.
fields.body:
William Hague last night moved to fend off a renewed bid by moderate One Nation Tories to recapture the soul of their party when he signalled a dramatic plan to create publicly funded, private "partnership schools" as a catalyst for reviving neglected inner cities.

Hours before the opening of his Bournemouth conference, the Conservative leader will this morning formally unveil his blueprint for setting up "regeneration companies" in run-down neighbourhoods as a demonstration of this week's key conference slogan, A Conservative Party for All.

The move came after key members of his praetorian guard had been forced to slap down a provocatively timed call by Michael Heseltine for his pro-European ally, Kenneth Clarke, to be recalled to the shadow cabinet - and allowed to go on expressing his dissident views.

Calling the exclusion of such a heavy-hitter as "ludicrous" Mr Heseltine said Mr Hague should "make a real concerted effort to bring Ken Clarke back into the shadow cabinet" and campaign as a "classic One Nation Conservative".

The timing of the former deputy prime minister's call on the eve of Mr Hague's crucial pre-election party conference was calculated to cause offence, even though Mr Heseltine dressed up his remarks as a constructive contribution to the Tory campaign to win back power at Westminster.

Mr Hague's response was unmistakable. Though his inner city spokesman, Archie Norman, had been working for months on a plan for urban regeneration to rival John Prescott's strategy, his aides flagged up this morning's press conference to divert media attention from another damaging split on Europe.

Flanked by senior MPs, Mr Hague - whose brief poll lead over Labour has disappeared - will admit: "Inner city renewal is not normally associated with today's Conservative party". Poor quality of urban life has accentuated the flight of ambitious, talented people to the suburbs for 30 years, he will say.

But his remedy will be controversial. Recognising the need for an outside catalyst to stimulate change Mr Norman has persuaded his old management consultant protege - Mr Hague - to accept public/ private partnerships called "regeneration companies" with sweeping powers across health, education and crime, as well as the built environment.

Central to their efforts to persuade upwardly mobile families to stay in inner city areas will be education and the prospect of new "partnership schools" set up by independent bodies, charities, churches or businesses, but financed with public money.

The move took pressure off Michael Ancram, the Conservative chairman, who had been forced to argue that Mr Clarke, the former chancellor, who lost the 1997 leadership contest to Mr Hague, had excluded himself by refusing to accept the policy ruling out UK membership of the eurozone for the next parliament. "If you are in the shadow cabinet, you accept the collective responsibility of the shadow cabinet line. Those who do not accept it cannot expect to be in the shadow cabinet."

Mr Heseltine's intervention 24 hours before John Major makes a fresh appeal for One Nation moderation, again underlined the Tory talent for destructive infighting over Europe just as Denmark's No vote on euro-membership is forcing Tony Blair's cabinet to make a tactical retreat on the timing of its euro referendum.

To compound the offence, Mr Heseltine, who is stepping down as MP for Henley at the election, suggested to his fellow Tories that they should follow the example of one of their least favourite Labour politicians, the four-time election winner, Harold Wilson. For unity's sake, he allowed seven cabinet leftwingers to campaign for a No vote in the 1975 EU referendum.

The Tories arrive in Bournemouth in good heart. But the latest clutch of opinion polls suggest Labour has managed to bounce back from the fuel crisis - and Mr Hague's 8% lead - since ICM put the government ahead again by 38% to 37% and 20% for the Lib Dems. NOP in the Sunday Express gave Labour a 6% lead.

fields.headline: Britain's champions of liberty
fields.standfirst:
The courts should apply the Human Rights Act in the spirit of John Wilkes and Thomas Paine

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Today the Human Rights Act comes into force. Will anyone cry "Jack Straw and Liberty!" or carry Lord Irvine, in full-bottomed wig and britches, in triumph to Mansion House?
fields.body:
Today the Human Rights Act comes into force. Will anyone cry "Jack Straw and Liberty!" or carry Lord Irvine, in full-bottomed wig and britches, in triumph to Mansion House? Alas, the London mob is not what it was when it cheered such defenders of freedom as Lord Erskine, flushed from battling at the Old Bailey with the repressive government of George III.

These days, it is more easily mobilised to hunt alleged paedophiles. Whether today will mark an historic legal shift in favour of the liberty of the subject depends on whether the courts apply the new act in the spirit of John Wilkes and Tom Paine, or whether it is interpreted as just another European convention.

Of course, the act makes the European Convention of Human Rights enforceable in our own courts, short-circuiting the five-year trek to the European court in Strasbourg. But the convention is not "European" in any special sense: it sets forth a list of elemental guarantees, couched in simple English, drawn or elaborated from the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

These are principles for which English radicals have fought and died down the centuries, with some monumental successes (habeas corpus, due process, ending the death penalty) and notable failures (blasphemy, sedition, official secrecy). The advent of the Human Rights Act provides the opportunity to reverse these failures, by giving judges new powers to revise the common law (law made by judges) and reinterpret statutes to bring them into conformity with human rights principles.

Although old Labour withheld support for a bill of rights on the grounds that judges could not be trusted, there is little doubt that modern judges are up to the task. In the first test case, some were even prepared to upset anti-terrorist legislation because it reversed the burden of proof, that "golden thread" of English criminal law. This was a hopeful example of using the act to give full force to an English tradition of fair play. But in the unnecessarily long lead-time between the passage of the act (November 1998) and its operation, a danger has emerged that threatens to dilute its impact.

This period has seen the publication of many fat textbooks and innumerable training courses for judges, lawyers and magistrates. These have made the mistake of teaching the act - as if it were a European invention without English ancestry - mainly through the case law of the European court and the now defunct European commission.

This has served to obscure the richness of our own history as a source of inspirational interpretation. And it treats with too much respect a body of European jurisprudence that is cautious, sometimes reactionary, often cast in unhelpful generalities and worst of all, expressed in direst Europrose.

Instead of trying to apply such slippery precedents, our courts must recognise their limits. Strasbourg judges have been treading warily, anxious not to disturb national governments unduly. They have sometimes fudged important principles with "balancing exercises" or by allowing to states a "margin of appreciation" to infringe the liberty of their citizens in the interests, for example, of public order or the Catholic church.

Decisions emanating from a full chamber of 21 judges tend to be intellectually simplistic, while some "admissibility decisions" churned out by the European commission in the years before its demise read like law student essays and are simply wrong. Our own courts can do much better than this with the guarantees of the convention, so long as they do not feel obliged to adopt Strasbourg approaches.

To locate an authentic British culture of liberty, they should go back to Wilkes and Paine and they should look in particular to the true progenitors of the modern human rights movement - a group of writers and lawyers that formed around HG Wells to draft the first "universal" bill of rights in 1939. They included JB Priestley, Viscount Sankey (Labour's first lord chancellor), Barbara Wootton and even AA Milne, who motored up from Pooh Corner for the meetings to forge a set of written guarantees against the onslaught of fascism.

Their language ("there shall be no secret dossiers kept in any government department..an Englishman's home and reasonably limited garden enclosure is his castle") may be dated, but its spirit should infuse interpretations of the Human Rights Act. Their work, published as a Penguin Special in 1940, inspired Roosevelt's "Four Freedoms" speech and was one of the models for the Universal Declaration (which was in turn the model for the European convention) but has been forgotten by the textbooks and training materials.

The Human Rights Act will feature in a lot of litigation, although it will mostly be used to support decisions that the courts would have reached in any event. It will make a real difference, however, if it is wielded as a weapon to demolish those oppressive common laws under which freethinkers have suffered in the past. Will it mean the end of the laws of blasphemy and criminal libel and sedition? If so, the Human Rights Act will be important not only to lawyers, but to humans as well.

Geoffrey Robertson QC is author of Crimes Against Humanity: the Struggle for Global Justice, published by Penguin.

They included JB Priestley, Viscount Sankey (Labour's first lord chancellor), Barbara Wootton and even AA Milne, who motored up from Pooh Corner for the meetings to forge a set of written guarantees against the onslaught of fascism. Their language ("there shall be no secret dossiers kept in any government department..an Englishman's home and reasonably limited garden enclosure is his castle") may be dated, but its spirit should infuse interpretations of the Human Rights Act. Their work, published as a Penguin Special in 1940, inspired Roosevelt's "Four Freedoms" speech and was one of the models for the Universal Declaration (which was in turn the model for the European convention) but has been forgotten by the textbooks and training materials. The Human Rights Act will feature in a lot of litigation, although it will mostly be used to support decisions that the courts would have reached in any event. It will make a real difference, however, if it is wielded as a weapon to demolish those oppressive common laws under which freethinkers have suffered in the past. Will it mean the end of the laws of blasphemy and criminal libel and sedition? If so, the Human Rights Act will be important not only to lawyers, but to humans as well. Geoffrey Robertson QC is author of Crimes Against Humanity: the Struggle for Global Justice, published by Penguin. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Lomu tackles teething problems off the pitch

fields.headline: Lomu tackles teething problems off the pitch
fields.trailText: Can our systems cope with Jonah Lomu? The world's greatest rugby player has been helping us to test the strength, accuracy and robustness of our systems. We've been undertaking one of our regular testing sessions and Jonah is privileged to be one of our nominated early users.
fields.body:
Can our systems cope with Jonah Lomu? The world's greatest rugby player has been helping us to test the strength, accuracy and robustness of our systems. We've been undertaking one of our regular testing sessions and Jonah is privileged to be one of our nominated early users.

Although we're not great rugby fans, our operations director Stuart is. The result is a team of dummy rools customers named after famous past and present New Zealand rugby players.

These dummy customers have been playing a valuable role. At every stage of development they have tackled key functions of the rools service. Hundreds of accounts have been opened in their names, thousands of purchases have been made and most customers have received a number of refunds.

In the process, each dummy customer has built up a unique history and personal profile and Stuart has amused himself trying to reflect the real on-pitch personality as he sees it.

While Jonah Lomu runs straight through - simply opening an account and spending all his money, Grant Fox - one of the world's great fly halves - has a more complex approach, involving refunds and adjustments. The legendary John Kirwin is transformed into Sir John Kirwin as Stuart reckons he should have been knighted. He's clever, pulls off some of the most complicated transactions possible and obtains numerous partial refunds.

At one stage last week we had every member of the rools team logged on to our development site, adopting the guises of various dummy customers and testing from every angle.

One of the more basic problems was one that we thought that we had covered months ago. Somehow "robbiewilliams.com" and "kylie@pop" were both accepted as valid email addresses despite the fact that a simple routine should have filtered out such obvious interlopers.

That particular issue was quickly rectified, but it took a bit more digging to get to the bottom of a minor problem with payments.

On two occasions retailers had been credited with a 1p higher commission than they should have been. It's the sort of thing that accountants would get very concerned about, but it was not that important given that all this is merely a test run.

The real challenge will come when we try real people and real money. But at least it will mean a well earned break for Jonah Lomu and the rest of our hardworking, rugby-playing virtual friends.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of rools, a payment service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card.

fields.headline: Ethical index sees UK entrants
fields.standfirst: BG Group and Thames Water rise in the charts, while Procter & Gamble ousts Unilever
fields.trailText: There is one global index which, despite its Dow Jones parentage and the presence of Microsoft, Exxon and other leading American companies at the top of most league tables, is dominated by European rather than US companies.
fields.body:
There is one global index which, despite its Dow Jones parentage and the presence of Microsoft, Exxon and other leading American companies at the top of most league tables, is dominated by European rather than US companies.

The Dow Jones sustainability index, which celebrates its first birthday this week, aims to identify the world's most responsible companies. They are the ones, out of the 2,000 members of the Dow Jones global indices, judged to be ahead on social, environmental and economic criteria.

In the changes to the index which come into effect on Friday two British companies have leapt to the top of their sectors. They are BG Group, soon to be split in two, and Thames Water, which is being acquired by the German group RWE. On the other hand Unilever has been ousted by one of the few US winners - its rival, Procter & Gamble.

Apart from BG and Thames Water, others among the 30 British representatives include recognised environmental leaders such as Anglian Water, BAA, British Airways, BT and Sainsbury.

The analysis by Sustainable Asset Management (SAM), an asset management firm in Switzerland, is not based on individual incidents. The researchers look at strategy and management systems across the three categories of economic, environmental and social impacts. They examine risks and opportunities, looking for firms which are well placed to avoid environmental disasters, for example, and to capitalise on community involvement.

SAM says BG is a clear leader in all three fields. It praises the gas company's thoroughness in environmental management and cites its establishment of the BG Foundation in the social sphere.

Thames Water is praised for its approach to employee health and safety and its communication of environmental targets and policies.

The new league table includes 236 companies from 27 countries, worth a total of $5.5 trillion (£3.8 trillion). The US contributes 51 companies, including Dell and Intel but not Microsoft. In total the Americas constitute almost 44% of the index, marginally less than Europe, with the final 12% coming from Asia. These companies are the top 10% of their respective sectors, according to SAM's research.

The purpose of the index is to give investors a means of buying into the world's sustainable business leaders. But from the investment point of view that is of no use unless they deliver financial returns as well as good social and environmental performance. So far, that is the case.

In its first year the index performed marginally less well than the DJ global index from which it is drawn - 59.2% growth against 60%, but that was mainly because of the weak euro. Calculated over the past five years the sustainable companies' share prices grew 241% against 174% for the global basket. All the other figures are in favour of the new index - nearly 15% return on equity (from less than 10%), higher earnings growth leading to higher price-earnings ratios but also slightly higher dividend yields.

Not that many investors have been attracted so far, however. Only 17 licences to use the index have been taken up to date, all in Europe. In Britain the sole licensee is Bear Stearns, with a capital guarantee note based on the index.

The "best in class" approach - buying the best companies in each sector - is still a fairly novel development from the ethical investment tradition of avoiding poor companies or sectors.

In Britain last year's ethical pension legislation has accelerated interest in positive discrimination, because trustees are keen not to limit the total potential investment population. But the preference of those funds which have addressed ethical issues has been for "engagement" - continuing to invest according to financial criteria but pressing those companies to improve their social and environmental performance.

Mark Mansley of Claros Consulting, who advises on socially responsible investment, said: "I have slightly mixed feelings about it.

"There is no engagement and it amounts to taking an active position on sustainable development and quite a passive position on financial performance."

However, with pension funds slowly coming to terms with the requirement to confront ethical issues, next year's index could see more British takers.

webTitle: Competition report clears the big five

fields.headline: Competition report clears the big five
fields.standfirst: Inquiry into leading supermarket chains rejects government's accusations of rip-off retail culture
fields.trailText: Britain's big five supermarket chains will emerge virtually unscathed from the long-running competition commission inquiry into their market dominance.
fields.body:
Britain's big five supermarket chains will emerge virtually unscathed from the long-running competition commission inquiry into their market dominance.

The report has thrown out a number of the key accusations which sparked the 16-month inquiry, noting that the market is "broadly competitive".

A copy of the report, leaked to the Observer, deflates the "rip-off Britain" tag coined by the government. It concludes that the profits earned by the supermarket chains "could not be considered excessive" and that "overall, excessive prices are not being charged".

Price differentials between Britain and other parts of Europe and the US are attributed to higher land and building costs and the strength of sterling rather than any anti-competitive behaviour.

Neither will the big five - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Morrisons - be forced to dispose of any stores, although it will be tougher for them to build new supermarkets.

Shoppers, the report notes, "showed a high degree of satisfaction" with the service they get. Food prices in real terms declined 9.4% between 1989 and 1998.

The results of the inquiry were passed to ministers in August and are expected to be published by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, within two weeks. It will prove an embarrassment to the government's attempt to make political capital out of "rip-off Britain" by turning itself into a consumer champion.

In several instances where the report does criticise the supermarket chains, it recommends that no action be taken.

The practice of selling items below cost, the report says, acts against the public interest and is damaging to smaller stores. It also takes a dim view of supermarkets charging different prices for the same goods in various parts of the country according to how intense the local competition is.

But in both cases it says there is no practicable way of forcing change.

One supermarket insider last night described the report as "a bit of a damp squib".

The most punitive part of the report recommends that the big five be forced to gain clearance from the office of fair trading before building new superstores. The rule applies to new stores of 1,000 sq metres or more within 15 minutes' drive of one of a grocer's existing stores.

The measure will be introduced to combat worries about local monopolies developing in some parts of the country. It suggests the OFT set up a dedicated unit to deal with such cases.

The report also highlights concerns over the treatment of suppliers and suggests there is a "climate of fear" among suppliers to the big chains. It identified issues including payments for shelf space and forcing suppliers to purchase packaging from certain companies to win commission for the supermarket.

That too, though, has largely been pre-empted by the Institute of Grocery Distribution which, in conjunction with the larger supermarket chains, has already drawn up a voluntary code of practice.

The inquiry will disappoint the many critics of the growing power of the supermarkets, especially farmers who have accused them of squeezing profit margins.

Problems associated with the development of out-of-town superstores are alluded to, including lack of access by low-income groups, transport issues and damage to town centres - but none are attributed to anti-competitive behaviour. It is also critical of certain chains stifling competition by snapping up land on which rivals could build.

fields.headline: Rover 'in talks with Proton'
fields.trailText: Union leaders last night backed moves by John Towers, chairman of the struggling British car-maker MG Rover, to secure a big-league partner to save the Longbridge plant.
fields.body:
Union leaders last night backed moves by John Towers, chairman of the struggling British car-maker MG Rover, to secure a big-league partner to save the Longbridge plant.

Responding to news that Mr Towers was talking to Proton, the Malaysian car-maker, Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering and electrical union, said: "It is the right move and we are in favour of it."

Sir Ken said that Mr Towers had made it clear after rescuing the plant earlier this year that he would be looking for a partnership with a "major producer within 18 months".

The AEEU leader said that while Proton was still a matter of speculation, it was right that Mr Towers was speaking to big companies in the industry on a partnership deal.

"Our bottom line is simple. It is the long-term survival of MG Rover, and a partnership is necessary to meet that goal," Sir Ken said.

MG Rover yesterday confirmed that it was talking to another company on a "collaboration" deal without identifying Proton. It said that discussions centred on plans to replace the mid-range Rover 25 and 45 in 2004.

A spokesman denied that Mr Towers wanted to sell the whole group in two or three years to another car manufacturer.

"We have both signed a confidentiality agreement and we will not say any more until the discussions have come to a conclusion."

The spokesman went on to say that Mr Tower's commitment to the project, a view which is shared by the unions. "This team is not for walking away," he said.

The Phoenix consortium took over the Rover group from BMW in May. Phoenix paid just £10 for the sprawling Longbridge plant when the German car company decided to sell after suffering mounting losses.

Mr Towers rescued the jobs of 7,000 workers at Longbridge with a last-minute bid after days of exhaustive negotiations with BMW, which was accused by the government of failing to keep it fully informed of the crisis facing car production in the West Midlands.

webTitle: Workers given help to find the right balance in life

fields.headline: Workers given help to find the right balance in life
fields.trailText: Up to a quarter of million employees will benefit from a government initiative to help them juggle work and home life more successfully, the Department for Education and Employment is to announce today.
fields.body:
Up to a quarter of million employees will benefit from a government initiative to help them juggle work and home life more successfully, the Department for Education and Employment is to announce today.

The DfEE will provide 69 companies with free expertise from leading management consultants to help them reshape their working practices so that employees can better balance their working and domestic lives.

"Work-life balance is the hot topic for employers and employees alike," said Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities. "We all want to get a life, to spent time with our families, our children and our elderly parents - or just enjoy our hobbies."

The DfEE selected the 69 organisations from more than 180 who applied for to its Work-Life Balance Challenge Fund.

The winners range from large businesses to small charities, and include big names such as Freemans, Unijet, the Bedfordshire police and SmithKline Beecham.

Ms Hodge also announced that the fund would be doubled to £5.5m over the next three years.

"These challenge fund winners have taken a brave step forward in asking for help in identifying ways to improve their employment and working practices," she said.

The Federation of Small Businesses welcomed the move. "At the end of the day the winners will not just be the employers but also their employees," said the FSB's Stephen Alambritis.

Research conducted by one of the successful bidders, Plymouth Citybus, shows that problems fitting shift work around family responsibilities is a large factor causing workers to quit.

The managing director, Jonathan Bayliss, said the firm hoped the consultants' advice would help it reduce the costs of workers handing in their notice.

fields.headline: Fewer firms go bankrupt
fields.trailText: The number of companies going bust in Britain has slowed dramatically, according to new figures out today.
fields.body:
The number of companies going bust in Britain has slowed dramatically, according to new figures out today.

Researchers Dun & Bradstreet say 30,925 businesses failed in the first nine months of this year, down 6.4% on the same time last year.

But the fall over the past three months was 9%, compared with a 3% drop in the first quarter of the year.

"The figures show the benefit of the economic stability we have been seeing over the past 12-18 months," said Phillip Mellor, senior analyst at D&B. "Companies have even got used to coping with the strength of sterling."

Mr Mellor said many start-up companies, which would previously have failed within the first few years of their existence, are now surviving because of the more benign economic climate.

But he sounded a note of warning. "Should we see a slowdown in the economy over the coming months that could cause problems for many of the recent start-ups. When they were founded they were undercapitalised and they are operating on tight margins. They could suffer if things turn down."

The figures show business failures in London declining nearly a fifth, while there were falls of around 10% in the east, south-west and Scotland. But failures in the north-east rose 1% and were static in Wales.

Bankruptcies of small businesses, down 7.3%, are falling at a faster rate than liquidations of larger firms, which declined 5.1% in the last quarter.

webTitle: M&S line loses out to rivals

fields.headline: M&S line loses out to rivals
fields.trailText: It is not only Marks & Spencer's grip on the nation's underwear that it is under threat. A report published yesterday said the high street retailer looks set to be overtaken as Britain's leading seller of children's clothing.
fields.body:
It is not only Marks & Spencer's grip on the nation's underwear that it is under threat. A report published yesterday said the high street retailer looks set to be overtaken as Britain's leading seller of children's clothing.

The report from market research group Verdict identifies Woolworths, Asda own-label George and Next as vying for M&S's top slot.

This latest survey adds to an already bleak picture for the once overwhelmingly popular store.

A sales slump at M&S last year left it with 7% of the British childrenswear market down from 7.9%. Woolworths, in second place, has by contrast grown its share to within 0.2% of M&S -less than £10m difference - in sales.

The main four contenders are separated by is a mere 1.2%, illustrating how competitive the market has become.

Retailers are also con cerned by the increasing sophistication of children who, the report notes, are getting "older" at progressively younger ages.

While Woolworths has expanded its share of childrenswear by taking an increasingly tough stance on pricing, George at Asda has also been gaining at M&S' expense.

Five years ago it had 2.7% of the British childrenswear market. Today it has 6.3%.

Moreover, M&S is not the only traditionally strong retailer of childrenswear experiencing difficulties. Bhs and Mothercare have also suffered.

Bhs and Mothercare have also suffered.

webTitle: Vallance to stay on, says BT

fields.headline: Vallance to stay on, says BT
fields.trailText: BT yesterday denied reports that chairman Sir Iain Vallance would step down before his contract expires at the end of July 2002.
fields.body:
BT yesterday denied reports that chairman Sir Iain Vallance would step down before his contract expires at the end of July 2002.

The company issued an official denial to counter the growing speculation surrounding BT's senior management team. BT is coming under unprecedented levels of criticism from all sides, including investors, rivals, the regulator and government - leading some observers to suggest that changes in the boardroom are becoming inevitable.

Shares in the company closed a further 24p lower at 711p on Friday against the £15.13p peak they reached at the beginning of the year.

Two separate reports yesterday suggested Sir Iain would step down, one saying he would leave in January and the other in July 2001. He has been in the job since 1987.

The company is going through a period of profound change and is in talks with US telecoms firm AT&T about various ways of combining their businesses. It is also expected to announce the flotation of its global wireless division shortly in part to help pay down its £30bn debt mountain.

At home, BT is facing the break up of its local telephone monopoly but has been accused of dragging its heels and obstructing the process.

webTitle: Putin tries to ease Milosevic out

fields.headline: Putin tries to ease Milosevic out
fields.standfirst:
Russia leads international efforts to broker a peaceful handover of power in Yugoslavia

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Kremlin has launched a high-risk - but potentially rewarding - diplomatic initiative to broker a peaceful handover of power from President Slobodan Milosevic to the opposition in Belgrade.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow, Maggie O'Kane in Belgrade and  Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
The Kremlin has launched a high-risk - but potentially rewarding - diplomatic initiative to broker a peaceful handover of power from President Slobodan Milosevic to the opposition in Belgrade.

In a weekend of intensive diplomacy following last week's disputed Yugoslav elections, President Vladimir Putin spoke to President Clinton, the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and the Italian prime minister, Giuliano Amato, about the increasingly isolated Milosevic regime.

For the first time Russia has conceded that the opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, won the poll in the first round. Two senior Russian diplomats arrived in Belgrade yesterday for talks.

Earlier Mr Putin offered to send the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, to Belgrade to defuse the standoff. An influential Russian foreign policy official said that Moscow should mediate in Belgrade, checking all versions of election returns to assess whether a second round runoff scheduled for next Sunday was warranted.

"If it [a runoff] is not needed, it would make sense to discuss the conditions that would ensure the transfer of power," said Vladimir Lukin, a deputy parliament speaker and a former Russian ambassador in Washington. "Russia has a chance to play a very big role in this process."

That seemed to reflect the views of Mr Putin, who appears to be relishing the opportunities afforded to enhance Russian prestige by succeeding in some crisis management which would leave the west in its debt.

The Russian foreign ministry confirmed that Vladimir Chizhov, the Russian envoy to the Balkans, and Alexander Tolkach, a foreign ministry official, were in Belgrade for talks with the Milosevic and Kostunica camps.

Russian media reports suggest that the Kremlin is engaged in a high-risk strategy to edge Mr Milosevic out peacefully, but it appears that Moscow is advising Mr Kostunica not to boycott any runoff.

Rumours have been rife for days that Mr Milosevic could flee to Russia, and that Mr Kostunica may go to Moscow for talks on the crisis with Mr Putin, who is due to leave for a four-day visit to India today.

The key issue would be to organise when Mr Milosevic leaves power. The Yugoslav prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, has said the constitution allows the president to stay until next summer.

This is unacceptable to the opposition, but there may be room for compromise on finding a date which allows Mr Milosevic to stay on for a shorter period or by guaranteeing his security if he resigns immediately.

In Belgrade, Mr Milosevic, continues to ignore internal and international pressures to step down. According to one inside source he expects next Sunday's runoff to go ahead.

Mr Kostunica, a law professor, insists he has already won and such a runoff would be an insult to the voters.

He is trying to unseat Mr Milosevic by legal challenges, international pressure and by persuading Mr Milosevic's allies to desert him. His aim is to corrode Mr Milosevic's powerbase without violence.

"There must be no blood because Serbia is already bleeding," an opposition speaker told a rally in Belgrade on Saturday. "We know you are tired. We know you are fed up and tired of speeches but please tell everyone the general strike begins on Monday at 5am"

Essential services such as hospitals are not expected to be affected by the strike but most of the country is expected to come to a standstill.

webTitle: Court test for new right to life law

fields.headline: Court test for new right to life law
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: This week will see the first right to life case go to the high court after the Human Rights Act comes into force today. Judges are bracing themselves for new challenges across the whole legal landscape as long-established principles of law come under fresh scrutiny.
fields.body:
This week will see the first right to life case go to the high court after the Human Rights Act comes into force today. Judges are bracing themselves for new challenges across the whole legal landscape as long-established principles of law come under fresh scrutiny.

In a three-day hearing due to start on Thursday, the official solicitor may oppose a plea by the families and doctors of two severely brain-damaged patients that they should be allowed to die. Laurence Oates is considering mounting an argument that stopping tube feeding would breach their right to life, guaranteed by Article 2 of the European convention on human rights.

One patient is in a permanent vegetative state (PVS) while the other, though near to PVS, responds to some external stimuli. The courts have sanctioned the withdrawal of tube feeding for around 20 PVS patients and two in near-PVS since the case of the Hillsborough survivor Tony Bland, in 1993.

But the law must be completely reconsidered following the Human Rights Act, which incorporates the European convention on human rights into UK law from today. Article 2 imposes on the state a positive obligation to protect the right to life.

The case shows how profoundly the Human Rights Act may affect precedents laid down by the courts under common law. The common law states that doctors must act in the best interests of their patients, and the House of Lords held in the Bland case that there are circumstances in which death is in the best interests of a vegetative patient with no hope of recovery.

Mr Oates, representing the two unrelated patients, is considering arguing in the two test cases that withdrawing tube feeding would breach their right to life. The three-day hearing will be presided over by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, and could go to the court of appeal and even the House of Lords, to set a precedent for the handling of future PVS cases.

Ben Emmerson QC, a colleague of Cherie Booth QC in the new human rights Matrix chambers, will put the arguments for Mr Oates.

The case originally concerned only the first patient, who has been in PVS for some time after an anaesthetic mishap. But the court agreed to hear the second case at the same time.

That case is more sensitive because the patient, whose brain was deprived of oxygen when she had a heart attack in hospital, is not in full PVS, and she has been in her current state only since last January.

Guidelines lay down that withdrawal of feeding should not usually be considered until a patient been vegetative for at least a year, to rule out any chance of recovery.

But her feeding tube has become blocked and it would require an operation to put it right. Her family and doctors want to let nature take its course, but that would mean death within a few weeks.

In her case, Mr Oates may argue that taking a decision now, rather than replacing the blocked tube and reassessing the situation, would breach Article 6 of the convention by depriving her of a fair hearing in determining her civil rights.

Both families want their loved ones to be allowed to die, and lawyers for the families and doctors are likely to argue that Article 3 of the convention, the ban on inhuman and degrading treatment, and the right to "moral and physical integrity" in Article 8, justify that course of action.

In the Bland case, the House of Lords gave great weight to the indignities the patient was required to undergo during his care, even though he was oblivious to them.

Judges are bracing themselves for a barrage of cases arguing human rights points, both good and bad, from tomorrow.

The civil rights organisation, Liberty, is planning a series of test cases, including an application by a brother and sister, Adam and Joanna Rose, conceived through artificial insemination by sperm donors, who want information about their biological fathers.

Liberty is also defending the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, who will claim that his prosecution under the Official Secrets Act breaches Article 10 of the convention, the right to free speech. Liberty's director, John Wadham, said: "We intend to pursue a series of test cases to ensure that every public authority obeys the new law and respects the rights of all."

webTitle: Kray dies after 35 days of freedom

fields.headline: Kray dies after 35 days of freedom
fields.trailText: Reggie Kray said he hoped to reinvent himself "first as a man and eventually as an author, poet and philosopher."
fields.body:
Reggie Kray said he hoped to reinvent himself "first as a man and eventually as an author, poet and philosopher."

Yet as his life slipped away yesterday, drawn out of him by an incurable bladder cancer that might have killed a less stubborn soul weeks ago, he remained nothing more than the gangster he was in the 1950s and 60s.

Twin of Ronnie, younger brother of Charlie, the last of a family whose "firm" ruled east London with a merciless brutality that was feared, revered and ultimately lionised in a way none of them could have imagined back then.

Perversely, the Krays spawned a legitimate if ghoulish film and book industry that was much more lucrative than any of the protection rackets they had run.

In crude terms, Reggie Kray was the brains of the outfit, and Ronnie the brawn. Reggie was, nevertheless, a vicious killer. He stabbed Jack "the Hat" McVitie to death in a flat in Stoke Newington, north London, and was convicted of murder at the Old Bailey in 1969.

He was sentenced to life imprisonment with a recommendation that he serve not less than 30 years.

Freed from Wayland prison, Norfolk, on August 26 by the home secretary, Jack Straw, on compassionate grounds because of his deteriorating health, he spent his last days in the honeymoon suite at the Beefeater Town House hotel, at Thorpe St Andrew, near Norwich, with his 41-year-old wife Roberta.

Reggie was the only one of the three brothers to die a free man. Ronnie, jailed for life for the murder of George Cornell at the Blind Beggar pub in Mile End Road, died of a heart attack in 1995. Their elder brother, Charlie, died in April aged 73, while in Parkhurst prison for drug offences.

Kray's friends had hoped that Reggie, who was 66, might live for six months following his release, but he rarely had the strength to get out of bed and could not walk without help.

He refused lucrative offers to give a final interview, preferring to spend time with his wife. According to his lawyer, Mark Goldstein, he died peacefully in his sleep.

Although details of the funeral have not been released, Mr Goldstein said it was likely to be "a very big occasion."

The actor Barbara Windsor, whose ex-husband Ronnie Knight was a friend of the Krays, was one of the first to pay tribute. "You have to speak as you find. Charlie and Reggie came to see me after a show. They were charming and polite."

Tony Lambrianou, the man who disposed of McVitie by locking his body in a car and crushing the vehicle into a 3ft sq cube, said Reggie's past should be forgotten. "They were not evil men. Let's get this in perspective here. They done unto those what they would have done to them and this involved other villains. It's not an excuse, that's just facts. The shame was that he did not have a couple of years of proper freedom."

"Dodgy" Dave Courtney, another former gangster, said he was grief-stricken. "It was an outrage that he was kept in for so long. I think the authorities have done themselves no favours by keeping him in for so long. They have lost the support of decent law-abiding people throughout the country, who feel Reggie's sentence was too harsh."

Leonard "Nipper" Read, the officer who trailed the twins and eventually brought them to court, remembers them differently. "They were courteous and always referred to me as Mr Read during interviews. But I was never in any doubt of what they were capable of. They were killers and I was often in fear of my life.

"I find it odd that people think of the Krays as criminal masterminds. They were not clever. If they had been, they would never have been caught."

webTitle: Why humans would be in deep trouble without trees

fields.headline: Wood versus evil
fields.standfirst: Why humans would be in deep trouble without trees
fields.trailText: Why humans would be in deep trouble without trees
fields.body:
Three years ago, in an outburst of Eurotrashness that would have made even Antoine de Caunes arch an eyebrow, Antoine Hurel, managing director of the French-owned train operating company Connex, attacked the English love of trees and the culture of viewing them as "sacred". Hurel's case was essentially one of frustration. Every autumn, leaves of the wrong sort fall on Britain's railway tracks, causing trains to slip, stall and delay commuters. Even more frustrating to this Cartesian train manager is the way the crazy English grumble about said leaves while, most irrationally, rather enjoying this annual joke against themselves.

Three years on, Railtrack has said it will massacre thousands of trees by means of "track-mounted flail machines", to prevent leaf falls along hundreds of miles of tracks. This Pol Pot approach to the problem appears to be an act of wilful adult aggression - and a sad example of how all too many people charged with running the technological trappings of our civilisation see nature as an enemy.

The part played by trees in the rise of architecture and civilisation is something to which our friends at Railtrack and Connex may not have given much thought. Without trees, said some of the great French theorists in the decades leading up to 1789 and the revolution, no architecture. No architecture, no cities, no civilisation.

In 1753 the Abbé Laugier published his Essai sur l'Architecture. The frontispiece depicts the "natural state of architecture": a "primitive hut" that is in fact a classical temple, standing in a forest clearing. The classical temple, said Laugier, was derived from trees. And this makes sense. Although columns later came to represent people in Greek civilisation, they were made initially of tree trunks. The roofs, of course, were made of timbers. Architecture without the tree would have been impossible, both structurally and conceptually.

The fact that so many of the world's cities have grown up stripped of trees is sad, an unthinking reaction to the balance between nature and civilisation. Many of the finest architectural achievements have demonstrated this balance. Think of the great formal gardens of 17th-century France and their glorious avenues; think of the heroic composition of the Champs Elysées and imagine it stripped of its trees. Part of the point is the relationship between the artificial columns of the architecture and the natural columns of the trees.

In France, as in Britain, leaves can be a nuisance in autumn for those who have to sweep them up from the damp pavements, but would the Parisians really have it any other way? Don't the French like their trees too?

There have been those, in the spirit of Connex's Mr Hurel, who have called for the trees that line old French A-roads to be felled, to make driving safer. Perhaps Albert Camus would have agreed in the last few moments of his life before the car in which he was travelling rammed into just such a row of trunks. Yet trees used in an architectural manner are a defining characteristic of the French landscape, just as much as they are part and parcel of Britain's annual leaves-on-the-line comedy act.

Today, despite the number of trees axed in the quest to build more trash housing, junk offices and shopping complexes, architects have tended to become more, not less, sensitive to trees - not just to their plight but to their architectural and symbolic value. In Hungary, Imre Makovecz has made extensive use of trees in his highly animated timber buildings; he refers to these as "building beings". Many of the great timber roofs made by his team of travelling carpenters are held up by trees that retain their branches. Here is Laugier taken to a logical and romantic extreme.

For Makovecz, a deeply religious man, trees symbolise our desire to be a part of the earth while striving for the heavens. So he uses trees extensively in his folkish buildings to celebrate this connection.

Makovecz works at one extreme of architecture. Yet there are many architects across the world who have tried to work trees into their designs, even those intended for the most capitalistic of pursuits. The Ford Foundation in New York, designed by Kevin Roche (born 1922) and John Dinkeloo (1918-81), featured the first truly influential office atrium, a 12-storey jungle of trees that brought green life and delight into the otherwise rational, mechanistic heart of this fine office building. It dates from 1967 and its influence has been incalculable. Even the British parliament's monstrous Portcullis House office block has found room for 12 fig trees, rented at headline-grabbing cost of £30,000 a year.

Now we find architects such as Tadao Ando of Japan planning and executing the planting of tens of thousands of cherry trees in Kobe. This has been a lovely gesture in a city brutalised by the earthquake that destroyed 30% of its buildings five years ago.

In Britain, the Trees for London campaign has blossomed; its aim is to plant trees wherever sensible, possible or delightful. It has the support of many architects. Now is the time to plant as many as Railtrack aims to destroy. As for Mr Hurel, I could say that one day he will meet his Waterloo, but his Connex trains do that daily when not stalled by leaves on the line.

Many of the great timber roofs made by his team of travelling carpenters are held up by trees that retain their branches. Here is Laugier taken to a logical and romantic extreme. For Makovecz, a deeply religious man, trees symbolise our desire to be a part of the earth while striving for the heavens. So he uses trees extensively in his folkish buildings to celebrate this connection. Makovecz works at one extreme of architecture. Yet there are many architects across the world who have tried to work trees into their designs, even those intended for the most capitalistic of pursuits. The Ford Foundation in New York, designed by Kevin Roche (born 1922) and John Dinkeloo (1918-81), featured the first truly influential office atrium, a 12-storey jungle of trees that brought green life and delight into the otherwise rational, mechanistic heart of this fine office building. It dates from 1967 and its influence has been incalculable. Even the British parliament's monstrous Portcullis House office block has found room for 12 fig trees, rented at headline-grabbing cost of £30,000 a year. Now we find architects such as Tadao Ando of Japan planning and executing the planting of tens of thousands of cherry trees in Kobe. This has been a lovely gesture in a city brutalised by the earthquake that destroyed 30% of its buildings five years ago. In Britain, the Trees for London campaign has blossomed; its aim is to plant trees wherever sensible, possible or delightful. It has the support of many architects. Now is the time to plant as many as Railtrack aims to destroy. As for Mr Hurel, I could say that one day he will meet his Waterloo, but his Connex trains do that daily when not stalled by leaves on the line.

webTitle: This morning UK law sees the biggest change in more than 300 years. Here is why

fields.headline: This morning UK law sees the biggest change in more than 300 years. Here is why
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act has been described as the biggest change to UK law since the 1688 Bill of Rights. For the first time, individuals will have a range of over-arching civil rights enforceable in all British courts.
fields.body:
The Human Rights Act has been described as the biggest change to UK law since the 1688 Bill of Rights. For the first time, individuals will have a range of over-arching civil rights enforceable in all British courts.

The act incorporates into UK law the European Convention on Human Rights, which could be invoked up to now only by exhausting the appeals process in the UK and then starting again at the human rights court in Strasbourg. Public authorities and those exercising public functions - including government departments, local councils, schools, hospitals, prisons, police, crown prosecution service and the courts - will be obliged to respect all rights laid down by the European convention.

The new law will give greater power to the judges, who will not be able to strike down statutes passed by the UK parliament, but will have to interpret them so as to be compatible with the convention. If this is impossible, a judge may declare a law incompatible with the convention. Parliament will have new fast-track procedure by which such laws can be amended.

The European Convention on Human Rights:

 Right to Life

1. Everyone's right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in the execution of a sentence of a court after his conviction of a crime for which this penalty is provided by law.

2. Deprivation of life shall not be regarded as inflicted in contravention of this Article when it results from the use of force which is no more than absolutely necessary:

(a) in defence of any person from unlawful violence;

(b) in order to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent the escape of a person lawfully detained;

(c) in action lawfully taken for the purpose of quelling a riot or insurrection.

 Prohibition of torture

No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

 Right to a fair trial

1. In the determination of his civil rights or of any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. Judgment shall be pronounced publicly but the press and public may be excluded from all or part of the trial in the interest of morals, public order or national security in a democratic society, where the interests of juveniles or the protection of the private life of the parties so require, or to the extent strictly necessary in the opinion of the court in special circumstances where publicity would prejudice the interests of justice.

2. Everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law.

3. Everyone charged with a criminal offence has these minimum rights:

(a) to be informed promptly, in a language which he understands and in detail, of the nature and cause of the accusation against him;

(b) to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence;

(c) to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his own choosing or, if he has not sufficient means to pay for legal assistance, to be given it free when the interests of justice so require;

(d) to examine or have examined witnesses against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him

 Right to respect for private and family life

1. Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life, his home and his correspondence.

2. There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well-being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.

 Freedom of thought, conscience and religion

1. Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; this right includes freedom to change his religion or belief and freedom, either alone or in community with others and in public or private, to manifest his religion or belief, in worship, teaching, practice and observance.

2. Freedom to manifest one's religion or beliefs shall be subject only to such limitations as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of public safety, for the protection of public order, health or morals, or for the protection of the rights of others.

Freedom of expression

1. Everyone has the right to freedom of expression. This right shall include freedom to hold opinions and to receive and impart information and ideas without interference by public authority and regardless of frontiers.

2. The exercise of these freedoms, since it carries with it duties and responsibilities, may be subject to such formalities, conditions, restrictions or penalties as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society, in the interests of national security, territorial integrity or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, for the protection of the rights of others, for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence, or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary.

 Freedom of assembly and association

1. Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and to freedom of association with others, including the right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests.

2. No restrictions shall be placed on the exercise of these rights other than such as are prescribed by law and are necessary ... in the interests of national security or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime ... or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.

 Right to marry

Men and women of marriageable age have the right to marry and to found a family, according to the national laws governing the exercise of this right.

 Prohibition of discrimination

The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status.

fields.headline: Anti-heroin fungus 'may be misused'
fields.trailText: A novel weapon in the global war against heroin, a fungus that destroys opium poppies, might lead to an ecological disaster, scientists fear.
fields.body:
A novel weapon in the global war against heroin, a fungus that destroys opium poppies, might lead to an ecological disaster, scientists fear.

Britain and the United States are funding researchers in Uzbekistan to work on the biological weapon, which they claim could lay waste to millions of opium poppies in central Asia.

But a BBC Panorama investigation tonight will allege that the safety of the project, set up in 1998 under the United Nations drug control programme and overseen by a British scientist, is causing concern.

Confidential documents from the UN, seen by Panorama, show the organisation has anxieties about the safety of the project. The documents highlight the possibility that once the fungus is spread on poppy fields, such as those of neighbouring Afghanistan, the source of 90% of Britain's illegal heroin, it might be difficult to contain.

There is also concern that the fungus may mutate, or be used on food crops in offensive biological warfare.

In field trials the virulent strain of Pleospora papaveracea, described as "aggressive, infectious, self-propagating and deadly", caused opium poppies to wilt and die while apparently leaving neighbouring crops unharmed.

At the institute of plant genetics in Tashkent, Panorama discovered that some of the fungus had been prepared with talc and silica gel to make it capable of being sprayed from a plane.

The Uzbek scientists at the institute, a former germ warfare plant, estimated the fungus would be ready for regular use within three years.

Abdukarimov Abdusattar, the molecular biologist in charge of the institute, admitted there was a possibility of dangerous mutation of the fungus.

He also revealed that he planned to use X-rays to encourage mutations in an attempt to produce even more virulent forms - a form of genetic engineering with unpredictable results.

The programme suggests that, by opening a Pandora's box of genetic modifications such as this, the project would "touch the edge of biological warfare".

Environmentalists warned of the risk of an ecological catastrophe if Pleospora were used.

A British plant pathologist , Paul Rogers,said: "The fungus sounds like a silver bullet, but it could easily become a poisoned chalice.

"Once you develop a technology to spread plant diseases intentionally you are developing a technology which could easily be misused by bad people against legitimate food crops."

He added: "If things drift into the private sector, then who are the paymasters? You are simply opening things out for a wider spread of this kind of technology."

Professor Rogers also pointed out that there would be a further risk if the fungus were used to wipe out illicit drug harvests: "Drug cartels could themselves acquire the technology and in revenge attacks use a form of agricultural terrorism against Britain or the US."

He urged caution: "I think that Britain should be extremely careful about a project like this. While it appears to offer a great prospect, the dangers are very considerable. I think that it is a path that you tread with great care and great caution."

Despite such warnings, tests on the microbe have proved so successful that Mike Greaves, a British microbiologist overseeing the project for the UN, said that he believed it could provide the key to reducing the illicit drug harvests of the world.

"I love it. It's actually working. Many research projects don't work, and you get rather frustrated. This one is working on all levels," he said.

Commenting on the risks, he added: "We are still working on the safety aspects to be absolutely sure. You will appreciate that, in any sphere, whether it's science or public transport or any aspect of human life, you can never say that we are 100% safe."

 Britain's Secret War on Drugs, tonight at 10pm on BBC1.

webTitle: End of the affair that set pulses racing

fields.headline: End of the affair that set pulses racing
fields.standfirst:
Everybody agrees it was the greatest games ever - and that it is unlikely to happen again

Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: Like lovers forced to part, the Olympic movement and Sydney shared one long, lingering embrace last night before saying farewell. This has only been a 16-day romance, but it has been a peculiarly intense one. And both sides sense that life is never going to be this good again.
fields.byline: Matthew Engel at the closing ceremony
fields.body:
Like lovers forced to part, the Olympic movement and Sydney shared one long, lingering embrace last night before saying farewell. This has only been a 16-day romance, but it has been a peculiarly intense one. And both sides sense that life is never going to be this good again.

Just before the flame went out on the 2000 games at the Olympic stadium, Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, paid tribute to Sydney for producing "the best games ever". This is the traditional accolade handed out at closing ceremonies - until 1996, when Samaranch pointedly withheld it as a response to the multiple cock-ups of Atlanta.

This time he added: "They could not have been better" and thanked Michael Knight, the New South Wales Olympics minister, for producing "a perfect organisation".

This summed up a mood of almost rampant amity and self-congratulation. Only the American TV network, NBC, stuffed out of sight by the huge time difference, has failed to relish these games. An Olympics in which everything seemed to work concluded in the same vein with an impressive and enjoyable (if under-edited) closing ceremony, climaxing with a fireworks display centred on the Harbour bridge. Naturally, this was sensational - even for a city that was already considered the global pyrotechnic HQ.

The success of Sydney, however, creates problems for future Olympic hosts. Concern about the progress in Athens, the venue for 2004, is already starting to move from concern to alarm, if not yet panic. There are even far-fetched rumours that Manchester, which is building quasi-Olympic facilities for the 2002 Commonwealth Games, could be asked to step in. With Beijing favourite to get the 2008 games, the chances of anyone reproducing Sydney's mix of efficiency and enjoyment in the near future seem close to zero.

Sydney even managed to incorporate self-deprecation. "Roy and HG", the TV hosts who made Fatso the Fat-arsed Wombat a more successful Olympic icon than any of the official souvenirs, were brought in to the closing ceremony. They shared the occasion with the handful of well-known Australians who had not been chosen for opening night. These included Paul Hogan, Kylie Minogue, Greg Norman and about 60 Sydney drag queens. In one very nice touch, John Wing was introduced. In 1956, he was a schoolboy who wrote to the organisers and suggested that the closing ceremony should consist of informal mingling rather than formal marching. This idea was accepted and has been a tradition ever since.

Sense of achievement

The sense of achievement and well-being extended to corners no one could have expected in advance. The final day of competition produced two more gold medals for Britain: from the heavyweight boxer, Audley Harrison, and Stephanie Cook in the inaugural women's modern pentathlon event. This took the total to 11, equal to the combined haul at the three previous Olympics: five at both Barcelona and Seoul, plus one at Atlanta four years ago.

By the end, Britain's Olympians could hardly stop themselves. The marathon runner Jon Brown, who did not even rate a mention in pre-race speculation, came within seven seconds of a bronze medal to wrap up the country's most successful games in 80 years.

The 11 golds outstripped the total of nine from the Chariots of Fire Olympics of 1924 and rank behind only the 14 at Antwerp in 1920 and 56 in 1908, when Britain had home advantage and most of the potential rivals had the decency not to turn up.

There were also 10 silver and seven bronze this time. This is the first time since 1908 that Britain has put aside its historic attachment to finishing second and won more gold than silver. British officials are astounded at their team's performance. "We didn't have a target for gold medals here," said Simon Clegg, the British chef de mission. "Some of us had private hopes but, whatever they were, we've exceeded them."

These figures will be seen as an overwhelming justification of the improved funding for British sport since the introduction of national lottery money, and will lead to pressure for more handouts. "We're just seeing the roots of recovery," said Clegg. "British sport has been under-funded for years, but that's changing."

Nonetheless, it is impossible to imagine Britain ever matching Australia in organisational terms. Visitors have been left awestruck by the efficiency and national effort that have characterised the Sydney games. Even the rail system has been almost faultless. The idea that British train companies - in 2004 or 2040 - could move the numbers that have been shifted here every day is laughable.

But much of the secret has been in the efforts of the volunteers, whose efficiency, courtesy, knowledge and kindness have been a breathtaking feature of these games. One of the Sydney Sunday papers listed them all yesterday under the heading 47,000 HEROES, from Aadil, Naseem to Zylstra, Warren. Until this week, Athens planned to have only paid staff. Adverts for helpers are now being placed.

For many, the sense of being part of this great enterprise may well never be re-created. Counselling organisations are expecting a surge in calls from people who feel suddenly bereft at the loss of purpose. Sports psychologist George Shilling warned: "The effect could be like the end of the second world war. There's the high emotion, then the realisation that we've got to get on with life."

Gains and losses

The real gains and losses for Sydney will take years to assess. The Australian Financial Review predicts that the Olympics will have virtually no effect on the New South Wales economy, and that the frenzy of Olympic investment has merely replaced other activity.

But the Olympics can transform countries as well as cities. The games changed the global perceptions of Japan (1964) and South Korea (1988). Los Angeles (1984) helped the US regain the confidence it lost in Vietnam. Barcelona (1992) was turned into a place that attracted global admiration.

On the other hand, Montreal (1976) was almost bankrupted, and the world is still laughing at Atlanta (1996). One suspects Sydney's mood of glorious self-confidence that has made these games such a triumph will sustain Australia for years.

This took the total to 11, equal to the combined haul at the three previous Olympics: five at both Barcelona and Seoul, plus one at Atlanta four years ago. By the end, Britain's Olympians could hardly stop themselves. The marathon runner Jon Brown, who did not even rate a mention in pre-race speculation, came within seven seconds of a bronze medal to wrap up the country's most successful games in 80 years. The 11 golds outstripped the total of nine from the Chariots of Fire Olympics of 1924 and rank behind only the 14 at Antwerp in 1920 and 56 in 1908, when Britain had home advantage and most of the potential rivals had the decency not to turn up. There were also 10 silver and seven bronze this time. This is the first time since 1908 that Britain has put aside its historic attachment to finishing second and won more gold than silver. British officials are astounded at their team's performance. "We didn't have a target for gold medals here," said Simon Clegg, the British chef de mission. "Some of us had private hopes but, whatever they were, we've exceeded them." These figures will be seen as an overwhelming justification of the improved funding for British sport since the introduction of national lottery money, and will lead to pressure for more handouts. "We're just seeing the roots of recovery," said Clegg. "British sport has been under-funded for years, but that's changing." Nonetheless, it is impossible to imagine Britain ever matching Australia in organisational terms. Visitors have been left awestruck by the efficiency and national effort that have characterised the Sydney games. Even the rail system has been almost faultless. The idea that British train companies - in 2004 or 2040 - could move the numbers that have been shifted here every day is laughable. But much of the secret has been in the efforts of the volunteers, whose efficiency, courtesy, knowledge and kindness have been a breathtaking feature of these games. One of the Sydney Sunday papers listed them all yesterday under the heading 47,000 HEROES, from Aadil, Naseem to Zylstra, Warren. Until this week, Athens planned to have only paid staff. Adverts for helpers are now being placed. For many, the sense of being part of this great enterprise may well never be re-created. Counselling organisations are expecting a surge in calls from people who feel suddenly bereft at the loss of purpose. Sports psychologist George Shilling warned: "The effect could be like the end of the second world war. There's the high emotion, then the realisation that we've got to get on with life." Gains and losses The real gains and losses for Sydney will take years to assess. The Australian Financial Review predicts that the Olympics will have virtually no effect on the New South Wales economy, and that the frenzy of Olympic investment has merely replaced other activity. But the Olympics can transform countries as well as cities. The games changed the global perceptions of Japan (1964) and South Korea (1988). Los Angeles (1984) helped the US regain the confidence it lost in Vietnam. Barcelona (1992) was turned into a place that attracted global admiration. On the other hand, Montreal (1976) was almost bankrupted, and the world is still laughing at Atlanta (1996). One suspects Sydney's mood of glorious self-confidence that has made these games such a triumph will sustain Australia for years.
