fields.headline: Who needs stars?
fields.standfirst: Welsh National Opera produces amazing productions on a shoestring.  Stephen Moss  talks to some of those responsible
fields.trailText: Welsh National Opera produces amazing productions on a shoestring. Stephen Moss talks to some of those responsible
fields.body:
'Theatre is like making love," says opera director Moshe Leiser. "If you have a preconceived idea and don't have to think before you do it, it takes a lot of the pleasure away. The wonderful thing about making love is that you let things happen."

Leiser and directorial partner Patrice Caurier are currently making things happen in Welsh National Opera's new production of Gluck's Orpheus and Eurydice, which opens in Cardiff tonight. They will also be directing Rossini's La Cenerentola at Covent Garden over Christmas.

Leiser, a Belgian, and Caurier, who is French, have worked together for the past 18 years, in the sort of producer partnership that is rare in opera. They have struck up a close relationship with Welsh National Opera, producing both Fidelio and an award-winningly claustrophobic Carmen in 1997. Their approach is similar to that underpinning WNO: long rehearsal periods, a commitment to ensemble acting, and a suspicion of megastars who fly in just before a performance and unpack their role along with their toothbrush.

Leiser, who is dark, feisty and highly articulate, says that he could never work in those conditions, no matter how great the star. "There are a lot of producers whose province is to make images, and that's their only concern. In that case the star can come, he will probably know his job and it will work. The problem is that it's like having a painting that has nothing but one wonderful colour in it. That's not a good painting."

Since WNO could not afford the star's fee anyway, the question does not arise. In effect, the company makes a virtue of necessity and gets fine singers who may not be household names to give strong performances in an integrated show.

"We believe in opera as music theatre," says WNO's general manager, Anthony Freud. "That is only possible on the basis of an intensive preparation period. The people who work with us do so because they want to take part in a preparation period of that length and quality." Each production is rehearsed for six weeks, is premiered in Cardiff and then goes on the road for two months or more - to Oxford, Southampton, Liverpool, Bristol, Birmingham and the other towns that WNO has an obligation to serve under the terms of its Arts Council funding.

In recent years that intensity has paid off, with critical plaudits, numerous awards - including an Olivier for Richard Jones's production of Hansel and Gretel - and rave reviews for Jones's recent The Queen of Spades. The latter, along with Orpheus and Eurydice and Carmen, makes up the autumn programme: large-scale Tchaikovsky, small-scale Gluck and a popular revival. That balance, says Freud, is all-important in terms of both production costs and box office: Carmen is a sure-fire winner, whereas Gluck may not be.

"Orpheus is high-risk compared with, say, a revival of Madam Butterfly," says Freud, "but we lose vitality and validity if we are forced to retrench artistically into a corner from which we can only mount an unvarying diet of the most popular operas. It was important for us to mount a production of Orpheus and Eurydice for the first time in our history."

Freud says, without making a song and dance of it, that WNO is less well funded than the London houses and that funding in real terms has been eroded over the past few years. But he is full of praise for the original Arts Council plan, dating back to the 1970s, that gave regional opera companies catchment areas to provide with quality work. WNO has a potential audience of 12m across Wales and a large swathe of England, and though the company is proud of its Welsh base, its touring function and its appeal in England are critical too. "Touring is the reason for our existence," says Freud, "and when we take Orpheus on the road the vast majority of people will be seeing it for the first time."

Orpheus and Eurydice is being conducted by the early music specialist Paul McCreesh, who will be making his debut in a fully staged opera. I attended a rehearsal in Cardiff and was intrigued by the way Caurier and Leiser, both of whom read music, gather the singers round the piano and let the expression of feelings evolve from a close reading of the score. Weren't they, by offering suggestions on how passages should be sung, trespassing on the conductor's territory?

"I'm a relative novice to staged opera production," says McCreesh, "but I know enough to know that their approach is unusual. To find producers who can read music is relatively rare. It's a joy, and I'm not saying that to be sycophantic. It means that if you have a dispute it comes from a state of interpretation and knowledge, rather than the producer saying, 'I have this conception.'"

"The work we do around the piano is to find an interpretation that reflects what is happening to the characters," says Leiser. "At the beginning we know more or less what world we want to travel in, but the paths and the turns we take will be discovered along with the conductor and the singers. We don't have closed ideas. As you work on a piece, you feel when you are inside the music. As much as we produce the piece, the piece produces itself."

As Caurier and Leiser listen to the singers, they seem to share their suffering. Caurier has an odd habit of plucking his stomach as if he is in pain, while Leiser leaps into Eurydice's arms to show Orpheus precisely how to cradle her. Their working relationship must by now be second nature and they seem to communicate by occasional interjections and facial expressions rather than exact directions. What is most marked is the precision with which they approach the music: the score is being taken apart note by note and the characters' motives interrogated.

"I wouldn't say that somebody who cannot read the score is not a good director," says Leiser. "There are plenty of directors who cannot read a score. But when we are working we find that 80% of the staging is musical interpretation. It must be organic. Opera only exists when music and theatre are in sympathy."

"An artistic experience is an exchange," adds Caurier. "If an exchange doesn't exist..." He doesn't complete the sentence, stalled either by his English, which is less fluent than Leiser's, or by the vision of dictatorial divas and uncooperative conductors. WNO, happily, is far too down to earth to accommodate either of those preening species, which is probably why its recent record speaks, or rather sings, for itself.

 Orpheus and Eurydice is in rep at the New Theatre, Cardiff (029-2087 8889), till October 11, then tours.

webTitle: I may be old, but I don't live in California

fields.headline: California dreaming
fields.trailText: Another of my birthdays has just whizzed by - the 58th - and I notice that my skin is hanging in curtains and my moles are multiplying like a bumper crop of mushrooms. But why be glum? At least I don't live in California.
fields.body:
Another of my birthdays has just whizzed by - the 58th - and I notice that my skin is hanging in curtains and my moles are multiplying like a bumper crop of mushrooms. But why be glum? At least I don't live in California. "You really have to look good over there or you shouldn't go out at all," says Fielding, sounding crushed. He has just holidayed in Santa Barbara, where the pressure is on to keep one's body in fabulous condition.

Fielding's chances of doing this are almost nil. For a start, everything he's eaten for the past 40 years has been toxic, said the Californians strictly, and by rights he should be dead. From now on he must eat not three large meals a day but 17 small ones, and drink water more or less non-stop.

Of course he did go out. He had slap-up meals of lettuce and strawberries, and met rather odd people at parties who talked about "fat checks" and introduced him to their personal trainers. Meanwhile, out on the pavements, sun-tanned mothers roller-skated along with buggies, the sun shone, cheery persons jogged around and whizzed in and out of juice bars.

fields.headline: Sisterly love and hate
fields.standfirst: Anita Chaudhuri  on the pros and cons of rivalry between celebrity siblings
fields.trailText: Anita Chaudhuri  on the pros and cons of rivalry between celebrity siblings
fields.body:
Be honest. Would you agree, even if someone offered you a million pounds and a date with Jude Law, to come back in a future life as Louise Adams, the younger, less fabulous sister of Posh Spice? Possibly not. Adams appears to be the latest casualty of Celebrity Sister, a game for two or more players that is guaranteed to leave the loser looking foolish and humiliated. A few days ago Adams attended a fashion awards ceremony with Posh, dressed in a similar outfit and identical hair extensions, a move which caused one gleeful gossip columnist to nickname her Posh Twice.

Alas, the case for Adams as a person in her own right is not convincing. In recent months her ultra-famous sister has bought her a £480,000 house, paid for her two-year-old daughter Liberty to attend the same nursery school as Brooklyn Beckham and encouraged her to get a job as a reporter on Sky TV.

Yet despite her sister's efforts to look after her best interests, one can't help feeling for Adams. There can be few states more ignoble than finding yourself for ever the wannabe, especially if you have been trying to live up to your role model since the day they were spitting puréed apple in your face from their high chair.

One small comfort for her must be the knowledge that she is not alone. In recent weeks celebrity siblings have dominated the pages of the Hello! circuit. Karen Hurley, the utterly anonymous sister of Liz, was last week photographed attending a film premiere with her sister's ex-boyfriend Hugh Grant; Gemma Kidd took to the catwalk with her supermodel sister Jodie in aid of a breast cancer charity; the Corrs sisters become more terrifyingly identical with every album they release; and the antics of All Saints sisters Nicole and Natalie Appleton and their matching rock-star boyfriends are never more than a headline away.

Not all celeb siblings are as gruesome. Actress Sadie Frost often waxes lyrical about her childhood as the eldest of five sisters, likening it to Louisa May Alcott's Little Women. If there's a common denominator among these high-profile sisters and the sisters we know and love in real life, then it must surely be this inexplicable desire to forge an identity and a sense of belonging through emulating our nearest and dearest.

Personally, I am not in the habit of consciously copying the clothes, make-up and hairstyles of anyone, be they celebrities or close friends - except that is, those of my sister. She is four years younger than me, so it's not a habit that can be attributed to the old "leader, follower" dynamic. All I know is that in her company I have a glorious compulsion to become a copycat. The most common question during our conversations is not "How are you?" or "How are Ayr United?" but "What other colours does it come in?". This is perhaps a regression to the days when our mother used to dress us in matching psychedelic outfits.

Professor Anne Woollett, a psychologist at the University of East London, has a theory about this. "Siblings are sufficiently like one another to be impressed by each other. You'll see them wearing something and you automatically think, 'Oh, I might look good in that too,' in a way that you wouldn't with, say, your mother." Woollett has conducted research into family ties, and one finding was that adult sisters kept in far closer contact with one another than brothers.

"That might well be because men aren't as good at keeping in touch. And although there have been suggestions that male siblings are more competitive with one another, I've noticed a competitive edge among sisters too."

Susan Van Scoyoc, a psychologist who runs the Women's Practice therapeutic centre in Essex, says that many of the women she sees in therapy are dealing with issues relating to sibling rivalry. "In dysfunctional families, sisters will often be rivals for success and attention. Sisters are often pigeonholed as the pretty one or the clever one, when the chances are that each sister is striving desperately to be both of those things. The Freudian theory is that they're vying for daddy's attention, and those rivalries run deep."

Culturally, sisterhood has ever been perceived as one of biology's most mesmerising tricks. When sisters fall out, or when one is seen to be eclipsed by the success of another, the world waits with bated breath to hear the tale. Hilary du Pre's account of growing up in the shadow of world class cellist Jacqueline was compelling because anyone with a sibling could to some extent imagine the extent of her pain.

Other accounts are more crazed, but no less enthralling. In 1941, Joan Fontaine found herself being nominated for the same Oscar as her sister Olivia de Havilland, the latter being the favourite to win. When Joan was announced as the winner, a classic childhood regression kicked in. "All the animus we'd felt towards each other as children, the hair pullings, the savage wrestling matches, the time Olivia fractured my collarbone, all came rushing back in kaleidoscopic imagery. My paralysis was total. I felt Olivia would spring across the table and grab me by the hair. I felt age four, being confronted by my older sister." Olivia didn't speak to her for 10 years.

"Children, vis-à-vis each other, have enormous power," explains Penelope Farmer, editor of Sisters, a new anthology published by Penguin which celebrates female siblings from Virginia Woolf and Vanessa Bell to Simone de Beauvoir and her doll-like sister Poupette. "And childhood is a Kafkaesque world of arbitrary judgments and penalties, of enigmatic pronouncements and doom-filled confusion which sisters have the power to add to and invoke, and which equally they have the power to explain, to ease."

Tracing the roots of sibling rivalry can be fascinating. Take the case of Margaret Drabble, who was far more famous than her sister AS Byatt until the latter won the Booker prize for Possession. Byatt even wrote a novel The Game about two sisters who were novelists and how one of them destroyed the other by writing a book about her.

"To pretend that sisters or brothers love each other is just rubbish," says Drabble. "They are always fighting. What annoys me is the idea that Antonia and I should be lovey-dovey. Of course there was competition between us when we were children, which we've tried to grow out of. We were pitted against each other, by my mother, largely. Any sign of intelligence was praised, any interest in girly things ignored."

To anyone who is blessed with a sister, this last point is the most revealing. No wonder they don't get along. The greatest pleasure in having a sister is having someone with whom you share a common history of girlhood, with whom you have a collective memory of dressing up in your mother's glittery evening slippers, making clothes for Sasha dolls and later of battling for possession of Miners eyeshadow in Disco Silver. It is hard to imagine having a sister and not sharing those bonds, for though they may sound more trivial than the rigorous intellectual games of the Byatt/Drabble childhood, they serve as a valuable compass for playing at being girls together well into adult life.

fields.headline: A fashion moment
fields.standfirst: Piling on the glamour in Milan
fields.trailText: Will the Rich Bitch make it down to the beach? That's the question that will be answered at Milan fashion week which got under way yesterday.
fields.body:
Will the Rich Bitch make it down to the beach? That's the question that will be answered at Milan fashion week which got under way yesterday.

The bourgeois look - so popular this autumn - may well be eclipsed by the "next big thing" before summer hits us. Fashion has that sneaky habit of dashing off somewhere else just when we think we've caught up. So will spring see a move towards ultra modern simplicity? Or a return to Boho?

Not in Milan it won't. The Italians are having far too much fun from "flash" chic to turn their backs on it quite yet.

It all sounds like a licence to print money. And that irony has not been lost on Dolce & Gabbana. For their D&G diffusion label, gold coins and dollar bills were scattered across chiffon and silk eveningwear. As usual the first two days of Milan are dominated by the diffusion lines of the mega-brands. These collections are less expensive and often more fun than the mainline collection, but they also act as a good indicator of the designer's direction.

You did not even need to go to the D&G spring/summer 2001 collection to know that they would keep piling the glamour on - it's what they do well. For the last 15 years they have been glamming up the fashion, rock and pop world with their inimitable OTT style. This season was no different. Houndstooth check in stark black and white mixed with tons of leopard print - does that sound glitzy enough for you? Now imagine those prints on Lycra micro minis and you start to really get the feel. Add Madonna's latest single as soundtrack (stetson and all), a jewelled bodice, a pink feather boa and some thigh high white boots and you have got it. Not an easy look eh? But wicked all the same.

Most desirable were the printed silk evening dresses. Comic book superheroes and neon Vegas signs flashed across silk dresses, underwired in customary Dolce & Gabbana style, with a thigh high split which revealed a leopard lining. Most undesirable were the leggings. Please, please not yet.

But since the 80s have been forgiven for their gaucheness, D&G is smack bang in the middle of a fashion moment.

It will be the mainline collections of Gucci, Prada, and Dolce & Gabbana which decide the fate of the Rich Bitch. Will she ditch all the gold chains and status handbags for a younger funkier look? Or will she take to the beach in a shaved mink bikini?

webTitle: Is it the thought that counts - or the amount you fork out?

fields.headline: 'It's just what I always wanted'
fields.standfirst: As Michael Douglas gives Catherine Zeta Jones a £60,000 birthday necklace,  Dea Birkett  asks, is it the thought that counts - or the amount you fork out?
fields.trailText: As Michael Douglas gives Catherine Zeta Jones a £60,000 birthday necklace,  Dea Birkett  asks, is it the thought that counts - or the amount you fork out?
fields.body:
Hers was a Persian rug. His was a pair of cut-glass decanters in the shape of footballs. They were tokens of their love for each other. Yet, when it came to the divorce proceedings of this archetypal Mr and Mrs, their ownership was in dispute. It might have been her birthday, but he meant the rug for their house. She didn't intend the decanters, given on their second anniversary, to be for his use alone. Every exchange of presents between partners has a meaning beyond and below the pretty paper. There's no such thing as a gift without strings tied all around it.

The politics of present-giving were unwrapped last week when Catherine Zeta Jones gave her beloved Michael Douglas a framed photo of his sons for his 56th birthday. "It was very intimate," she said; "Meanie Happy Returns," bleated one tabloid. For Jones's 31st on the same day (would he have even remembered it if it wasn't, I wonder?), Douglas gave her a £60,000 sapphire and diamond necklace. Unlike the thoughtful family snap, this extravagance met with widespread approval. It showed he cared.

Women's gifts to men, like Jones's, display thought and affection. Men often express emotion through an excess of money, knowing few other ways to show it. Former Playmate Anna Nicole Smith spent $2m of her 89-year-old Texan husband's fortune in one shopping trip to the jeweller. "He bought me just about anything I wanted," Smith said, after winning £300m contesting his will. This she interpreted as taking care of her, "and I loved him for it". In this, as in so many other, more ordinary cases, it seems a bargain was struck.

Not all exchanges are so calculated. I once saw John Major at the cosmetics counter of Dickens and Jones. It was just before Christmas, and he was buying some make-up for Norma, I presumed. Although he had a bodyguard with him, I felt I was witnessing an intimate moment in the former prime minister's marriage. Not many men in late middle-age venture into a department store to buy their wife's favourite face cream; few would know what it was.

A gift can reveal your intimacy. But it can also display your ignorance. I was shocked when my boyfriend bought me a heavy Aran jumper, which I would not - and never have - worn. It made me question how much he really knew me, to buy something so obviously out of character.

But perhaps my boyfriend knew I would never wear anything like that, and only longed for me to be a country kind of woman. Men buy gifts to transform their women. Sexy lingerie is only the most obvious example. More than 70% of women's razors are bought by men. It is not uncommon for husbands to give their wives facelifts for Christmas.

Yet still, a present is marketed as proof that you care. "Tell someone you love them," says the advertisement as a delighted woman holds up a dozen red roses delivered in the post. "Diamonds are for ever" is written along a woman's slender, bejewelled neck while a male finger massages her collarbone. It's true, every gift does bear a message, but not necessarily the message intended.

Personally, a knock on the door from Interflora always rouses my suspicions; it's only guilty men who give flowers. A mistress is far more likely to be the recipient of gifts than a wife, and a wife is more likely to get gifts when her husband has a mistress. When an old boyfriend bought me a bunch of lilies, I knew bad news was on the way. He must have done something that would make me mad. The flowers turned out to be a softener before I learned what had happened the weekend before in the back of my car.

Our relationship with gifts wasn't always so fraught. Our very first presents as children, from our parents, are unquestioningly adored, simply because they give them to us, and we love them. But then, at some point, our relationship to beneficence changes. We become critical. Doesn't my mum know I'd never wear something like that? Doesn't dad know I'm too old for a doll?

By the time we're young adults, gift-giving is a battleground between our definition of ourselves and how other people would like us to be. We despise an aunt for giving us lacy handkerchiefs when we're so obviously the paper-tissue kind of girl. Everything we're given is treated with suspicion and subjected to scrutiny - until, that is, we get the first gift from our own child. What ever it is - homemade birthday card or lump of Play-Doh pretending to be a bowl - we cherish it.

But gifts between the sexes never recover that innocence. They are forever a field of deceit. Every exchange is loaded, every tear of the wrapping paper an agonising step closer to what will inevitably disappoint. Already, as the present is being unwrapped, the smile is fixed. We will say we've always wanted one, whatever it is. We will say, as necklace-sporting Catherine told Michael at their joint birthday party, "It's beautiful."

fields.headline: No: 1731
fields.standfirst: Paul Newman
fields.trailText: Paul Newman
fields.body:
Age: 75.

Job description: Screen legend.

Appearance: Why, a composite and older version of all those Hollywood male leads (Cruise, Costner, Travolta, et al) who have modelled their careers on his.

Distinguishing features: Like you needed to ask. Newman is so fed up with people stopping him in the street and asking him to remove his shades that he has taken to replying: "I would take my glasses off, except my pants fall down."

Something many of his fans wouldn't mind at all, presumably. Indeed. According to a survey in the 80s, Newman featured in the sexual fantasies of 46% of Italian housewives. But that's proportional representation for you.

Still, I suppose his salad days are over. The golden era of The Hustler, Hud and Butch Cassidy may be gone, but actually these are his salad days.

Really? Well, his vinaigrette days, anyway. Paul's range of supermarket foods - Newman's Own balsamic vinaigrette, Say Cheese pasta sauce and Picture Show popcorn - is booming, much to the delight of the left-liberal charities to whom he donates all the profits.

Still, from making cinema history to politically correct grocery products - bit of a comedown, isn't it? The famously self-deprecating Newman was heard regretting the day his vinaigrette outgrossed his movies. But he hasn't forsaken the silver screen for the salad bowl entirely: his latest film, Where the Money Is, is out on Friday.

Surely you jest? Yes. Actually, she's plotting a bank heist. Although, come to think of it, the opportunities for cross-promotion are endless.

For example? Message in a Bottle of Vinaigrette; Somebody Up There Likes Pasta Sauce; Butch Cassidy and the Sun-dried Tomato...

webTitle: Protestant severely injured by loyalist booby trap bomb

fields.headline: Protestant severely injured by loyalist booby trap bomb
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A man suffered severe leg injuries yesterday when he triggered a loyalist bomb while digging for fishing bait near Larne in Co Antrim. He was in a serious condition last night.
fields.body:
A man suffered severe leg injuries yesterday when he triggered a loyalist bomb while digging for fishing bait near Larne in Co Antrim. He was in a serious condition last night.

The victim, aged 29 and understood to be a Protestant, is thought to have stumbled on a tripwire. He was with two Catholics, one of whom digs for bait there at that time every Sunday, and it appears he was the intended target. Loyalists have carried out dozens of attacks on Catholics in Larne in recent years, including on the family of their intended target.

Police called it an indiscriminate attack that could have led to widespread injury. Children often frequent the area at Magheramourne, near Larne.

The victim was treated at a local hospital and transferred to the Royal Victoria hospital, Belfast, for surgery. His mother, who asked not to be named, said he was in deep shock and semi-conscious.

Sean Neeson, leader of the Alliance Party, who represents east Antrim in the assembly, said: "I obviously condemn this incident. It appears to be a blatant attempt to carry out a sectarian murder. There is an urgent need for a major inves tigation into loyalist and sectarian activities in the Larne area."

The incident came fewer than 48 hours after a Catholic man was shot dead in a pub in Magherafelt, Co Londonderry. There are suspicions of IRA involvement in what appears to be a drugs related execution. The RUC said yesterday it had ruled out a sectarian motive.

Two gunmen in wigs singled out Patrick Gerard Quinn, 32, as he drank at 11pm in the Depot bar and shot him three times in the head and body. The IRA is thought to have six months earlier ordered him to leave nearby Coalisland over alleged drugs dealing.

If IRA involvement were proved, it would rock the peace process. But, although police believed the IRA was responsible for the murder in similar circumstances of Ed McCoy, a Catholic and drugs dealer aged 30, five months ago outside Belfast, it was unable to bring charges.

Another threat to the power-sharing executive loomed as Jeffrey Donaldson, an Ulster Unionist MP opposed to the Good Friday agreement, gave his strongest hint yet he was considering a challenge to his party leader, David Trimble. Mr Donaldson insisted: "I will not shirk my responsibility."

He is to seek a special meet ing of the Ulster Unionist Council, the party's ruling body, to demand that Mr Trimble and his three ministers withdraw from the executive because of the lack of progress over IRA decommissioning. He could expect to succeed, which could lead to Mr Trimble's demise.

There is speculation that the independent weapons inspectors, Cyril Ramaphosa and Martti Ahtisaari, will return to Ireland this week to re-examine the IRA dumps they saw in June, in a compromise allowing devolution to be restored in May after the executive was suspended three months earlier.

They may also be invited to see two more dumps, and the government would hope that development soothes Mr Trimble's troubles, acute since the party's defeat in the south Antrim byelection 11 days ago.

fields.headline: Women in the house
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee writes about "The hell of women's working lives in parliament" (Time for a sex change, September 29). This is plain silly. The hours are difficult. And the media can be nasty. But we women MPs enjoy salaries, perks and privileges that the average working woman can only dream of. Hell is a single mother struggling to bring up her children on benefits. Not a woman MP on £46,000 a year.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee writes about "The hell of women's working lives in parliament" (Time for a sex change, September 29). This is plain silly. The hours are difficult. And the media can be nasty. But we women MPs enjoy salaries, perks and privileges that the average working woman can only dream of. Hell is a single mother struggling to bring up her children on benefits. Not a woman MP on £46,000 a year.

Polly Toynbee is also wrong to say that Speaker Betty Boothroyd MP dislikes women. In 13 years in parliament I have never seen a shred of this alleged dislike. Betty was a strong defender of the rights of backbench MPs - including women. She carried out her duties as Speaker with intelligence, independence and style. And consequently did an enormous amount for the reputation of women politicians both here and internationally.

I have campaigned for more women MPs all my political career. I was saddened to find that more new male MPs had the courage to vote against the government's cut in benefit to single-parent mothers than did my new female colleagues. This may shed some light on why ordinary Labour party members are now less willing to select women parliamentary candidates.
Diane Abbott MP
ABBOTTDJ@parliament.uk

 Polly Toynbee bemoans the plight of women in politics. She highlights their lack of sustained influence on policy, process and outcome. I agree that this results in disadvantage to democracy.

There is a simple solution: reduce the number of parliamentary constituencies by half; each constituency to elect one woman and one man; each voter to have two votes, one for a man, one for a woman.

The result would be a parliament most closely reflecting the structure of our society. This could also save a lot of hot air over proportional representation. How much more proportional need it be than 50:50, men and women?
Sandy Carmichael
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk sandy.c@rmichael.org.uk

fields.headline: Lottery threat to charity millions
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Charities could lose out on millions of pounds of funding becuase of the uncertainty over who will be awarded the next licence to run the national lottery.
fields.body:
Charities could lose out on millions of pounds of funding becuase of the uncertainty over who will be awarded the next licence to run the national lottery.

Camelot, which currently runs the game, said at the weekend it was likely to make another legal challenge against the national lottery commission if at the end of this month the licence is awarded to Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery.

An additional legal action is likely to delay the award of the licence even further, threatening to leave the lottery with no company in a position to run it after October next year.

Dianne Thompson, Camelot's chief executive designate, wrote to the commission last week seeking assurances that it would act fairly, but a spokeswoman said none had yet been given.

"We are in an invidious position," the spokeswoman said. "We don't have confidence in the process, and the statements they have made so far don't suggest they have an open mind ...

"If at the end of the month we feel they haven't been fair, then we will likely go to judicial review again. Either way there is a big prospect of legal challenge, because if we win the licence the People's Lottery would want to know: did the commission bend over backwards in order not to appear biased against us?"

The commission announced in August that neither bid could win the licence as it stood but said it would enter into exclusive talks with the People's Lottery to allay certain outstanding concerns.

In the high court, Camelot won the right to be given a month to answer concerns about its bid. Mr Justice Richards condemned the commission's decision as "conspicuously unfair". The commission confirmed yester day that it has dropped its legal advisers, the official Treasury solicitors.

The process is already behind schedule, and further stalling could delay the start of the new game. The People's Lottery is expected to need at least 12 months to get up and running if it wins. A survey of independent newsagents yesterday found two-thirds concerned that the new terminals would not be ready in time.

Camelot is due to hold talks with the commission to extend its licence for a month or two beyond October in case of delay, but the spokeswoman warned yesterday that the uncertainty meant many staff were seeking jobs elsewhere. There are also problems with renewing supply contracts.

Charities fear that an interruption to the lottery could leave them out of pocket. Estimates have put the loss to good causes at £4m for each 24 hours the lottery does not run.

A commission spokesman played down the worries: "Camelot indicated in court they were willing to use their best endeavours to come to terms with us to bridge whatever gap there was. Nobody wants there to be a hiatus."

However, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said last week that the commission should consider its position.

Ms Thompson said in her letter to the commission's chairwoman, Dame Helena Shovelton: "We cannot identify any acknowledgment on the part of the ... commission that it has done anything wrong. Rather than this, there has been created the impression that [it] seeks to lay blame for the aberrant behaviour at the door of its legal advisers.

"All this leaves Camelot with the inescapable conclusion that it has been and will continue to be subjected to intolerable bias."

webTitle: Letters: Still counting your votes on the future of the euro

fields.headline: Still counting your votes on the future of the euro
fields.trailText: The Eurosceptics say - most of the time - that we should not be influenced by Johnny Foreigner. But now, suddenly, those same people say we should be following the views of a small nation hundreds of miles away where fewer people than the population of Torquay swung a referendum (Sceptics handed pole position, September 30).
fields.body:
The Eurosceptics say - most of the time - that we should not be influenced by Johnny Foreigner. But now, suddenly, those same people say we should be following the views of a small nation hundreds of miles away where fewer people than the population of Torquay swung a referendum (Sceptics handed pole position, September 30).

Meanwhile, a country with a population larger than ours, with an economy more closely aligned to ours, is enjoying huge benefits for its exporters while ours struggle. But, of course, they are German - so we should not take any notice of them. Paul Walter
Newbury, Berks
walterp@ntlworld.com

 You are quite right (Leader, September 30). Voters will remember Black Wednesday. They will also remember that this was caused by membership of the exchange rate mechanism, which necessitated an interest rate that did not fit our domestic economy. The difference between ERM and monetary union is that we could escape from ERM. From monetary union there is no escape.
Alan Sykes
Garstang, Lancs
shepus@goldserve.net

 It is not in the least surprising that the Danes have said no to the euro (Ministers hit brakes over euro, September 30). When things are going well, people want to stick with what they've got, but when things start going wrong it's a different kettle of fish.

Take our own experience with the ERM. Does anyone believe that Mrs Thatcher would have had any truck with such an idea if there had been another way out of our dire financial position? Of course she wouldn't, but with mortgage rates stuck at 15% and unemployment rising beyond 3m, she had to swallow hard and take us in at the punitively high rate demanded by the other members.

Under the Tories the same disasters would occur. Short-term fix and hope that something will turn up is their motto. Note William Hague's answer to the fuel crisis: cave in to the blockades and knock 3p off petrol. It would work for about a week, then the petrol companies would put 3p back on.

If the Tories ever got their hands on our affairs again we'd soon be knocking on Europe's door and begging for admittance to the euro at any price, without any chance of a referendum.
John Crampton
Nottingham
john@crampton63.freeserve.co.uk

 I get an embarrassed feeling that runs up and down my spine whenever I recall that I voted against staying in the EEC back in 1976. I can't believe I made such a stupid, Little Englander decision. I have a feeling in a few years time, when the euro is up and running properly and is challenging the dollar, the young Danish people in your photograph (Buoyant but facing a sea of troubles, September 30) will have the same acute feeling of embarrassment.
Joe Phillips
Bingham, Notts
country.joe@ntlworld.com

webTitle: Letters: The jury is still out

fields.headline: The jury is still out
fields.trailText: Having observed the irrational and illogical behaviour of the British public during the recent fuel "crisis", I would have no confidence that 12 upstanding members drawn from this group would reach a sane decision were I ever to come before a jury (Lords reject Straw jury bill again, September 29). The loudest voice would likely be the greatest influence.

The loudest voice would likely be the greatest influence.
Patricia Rowan-Robinson
Ross on Wye

 Did I really hear Jeffrey Archer claim that the concept for his play, where the audience pronounces the accused innocent or guilty, was unique (Archer rewrites play to strengthen prosecution, September 30) Back in to my amateur dramatic days I recall Night of January 16th, by Ayn Rand, and the fun we had selecting our jury from the audience, while hoping our cast would remember the words of the two available endings. She got off every time, by the way.
Derek Haseldine
Burgess Hill, West Sussex deltyaar.5@virgin.ne

fields.headline: Unfinished business
fields.trailText: I am grateful to Jeff Rooker MP (Letters, September 30) for correcting my shorthand (Letters, September 29). We should indeed commemorate what Audrey Wise and he achieved in linking tax allowances and retail prices under the last Labour government. We should restate the principle of universal benefits, index-linked to prices or earnings, whichever rises more.
fields.body:
I am grateful to Jeff Rooker MP (Letters, September 30) for correcting my shorthand (Letters, September 29). We should indeed commemorate what Audrey Wise and he achieved in linking tax allowances and retail prices under the last Labour government. We should restate the principle of universal benefits, index-linked to prices or earnings, whichever rises more.

Sadly, this government's spokespersons do not now apply this to pensions. The contribution of older people - and older Labour policies - should not be written out of history. They are still relevant today.
John Nicholson
Chief executive, UK Public Health Association john@ukpha.org.uk

 Tom Kenny (Letters, September 30) expresses astonishment that the police have no arrangement with the immigration services to deport criminals.

In fact, provided that the police or crown prosecution service remember to serve the correct notice, criminal courts have the power to recommend that an overseas national be deported as part of the sentence for most offences. The recommendation is then passed to the Home Office for action.

What Kenny does not explain is why his non-British burglar should face additional penalties in comparison to a similar British criminal.
Paul Ward
Brighton PaulWard123@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: How our medals measure up

fields.headline: How our medals measure up
fields.trailText: Over the last two weeks our athletes have, win or lose, inspired everyone with their Olympian efforts against the stiffest world-class competition - efforts that have been funded to the tune of £80m over the last three years (Olympians must answer the money question, September 30).
fields.body:
Over the last two weeks our athletes have, win or lose, inspired everyone with their Olympian efforts against the stiffest world-class competition - efforts that have been funded to the tune of £80m over the last three years (Olympians must answer the money question, September 30).

Compare this with over £800m spent on the dreadful Millennium Dome. Unlike the dome, which is short-term and London-centric, funding for athletes often leads to benefits for everyone, such as improved swimming facilities.

To obtain funding, our teams were asked to set targets for medals to be won (who can possibly predict that?) and those that have failed face possible cuts. This marketplace philosophy is now endemic and frequently applied inappropriately where long-term cultivation is needed. It is a sure way of withering fruit on the vine. UK Sport should be asking why France did so well.
Martin Whittle
Sheffield

 Congratulations to our Olympics team on the best medal haul since Noah was a lad. But before we get carried away with the achievements we must recognise that in the medals table we only came fifth out of the EU member states.

We have done well, particularly in sports where funding has been targeted and those outside the mainstream. Even our athletics medals were in sideline events rather than the blue riband ones, and it may well be that we should nurture these sidelines rather than put resources into competition with America. We must cherry-pick our events rather than fail in those that now seem beyond us, only supporting exceptional talents in those sports.

We can win and enjoy future games with continued lottery funding, but let us target our funds (even if the sports concerned are not thought of as good television) rather than use a scatter-gun.
Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex brirobinson@lineone.net

 It is impossible to compare standards in sport. The medals table is different when seen against populations; it is even more different when seen against facilities and opportunities. Some countries, like Sudan and Ethiopia, have perhaps only one athletics track, one indoor sports hall and one real swimming pool in the whole country.

We seem to win in sports which have the best machinery - bikes, canoes, boats and horses. A form of sports fascism will intensify this with the rich sports getting richer and the poor, poorer. At the same time we will not compete properly in those global sports - based on participation numbers - where comparisons could be made: football, basketball, volleyball, handball and running. Team sports therefore, have a great importance to the majority in world sport - Cameroon's victory being a case in point.
Don Anthony
Honorary president, English Volleyball Association

 Remember the days when we were told that throwing money at problems didn't work? Now that the lie has been given to this by the achievements of our competitors in Sydney what next? Music, maths, science and sport in schools would be my choice.
Michael J Rennie
Dundee amrennie@netscapeonline.co.uk

 To suggest that "gymnasts have failed miserably" in spite of lottery funding is simply not true. Last year the women's team qualified for the first time to send a full team to the Olympics, and an unprecedented three gymnasts - the maximum allowed from any one country - qualified for the all-round competition.

This is something for British gymnastics to be proud of and build on. Overturning the stranglehold of the Russians, Romanians and Chinese will not happen overnight.
Becky Warren and Paul Fairweather
Bristol r.c.warren@tesco.net

 More money requires to be put into the grassroots of sport at school and club level. As a club coach and treasurer I spend too much of my time fund raising (car boot sales, sponsored throws, bag packing at supermarkets, etc) when I should be coaching. Pay qualified coaches to take classes after school and society will reap the benefits with a healthier and more focused youth.
Jim Longmuir
Cluarankwai Judo Club, Kilmarnock

 A British yachtsman is acclaimed after winning his gold medal not by sailing faster but by using blocking tactics to slow his opponent. It's a good job the situation wasn't reversed or the newspapers would be full of "Johnny Foreigner's dirty tricks".
T Hall
Manchester tdhall@onmail.co.uk

 I have just watched the closing ceremony of the Sydney Olympics. The aerial ballet on stilts was quite impressive, but I saw it at the dome first.
John You
Harlow jmy@harlow.co.uk

fields.headline: Back the right bills
fields.standfirst: The right to roam must take priority
fields.trailText: The kitchens of the House of Lords have already anticipated the demands that all-night sittings make on their service. Extra supplies of black puddings have been ordered to ensure that there is an adequate breakfast supply for the country landowners, who begin their battles against the right to roam in the chamber tomorrow.
fields.body:
The kitchens of the House of Lords have already anticipated the demands that all-night sittings make on their service. Extra supplies of black puddings have been ordered to ensure that there is an adequate breakfast supply for the country landowners, who begin their battles against the right to roam in the chamber tomorrow.

The end of a parliamentary session approaches. The log jam of bills in the Lords is even bigger than normal. Hence their "overspill session" began last week, while the Commons is not due to return until October 23, when it will elect a new Speaker. Ministers, as we reported last week, are already planning to put back the state opening of the new session of parliament to reduce the risk of the loss of this session's bills from lack of parliamentary time.

One bill already looks lost. Last week the Lords rejected, for the second time this session, moves by the government to restrict thousands of defendants' rights to a jury trial. Under the proposals defendants who are charged with middle ranking offences, such as theft or burglary, would no longer be able to opt for a jury trial in the crown court. They would be heard by magistrates instead, saving the Treasury an estimated £128m and reducing court delays. It was not just Liberal Democrat and Conservative peers opposing the move, but also Labour members, some even appointed by Mr Blair himself. Helena Kennedy, the human rights lawyer, was one Labour member damning the bill for its "erosion of justice which will do enormous damage to the reputation of the criminal justice system". Ministers have one last option. They could invoke the 1911 Parliament Act, which allows the lower house to override the objection of peers when repeated a second time. But this has only been used three times since the second world war. Lady Kennedy rightly advised ministers to desist, to avoid being accused of ministerial arrogance. Many Labour MPs will privately be celebrating this defeat.

Ministers need to reserve their energies for defending their more positive reforms, such as the freedom of information and countryside bills. The FoI bill is no radical charter, but better a one-toothed watchdog than no watchdog at all. The countryside bill is much more progressive with its new right to roam and greater protection for sites of scientific interest. These advances will need to be defended with vigour.

webTitle: Coal miners pull plug on Serbian power

fields.headline: Coal miners pull plug on Serbian power
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Workers in Serbia's most powerful industry have swung against President Slobodan Milosevic, threatening to throttle the electricity system and plunge the entire country into darkness.
fields.body:
Workers in Serbia's most powerful industry have swung against President Slobodan Milosevic, threatening to throttle the electricity system and plunge the entire country into darkness.

The 7,500 miners at the huge Kolubera open cast mine, 40 miles south of Belgrade, went on strike at the weekend in support of the opposition challenger, Vojislav Kostunica.

Mr Kostunica claims outright victory against Mr Milosevic in the Yugoslav presidential poll on September 24. Mr Milosevic insists that a runoff is needed.

A countrywide campaign of strikes and civil disobedience is due to start at dawn today, aimed at forcing Mr Milosevic to stand down, but the miners at Kolubera stayed away from work yesterday. Many of the other 900 workers at the complex are expected to join the boycott today.

"Kolubera is the single most powerful industrial weapon in the whole country. It is the biggest giant," said Milovan Rankovic, from the Serbian electrical industry union.

Serbian ministers including the energy minister, Slobodan Tomovic, held urgent meetings with strike leaders yesterday while industry officials attempted to persuade the workers to call off the action.

One mineworker said the director of coal at the Kolubera complex, Milovan Zunic, had threatened to expel strikers, threatening that "they would kick us out with the help of police and then bring people from Kosovo to work instead".

Police tried to enter one of the complex's pits yesterday, apparently aiming to end the strike, but were stopped by workers, a member of the strike committee said.

"Two police jeeps and three patrol cars tried to enter the area of Tamnava pit," Nikola Simic said by telephone. "But all the workers who were there stopped them coming in."

Kolubera provides the coal for the Obrenovac thermonuclear electricity station, which provides power for Belgrade and the surrounding region.

The miners' support is a significant gain for Mr Kostunica's Democratic Opposition of Serbia bloc. In the past the region of Lazarevac, where Kolubera is based, was a stronghold of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party of Serbia.

"If Kolubera goes on strike, the electrical system for the whole of Serbia is damaged," Mr Rankovic said. "But people in positions of power in this country have to accept responsibility."

Dragan Pantic, a 41-year-old coal worker, was defiant. "We are not going to give up. Look at what I've got after 19 years here," he said, indicating his worn-out shoes. He earns 600 dinar (about £100) a month.

"Support is huge. The election was a referendum against Slobodan Milosevic. It is possible that strikebreakers will come in. It is possible that they could make us sign that we will not strike. Yesterday we were all threatened," he said.

Another coal worker, Goran Djordjevic, 46, said: "I think this time Milosevic will go. People are ready. There's a lot of readiness here and all around Serbia to make it happen. The regime knows that Kolubera is dangerous for them politically and because of the electrical power system."

The extent of the coal stored at Obrenovac is not known. Experts suggest that an all-out strike at Kolubera could hit power supplies across Serbia within a week.

 President Milosevic's son, Marco, visited his opponents' headquarters at the weekend, and warned opposition activists that his father was still in power and had no intention of leaving, an activist said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hundreds of followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement marked China's national day yesterday with huge protests in Tiananmen Square, witnesses said.
fields.body:
Chinese break up sect protest

Hundreds of followers of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement marked China's national day yesterday with huge protests in Tiananmen Square, witnesses said.

Police detained several hundred members of the sect, kicking, punching and pulling them by the hair as they herded them on to buses after the protests broke out.
Reuters, Beijing

Flood victims fight for food

Troops guarded relief supplies in flood-ravaged areas of eastern India yesterday after a mob of 2,000 hungry villagers surrounded local officials at Chandpara, near the Bangladesh border.

Officials, police and soldiers quickly arranged for food to pacify the people. The worst floods in 22 years have left 758 dead and 200 missing in the state of West Bengal.
Reuters, Chandpara

Seven killed by Jeep gunmen

Russian police were hunting two men yesterday suspected of killing seven people in two attacks.

Three policemen and two bystanders were killed on Saturday when the driver and passenger of a Jeep opened fire with automatic weapons at a roadblock 190 miles north-east of Moscow, a police spokesman said. Several hours later, a policeman spotted the suspects and was killed, along with a local resident, in a gunfight.
Reuters, Moscow

It's a boy for Timorese leader

East Timor's independence leader, Jose Alexandre "Xanana" Gusmao, and his Australian wife, Kirsty Sword, have had their first child, a son. Mr Gusmao was present at a Dili hospital for the birth of Alexandre Sword-Gusmao. He has two sons and a daughter by a previous marriage and another relationship.
AP, Dili

fields.headline: 65 Greek boats fail safety test
fields.trailText: Another vessel sank in the Aegean sea shortly after midnight yesterday, hours after Greece confined 65 ferries and cruise ships to port for failing to meet safety standards.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll and  Michael Howard  in Athens
fields.body:
Another vessel sank in the Aegean sea shortly after midnight yesterday, hours after Greece confined 65 ferries and cruise ships to port for failing to meet safety standards.

An American tourist died after Zeus III, a chartered yacht with 38 people on board, hit a rock off the island of Naxos, seven miles from where the Express Samina ran aground on Tuesday. Richard Idhe, 82, of Ohio, is thought to have suffered a heart attack.

The death toll from the Express Samina rose to 79 with the discovery of two corpses in the wreck's bar. More bodies are feared to be inside the ferry's car deck.

The sinking of the Zeus III brought to four the number of incidents involving Greek passenger boats in less than a week. The ferry Rodos, carrying 575 passengers, suffered engine trouble and made an emergency stop at Syros on Friday. Hours earlier the Express Artemis ran aground near Naxos with 1,081 passengers on board. No one was hurt in either incident.

In an attempt to shore up the credibility of Greece's merchant fleet, the government yesterday suspended the operating licences of 56 ageing ferries and nine cruise ships. Their sailing permits will be revoked permanently unless they are upgraded to meet EU safety requirements within 20 days. The EU has asked Greece to provide a detailed report on the Express Samina disaster within a month.

Politicians, unions and the media have been pressing the government to end the monopoly of Minoan Lines, whose subsidiary, Minoan Flying Dolphins, was involved in three of the week's accidents. Fury at the company escalated into a firebomb attack yesterday on its office in Athens.

The Express Samina's captain and three of the crew appeared before prosecutors yesterday to face charges of manslaughter, violating maritime rules and abandoning the ship before all passengers had left.

Captain Vassilis Yannakis, his first officer and two other crew members started giving testimony before an investigating magistrate on Syros. Capt Yannakis said in a statement: "As the captain of the sunken ship, I feel shattered emotionally and psychologically. I feel deep grief for the loss of life."

Blanket charges of manslaughter are likely to become more specific during the hearing, expected to resume today.

The Greek media reported that the captain and his first officer, Anastasios Psychoyos, had left the trainee captain, Yannis Patilas, 22, alone on the bridge. After losing control in gale-force winds, he is thought to have called Mr Psychoyos, who arrived too late to avert tragedy. A seaman, Panayotis Kasdaglis, is the fourth to face charges.

webTitle: Turkish drought worsens regional water row

fields.headline: Turkish drought worsens regional water row
fields.standfirst: Iraq and Syria say new dams threaten supply
fields.trailText: After the driest summer in 20 years, Turkish officials are warning that they cannot supply Syria with all the water it wants from the Euphrates and Tigres rivers. The announcement will cause concern in the Middle East, where water is one of the most sensitive strategic issues.
fields.body:
After the driest summer in 20 years, Turkish officials are warning that they cannot supply Syria with all the water it wants from the Euphrates and Tigres rivers. The announcement will cause concern in the Middle East, where water is one of the most sensitive strategic issues.

Under an informal agreement, Syria is supposed to receive 500 cubic metres of water per second from the two rivers as they cross the border from Turkey. This month, however, the average flow has been only 160 cubic metres per second, and next month it could be even less.

The water levels in Turkish reservoirs have become dangerously low, and Turkey is bracing for a winter of severe energy shortages. The head of the state water authority, Dogan Altinbilek, has said that the amount of water Turkey can send across the border will depend on rainfall in the next few months.

Syria and Iraq, which is also downstream from Turkey, complain that Ankara's ambitious programme of dam-building on the Euphrates and the Tigres is a threat to their water supply. Turkey, however, insists that the shortages have nothing to do with the dams, which officials in Ankara say have improved the situation.

"Syria would have received only about 50 cubic metres [per second] if there had been no dams on the rivers," Mr Altinbilek said.

Water has been a contentious issue between Turkey and its neighbours for years. Sporadic talks on the issue have failed to reach any formal agreement.

Turkey insists that there is more than enough water in the two rivers for all three countries, but it claims both Syria and Iraq waste supplies because of inefficient water management and poor agricultural techniques. In turn, Damascus and Baghdad accuse Turkey of trying to dictate terms.

The lack of an agreement on water sharing has been one of the main points emphasised by opponents in Britain of the proposed Ilisu dam, which would be one of the biggest dams in the region.

The British government is still considering whether to grant Balfour Beatty export credit guarantees worth £200m to build the dam on the Tigres, a few miles north of the Syrian border. Current signs are that the plan has run into serious difficulties.

If the drought intensifies, Turkey's use of water on the two most important rivers in the region will come under even closer scrutiny. Some strategic analysts have predicted that water, rather than oil or land, could be the spark which ignites a future war in the Middle East.

 A court last week acquitted a Turkish journalist who had been charged with insulting the military in her banned book on the Kurdish rebel war.

The case was seen as a test of Ankara's intentions to improve its poor human rights record. Amnesty International called the verdict "a step forward for freedom of expression", but said the trial should "never have taken place".

fields.bodyText: After the driest summer in 20 years, Turkish officials are warning that they cannot supply Syria with all the water it wants from the Euphrates and Tigres rivers. The announcement will cause concern in the Middle East, where water is one of the most sensitive strategic issues. Under an informal agreement, Syria is supposed to receive 500 cubic metres of water per second from the two rivers as they cross the border from Turkey. This month, however, the average flow has been only 160 cubic metres per second, and next month it could be even less. The water levels in Turkish reservoirs have become dangerously low, and Turkey is bracing for a winter of severe energy shortages. Syria and Iraq, which is also downstream from Turkey, complain that Ankara's ambitious programme of dam-building on the Euphrates and the Tigres is a threat to their water supply. Turkey, however, insists that the shortages have nothing to do with the dams, which officials in Ankara say have improved the situation. fields.headline: New complaint over missing embryos
fields.trailText: Detectives will this week attempt to speak to the scientist at the centre of the missing embryos scandal after a couple made a formal complaint about their treatment, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives will this week attempt to speak to the scientist at the centre of the missing embryos scandal after a couple made a formal complaint about their treatment, it emerged yesterday.

Police spent Friday interviewing staff at the Hampshire Clinic in Basingstoke, where an internal investigation has begun into how frozen embryos of women undergoing fertility treatment were lost.

The clinic said that it has called in detectives but sources involved in the investigation confirmed that the police had also been approached by the unnamed couple.

Embryologist Paul Fielding, 33, of Whitchurch, Hampshire, has been suspended from work at the North Hampshire Hospital since it emerged that embryos at the hospital and the private clinic, where he was contracted to do work, have gone missing.

It is alleged that Mr Fielding, who has not been seen at his home since the scandal broke, may be responsible for acci dentally destroying the embryos and then trying to cover up for his error. It is thought that the detectives are trying to contact him through his solicitor.

A spokeswoman, Carole Friend, confirmed that the police have been to the clinic. She said the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority is also investigating.

Up to 40 patients at the clinic and hospital are understood to be involved in the scare, and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has ordered the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to prepare an urgent report.

Dozens of women are understood to have contacted a confidential helpline over fears that their babies are not biologically theirs, or that their embryos may have been implanted in other women.

Mothers who have had babies since undergoing treatment at the two centres are to be offered DNA tests to prove their babies are their own. Some women have been told they must start their fertility treatment again because of errors in records.

webTitle: Use over 50s or economy will fail, businesses warned

fields.headline: Use over 50s or economy will fail, businesses warned
fields.trailText: The British economy will fail if it does not make better use of the skills and wisdom of the over 50s, according to a report published today by the Industrial Society.
fields.body:
The British economy will fail if it does not make better use of the skills and wisdom of the over 50s, according to a report published today by the Industrial Society.

It presents evidence from the dot.com sector to show that even youthful start-up companies in the new technology industries have started looking for older workers to provide the experience and strategic vision needed for survival.

"Declining birth rates mean that employers are going to have to become more creative if they want to access the knowledge workers they need. And that means abandoning the lazy prejudice of age discrimination," said the society, an independent thinktank specialising in the world of work.

By 2020 the number of working people under 50 will have dropped by 2m, while the number over 50 will have increased by 2m.

"By 2020 ... employers looking to their traditional source of labour - young workers - will find that the spring is running dry," the report said.

Fortunately, the generation now passing 50 were not willing to take on the traditional behaviour patterns of old age. They accounted for 80% of the nation's wealth, enjoyed better health and were more inclined than the heavily mortgaged parents of young children to take on new challenges and adapt to new ways of working. This made them "highly effective new economy workers".

The report found the grey revolution was already well under way. The over 50s were returning to work faster than the rest of the population as demand for their skill ratcheted up.

In the past year the employment rate for women aged 50 and over increased at almost three times the rate for the workforce as a whole.

In the last four years, the Australian economy has created 360,000 full-time jobs and three-quarters went to workers aged 45 and over.

The Industrial Society identified five key skills that businesses need from older workers:

 Warhorses.

The elders most in demand by the dot.com companies are seasoned campaigners with experience of previous economic cycles. One study showed that new businesses set up by entrepreneurs in their early 50s were twice as likely to survive as businesses started by people in their early 20s, illustrating the value of experience in a new set-up.

 Trusted guides.

Consumers looking for guides through the chaos of a competitive market place tended to trust age and experience over youth and enthusiasm. For example, the Nationwide building society employed older mortgage advisers since it found buyers preferred taking advice from people who were more likely to own their own home.

 Networkers.

Companies trying to build relationships abroad needed older people's networking skills. For example, firms trading in Asia where respect for age was important found they got on better by fielding older representatives.

 Connectors.

Organisations relying more on freelancers and contract workers needed team builders, mentors and connectors to create a sense of partnership between people and organisations, even in chaotic times. Older people were better at providing this organisational glue.

 Strategists.

Businesses needed someone to stand above the expanding sea of information to focus on longer term goals. According to venture capitalists, start-up firms were beginning to recognise the need for older people to bring their strategic vision.

Charlotte Thorne, author of the report, said: "Society and pressure groups have traditionally seen ageing as a time of loss and vulnerability ... What businesses are really after is wisdom, and that puts older workers in pole position."

Some sectors of the economy were slow, however, to adapt to the trend. In the past 20 years the proportion of men between 50 and 65 who were not working doubled. And a third of people between 50 and the state retirement age do not work.

The society said the government should take a lead by scrapping compulsory retirement at 60 for civil servants. "Nineteenth century concepts of retirement have no place in the new economy."

Formal retirement ages should be abandoned and rules changed for occupational pension schemes to make it easier for older people to work flexibly and take on part time work if they wish.

 Margaret Hodge, the equal opportunities minister, last night announced the first 69 winners of a government competition to encourage a better balance between work and life. Organisations ranging from big business to small charities will get free consultancy to help them to introduce flexible working and improved productivity.

Ms Hodge said: "We all want to get a life, to spend time with our families, our children or our elderly parents or just to enjoy our hobbies."

webTitle: Glastonbury in doubt after Danish deaths

fields.headline: Glastonbury in doubt after Danish deaths
fields.standfirst: 100,000 fans without tickets got into Britain's longest-running festival this year. Now fears about crowd safety are threatening its future
fields.trailText: The future of the Glastonbury festival is in doubt after the deaths of nine fans at its Danish equivalent, Roskilde, and the overcrowding which jeopardised safety at this year's event.
fields.body:
The future of the Glastonbury festival is in doubt after the deaths of nine fans at its Danish equivalent, Roskilde, and the overcrowding which jeopardised safety at this year's event.

This summer Britain's longest-running rock festival was swamped by an estimated 100,000 illegal entrants who jumped the fence or sneaked in to join 80,000 ticket holders and 20,000 performers and staff.

The deaths of nine young men who were trampled by the crowd at Roskilde festival near Copenhagen put safety at open air gigs under the microscope.

Michael Eavis, who has been organising the Glastonbury festival on his farm near Pilton, Somerset, for three decades, is intent on winning the public relations battle and two weeks ago unveiled a 20ft high "super-wall" aimed at deterring fence-jumpers.

But he faces an uphill struggle to convince the local authority, Mendip district council, which could refuse the festival a licence.

A source on the council's regulatory board said: "Of the 100,000 extra people, around 30,000 came in over the fence, the rest got in some other way - we are talking about a total breakdown of security."

Overcrowding pushed safety levels to the margins of what was acceptable, according to Steve Anderson, the district council's head of environmental health.

"The event was not safe, as a pure function of the numbers of people on the site and the movement of those people."

A number of fans needed to be pulled from the crowd watching headliners Travis after fainting in the crush, while movements of people to see star attractions such as Leftfield and Fat Boy Slim caused bottlenecks across the site.

Mr Eavis, who estimates the numbers of fence jumpers at 10-15,000, declared that whether Glastonbury runs next year will be "my decision".

He insisted that safety was not a problem: "There were fewer medical emergencies this year than there were last year.

"I didn't really feel crowding was an issue. I was in the crowds all the time. I was walking around on Saturday night after 12pm when everything closes and all the various worlds collide."

For Glastonbury 2001, a £1m steel barrier, nearly twice the height of the existing 11ft fence, will be thrown around the site, the farmer said.

Each section will slide together securely, without nuts and bolts, and will be fixed with metre-long prongs driven into the ground.

An 11ft wide steel track will be laid around the five mile fence to enable a fleet of 50 Land Rovers to patrol the site, and also to deter tunnellers burrowing their way in.

Mr Anderson said: "The work that Michael is doing at least has started to address the problems in terms of control of numbers. But it is just the beginning. There's a whole host of issues that need to be addressed, not least of which is ensuring that people don't make the journey to attempt to get in."

Aside from safety, a major bone of contention is the unofficial festival which takes place at Pylle, east of the official site, and caters for the convoys of travellers who see themselves as standard-bearers for the original "free festival" spirit. The travellers generate perennial complaints from villagers, but Mr Eavis said there had been "no police involved, and no violence" at Pylle.

The deaths at Roskilde are focusing minds this year. The fatal crush happened in the "mosh pit" near the stage as thousands of fans surged forward in a muddy field during a performance by American grunge band Pearl Jam.

Like Glastonbury, Roskilde is a charitable event renowned for its laid-back atmosphere. After the deaths, many, including Oasis and Pet Shop Boys, cancelled performances as a mark of respect.

The cause of the deaths remains unclear, but overcrowding does not appear to have been the crucial factor; the crowd watching Pearl Jam was not as big as the Glastonbury crowds, nor as big as the audiences at other stages.

Mr Anderson, who visited Denmark last week with an officer from Avon and Somerset constabulary, decided that two factors were vital to reducing the potential for such tragedies at Glastonbury.

"One is that the pit crew, the security men in front of stage are - as they are at Glastonbury - of fairly high competence. And [secondly] that there are personnel whose role is purely crowd surveillance from a more remote position, and when that person identifies a problem they must have the authority and the communication system to do something about it."

The regulatory board meets on October 12 to discuss a report on Glastonbury 2000, which is published later this week.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two men and a woman were under armed guard in hospital last night after a suspected gangland shooting in Leeds which has seen two deaths and seven woundings in seven months.
fields.body:
Gangland fears after shooting

Two men and a woman were under armed guard in hospital last night after a suspected gangland shooting in Leeds which has seen two deaths and seven woundings in seven months.

Straw's wife to modernise

Alice Perkins, the wife of the home secretary, Jack Straw, has been appointed head of the Civil Service corporate management, which will put her in charge of plans to modernise Whitehall.

Britons held for another month

A Yugoslav military court has extended for a month the detention of two Britons and two Canadians arrested on suspicion of terrorism. Adrian Prangnell and John Yore, who were training local police in Kosovo for the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, were detained in August on the border with Montenegro.

Airport worker hit by lightning

A Heathrow runway worker was lucky to survive after lightning hit a Boeing 767 and shot down a cable connected to his headphones. Ian Bartholomew, 28, was unhurt.

Mensa status for deprived pupils

Thirty pupils from Brynmawr comprehensive in one of the most deprived areas of south Wales have joined Mensa after tests showed they have IQs of at least 148.

3 share £11.5m

Three tickets shared the £11.5m rollover lottery jackpot with numbers 12, 15, 27, 32, 40 and 44. The bonus ball was 35. There was no winner of the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot.

fields.headline: Baby hospital 'not asked for help'
fields.standfirst: 'Great Ormond Street is leading place for joined twins'
fields.trailText: A renowned surgeon has stepped into the controversy over the case of Jodie and Mary by asking for his hospital to be recognised as the leading centre for conjoined twins, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A renowned surgeon has stepped into the controversy over the case of Jodie and Mary by asking for his hospital to be recognised as the leading centre for conjoined twins, it emerged yesterday.

The request from Lewis Spitz, of Great Ormond Street hospital, central London, is being seen by some as an implied criticism of St Mary's in Manchester as it prepares to operate on the twins. Professor Spitz wrote to the Department of Health asking for his hospital to be recognised as Britain's "centre of excellence" in the field.

Great Ormond Street has treated 16 sets of twins in the past 16 years and carried out 12 operations which half the children survived. St Mary's has never carried out the sort of operation needed for Jodie and Mary.

Last week the twins' parents announced that they were giving up a legal battle against the operation, which will inevitably lead to the death of the weaker twin, Mary.

The mother and father, who are devout Catholics from the Maltese island of Gozo, argued passionately in the high court and appeal court that their religious convictions meant they could not give permission for the operation even though both girls will die if it does not go ahead.

During the court hearings, it became apparent that St Mary's had no "direct experience" of performing the operation. It is thought that medics at Great Ormond Street have not been happy that they were not asked for advice despite their vast experience.

On the first day of the appeal, Professor Spitz said in a radio interview his team would be available if they needed "further assessment" but confirmed that Great Ormond Street had not been approached.

One of the first questions the appeal court judges asked was why no second opinion had been sought. It then ordered that a second team of doctors - from Great Ormond Street - examine the children. They "broadly" agreed with the findings of their Manchester counterparts but suggested that the girls could live longer if not separated than the St Mary's doctors had predicted.

Why the parents ended up at St Mary's rather than Great Ormond Street has never been made clear. It is known that a doctor at the hospital in their homeland which discovered that the woman was carrying conjoined twins had trained at St Mary's and advised them to seek treatment there. Another of the senior medics at St Mary's also has close links with Malta.

A spokesman for St Mary's said that it was "unaware" of Professor Spitz's letter. He also denied a report that its lead surgeon was considering abandoning the operation. "The position of the Central Manchester healthcare trust has not changed."

Following the announcement from the parents that they would not take the case to the House of Lords or the European court of human rights, the hospital said only that there were no "immediate" plans to carry out the operation. The surgeons have said that ideally they would operate on the twins when they were into their third month. They are now eight weeks old.

A spokeswoman for Great Ormond Street confirmed that Professor Spitz had written to the Department of Health but refused to be drawn into whether the letter criticised St Mary's.

fields.headline: Hover and out
fields.standfirst: 30-year cross Channel service comes to an end
fields.trailText: Two hovercraft that have carried cars and passengers from Dover across the Channel for more than 30 years were taken out of service yesterday.
fields.body:
Two hovercraft that have carried cars and passengers from Dover across the Channel for more than 30 years were taken out of service yesterday.

The craft, which carried 52 cars, have been forced into retirement by competition from the Channel tunnel and the new breed of "superferries", as well as passengers' demands for more luxury.

Heralded with Concorde as the brave new face of travel when launched in the late 1960s, the hovercraft will be replaced by two high-speed catamarans, which carry 90 cars and allow users to travel in luxury, but are slower.
